PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R.G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House records its deep sadness at the death, on 8 January 1996, of Francois Mitterrand, the former President of France, and expresses its deep sympathy to his widow, Mrs Danielle Mitterrand, to the Mitterrand family and to the people of France in their bereavement, and requests that this motion be conveyed by the Speaker on behalf of the House to the Government of France.

I move this motion on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who, along with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), is today attending the special Tasmanian memorial service in Hobart. Francois Mitterrand was a distinguished statesman and visionary leader. As President for 14 years, he stands alongside President de Gaulle as a key figure in the history of modern France. Mr Mitterrand's death, after a long illness which he bore with dignity and fortitude, was a profound loss for France, Europe and the world.

Francois Mitterrand once described politics as the art of judo—the art of nimbleness and the ability to surprise your opponent. In a political career which spanned almost 50 years, Mr Mitterrand proved himself a very skilled exponent of the art of politics as he defined it. He also brought to his political life the intellectual breadth and deep learning, enormous energy and sheer tenacity which made him not just a political survivor throughout those fifty years but a towering and influential figure in shaping the destiny of postwar France.

Elected to the French National Assembly in 1946, Mr Mitterrand soon after became, at the age of 30, a minister in President de Gaulle's first postwar government. He served in successive governments until 1958, when he broke with President de Gaulle. The next two decades were dominated by his rebuilding and leadership of the Socialist Party, which provided the platform for his third and successful bid for the presidency in 1981. His easy victory of a second term in 1988 was a tribute both to his popularity and to his authoritative dominance of the French political scene. Having gone the rounds with such people as the famous French Foreign Minister Couvre de Meville, de Gaulle and others, he was subsequently elected twice as President of France.

As is inevitably the case with such a long period in office, there are many different views and judgments about the achievements of Mr Mitterrand's two terms as President. But there is no doubt or disagreement about either the strength of his reforming zeal and of his commitment to social justice, or his pragmatic appreciation of economic realities as when, in 1983, he recognised the need to put aside his dream of `socialism in one country' and implemented an economic reform program based on fiscal restraint.

There is also no doubt that Francois Mitterrand was one of the chief architects of European unity and that this will be his most significant and enduring legacy. Mr Mitterrand was first and foremost a Frenchman, with a passionate pride in, and commitment to, his country. But he had the vision to realise that the best guarantee for France's future rested not in the pursuit of a narrow nationalism, but in securing a leading role for France in bringing about a united and peaceful European community. To achieve this goal, he worked with passionate conviction and unrelenting determination to build a partnership between France and Germany, a country against which he had fought in his youth. His clasping of hands with German Chancellor Kohl in a cemetery at Verdun in 1983 symbolised not only the friendship of the two leaders, but also the new era of peaceful and effective cooperation between their two nations.

While the goal of European unity was his major preoccupation, Mr Mitterrand also exercised active and constructive leadership to ensure a wider international role for France. He often took a direct and personal interest, as when he flew to Sarajevo in 1992 to draw attention to the plight of Bosnia. He was a catalyst in achieving closer cooperation between Europe and the United States. Under his leadership, France played a leading role in seeking resolutions to the problems in Cambodia and the Middle East. He committed French troops to the Gulf War, and to peacekeeping operations in Rwanda, Bosnia and Somalia.

Mr Mitterrand also displayed far‐sighted leadership in redefining France's role in the South Pacific. Under his presidency, France's enlightened policy of reconciliation with the indigenous peoples of France's overseas territories, especially through the Matignon Accords in New Caledonia, was a valuable initiative.

For Australians, Francois Mitterrand will be remembered most warmly for his declaration in 1992 of a moratorium on French nuclear testing. His decision was much appreciated, especially in the South Pacific, and was a positive contribution towards the goal of nuclear non‐proliferation. I am sure that Mr Mitterrand would have welcomed the recent signature by France of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, and its commitment to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, when negotiated.

Mr Mitterrand was an outstanding politician and impressive individual. His many achievements have left a deep and lasting legacy, which will shape not only the future of France but also of Europe. I am sure that all members of this House join with me and the Prime Minister in expressing our deep condolences to Mr Mitterrand's family and the people of France. I commend this motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to associate the opposition with this motion of condolence, and to do so personally as someone who both met late President Mitterrand on several occasions and was privileged to attend his state requiem mass in January as Australia's representative. For 50 of his 79 years, Francois Mitterrand was absolutely at centre stage of French politics.

BREAK.PARA: For the last 14 years he was the longest serving and only socialist President of the Fifth Republic and he will be remembered by the French people for many things—firstly, for the extraordinary political perseverance of a man who first entered government in 1944, was a minister 11 times between 1946 and 1957, and spent some years in the wilderness—twice running unsuccessfully for the presidency before finally entering the Elysee as President.

He will be remembered as the man who forged the socialists into a united and effective party in the 1970s and 1980s—moving the party away from the large accumulation of Marxist dogma it then had toward the centre. He will be remembered for a flourishing period of domestic reform in the 1980s in human rights and social policy in particular—including the abolition of the death penalty, the protection of coloured immigrants in France, the curbing of police powers, the modernising of labour laws and the doubling of the national budget devoted to the arts.

He will be remembered also by French people particularly for his extraordinary complexity—and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) has already commented on that—as the Vichy participant who became the Resistance leader; the very formal and reserved man, as I can personally testify, who was nonetheless a superb public orator; and the way in which he unpredictably changed political course from conservatism to socialism to, at the end, what could probably only be described as something in the middle. The Deputy Prime Minister referred to a judo characterisation, which is very apt. I always think of that famous quote of his: `My strategy is to have only tactics.'

He will be remembered for the way in which he blew hot and cold on so many issues, which led Regis Debray to say on one famous occasion that at least that kept the lukewarm people away. They are the ways in which he will be remembered by the French, but of course he will also be remembered by the people of Europe as a whole as one of the prime architects of European union, holding closely, even in the sceptical 1990s, to his policy vision of an integrated Europe based on close Franco‐German entente.

He will also be remembered not only by the people of France and Europe but also by the people of the world in particular for two great legacies, the first of them being his cultural legacy—the series of massive building projects that changed the face, in ways that have only enhanced it, of unquestionably one of the world's loveliest cities, Paris. This included the reconstruction of the Louvre with I.M. Pei's glass pyramid as the centrepiece, the great modernistic arch at La Defence, the new Bastille Opera House and the new national library project. All are a magnificent testimony to his cultural vision.

He will be remembered by the whole world for his contribution to a saner nuclear world. There were as always some twists and turns along the way. It has to be acknowledged that he opposed de Gaulle originally in the development of France's independent nuclear program then became one of that programs staunchest defenders.

But then came his momentous decision in 1992 to impose a moratorium on French nuclear tests in the South Pacific—a decision which was absolutely crucial in developing the momentum that we are now seeing for a nuclear non‐proliferation treaty consolidated and made indefinite in its scope and for a comprehensive test plan treaty which we all hope will be negotiated to its conclusion this year. Hopefully, ultimately, it will be the forerunner for the achievement of the complete elimination of nuclear weapons to which we are all in this House committed.

Francois Mitterrand's life left an extraordinary legacy for France, for Europe and for the whole world. It is entirely appropriate and fitting under those circumstances that we in this Australian parliament should mark his passing with this respectful motion of condolence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to associate myself with this condolence motion for former President Francois Mitterrand. As others have said before me, Francois Mitterrand was the longest serving French President, at least of the Fifth Republic, having served as the President for 14 years. He developed a reputation not just during his time as the President of France but throughout his adult life as being the consummate political pragmatist.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) used the well known quote that Mr Mitterand's strategy was only to have tactics. Certainly if one reads the various biographies of Francois Mitterrand, whilst there may be a lot of confection in much of the work written about him in recent years, the theme of pragmatism is something that emerges through those works. He was a socialist president. When his government first came to office in the early 1980s it pursued social democratic, centre left policies and by the time he left office it had moved in the opposite direction—I suppose to be fair, in line with the general move in the intellectual debate around the world.

He made a great contribution to European security and European peace through developing the relationship between France and Germany and always understood that the embrace between France and Germany was fundamental to the stability of Western Europe. He, along with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, was instrumental in designing and finally achieving the Treaty of Maastricht on European union in 1991. He also had a broader world vision as French presidents frequently do. He had a world vision for France, but a constructive vision for the national community. He involved France in the Gulf War coalition in a very constructive way and he committed French forces to peacekeeping operations in Rwanda, Bosnia and Somalia.

Under Mitterrand's presidency, France's bilateral relationship with Australia evolved in a very constructive way. There was, for example, the resolution, albeit for a limited period, of the difficult issue of New Caledonia through the signing of the Matignon Accords. As others have said, it was President Mitterrand, I believe in the face of pressure of local government elections or whatever, who imposed a moratorium on French nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

BREAK.PARA: France's agreement to limited reforms to the common agricultural policy of the European Union and to the conclusion of the Uruguay Round of the GATT was also an initiative of President Mitterrand's and, obviously, was also welcomed by our farmers who had suffered and who, let me say, continue to suffer under the weight of the common agricultural policy.

Australia and France under the Mitterand presidency collaborated successfully in a number of multilateral spheres, notably on Antarctica in which we both pursued successful joint diplomatic initiatives to protect the environment and to prohibit mining activity, and disarmament where there was close collaboration between Australia and France on the chemical weapons convention and a range of other similar issues. On Cambodia, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition would know better than I would, I understand we maintained a close dialogue with France during that period. There has also been a good record of cooperation in the South Pacific in areas such as development assistance, disaster relief, fisheries, surveillance and extensive defence contacts.

So during the Mitterrand presidency the relationship between Australia and France developed very constructively. He was, therefore, from Australia's point of view an important president but, above all, he was a very significant figure in the history of modern France and one of the most significant of presidents in the life of the Fifth Republic. Mr Speaker, I extend my sympathy to President Mitterrand's widow, Danielle and also, on his passing, to the people of France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your appointment to your very high office. I also wish to add a few words to the condolence motion for President Mitterrand. I was very excited when Mitterrand achieved his goal of leading the socialist forces to power in France in 1981. In so many ways he became a symbol of the possibilities of what might be called the democratic socialist approach that later developed and flourished throughout Europe. Although it is true that Mitterrand began with a more conservative approach, there is no doubt that he became very committed to the idea that you could have a left‐wing party which was committed to both the ideals of democracy and an egalitarian society. He saw that model as distinctively different from the Soviet system.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout his life both in domestic politics in France and in foreign policy throughout France's relations with the Soviet Union, he took a very tough attitude towards Soviet communism. So here you had a president who was from the left and who believed very much in the ideals of democratic socialism but who had no illusions whatever about the totalitarian system of the Soviet Union and who therefore, generally speaking, supported the broader democratic forces throughout the world.

Interestingly, looking at Mitterrand's period in office, during the reign of his governments all of the difficulties, problems, contradictions and issues which social democratic parties faced were faced by his governments—and he faced them very squarely. Initially, he began with a socialisation program of nationalisation of enterprises as a way of ensuring significant control of the French economy. But he found that this process was not very successful, given that he also wanted links with the rest of Europe in a tight European Union. So, as a consequence of that, Mitterrand eventually abandoned that program and moved to a more centre‐left program which allowed him to build bridges with the other nations of Europe and to strengthen the European Union.

As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) said, his most enduring achievement was in his dream that France would be at the centre of a greater European Union. He was very much in favour of expanding the European Union and yet making the Union more meaningful. He very much supported the development of the European Parliament. Interestingly, for some time now the biggest grouping in the European Parliament has been the democratic socialists, with whom he had considerable links.

So Mitterrand leaves a legacy of a man who believed very much in basic democratic socialist ideals and egalitarianism and who, nevertheless, was flexible in seeing that in the modern world different policies may be required at different times to achieve those goals. He certainly looked for those goals, but whether you can say that he finally achieved them, only history will tell. There is no doubt that throughout all of the governments that he was involved with, Mitterrand was always trying to find solutions for the betterment of the people of France and, in particular, to achieve greater equality and justice within France itself.

Much has been said of his commitment to disarmament and to stopping French testing in the South Pacific. For us in Australia that was further confirmation of the basic decency of Mitterrand and his concern to have good relations with this part of the world. We can all look to the Mitterrand era as one in which the relations between Australia and France were very good.

He, interestingly, very much loved and was committed to French culture. Nevertheless, he was an internationalist. He believed in important relations with the rest of Europe, with bringing together all the nations and cultures of Europe and, in that sense, he also appreciated others' cultures and others' points of view. I think Mitterrand was one of the important leaders of this century and we all mourn his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the other speakers today. As the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) indicated, Mitterrand's victory in 1981 was probably as interesting to my generation and the progressive wing of politics as a Thatcherite victory in Britain. As earlier speakers have remarked, he was a very complex person, a man who, in 1935, led demonstrations against foreign workers but, with his victory in the 1980s, increased their rights in France. In the Fourth Republic, when he was variously minister for veterans' affairs, overseas territories and the interior, Mitterrand was responsible for the first liberalisation of rights in colonial Africa but, at the same time, condoned the torture of FLN fighters in Algeria. That lead‐up to 1981, after the rise in 1968, and his ability to re‐establish the strength of the Socialist Party was, indeed, deeply inspiring to many of us. Only yesterday my father remarked on the huge emotion in Paris when he arrived there on 10 May 1981 as Deputy Premier of New South Wales and on the exuberance of the French population at that change of the French political scape.

SPEECH.PARA: To my mind, Mitterrand was most crucial, as some speakers have alluded to, in the actual transformation of French Left politics. From the 1920s, the Left in France had been largely dominated by the pro‐Stalinist Communist Party and their control of the major trade union federation, the CGT. Mitterrand had to walk a very narrow tightrope in essentially forming a socialist party that had credibility after its rather unfortunate history during the Fourth Republic. He was a man who had sacrificed himself by being one of the few on the left to strongly oppose the basic coup by de Gaulle and was to lose his seat as a result of that. He went into the wilderness and then, in 1971, became the first secretary of a party he had not previously been a member of, from a very small base.

On the one hand, he had to increase the strength of the Socialist Party and, on the other, he had to try to bring the Communist Party into an electoral alliance. He succeeded in doing that by the joint program and, in that process, marginalised the French Communist Party as a force in France. Of course, the collapse of the Soviet Union and later events were to strengthen that trend, but that was his essential accomplishment—he made the French Socialist Party the major party of the Left.

The period from 1981 did have a lot of very essential social reforms: the abolition of the death penalty; the abolition of the rather draconian security court; and people have referred to the increase in the arts expenditure. Modern Paris has been transformed by many of the edifices that he was responsible for. One thing that has been left out and is crucial, and very contemporary in this country, is the question of centralisation of power. He essentially—very crucially—got rid of the authoritarian centralised Bonapartist leftovers. He abolished the prefecture system to a large degree—undermined it—and established local and regional government. Even in Australia at this time we debate the process of eliminating municipal power and centralising controls.

In conclusion, I join with others and finally refer to a fairly novel and independent foreign policy, on the one hand supporting Pershing missiles, being part of NATO, being fairly anti‐Soviet but, on the other hand, being one of the first people to welcome Gorbachev into the international community, supporting the Third World, taking an independent line in regard to the US embargo on Cuba and, of course, supporting liberation movements in El Salvador and Nicaragua.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following amendments to the standing orders be made:
Days and hours of meeting
Unless otherwise ordered, the House shall meet for the dispatch of business on each—

TAB.TAB: Monday, at 12.30 p.m.
Tuesday, at 2 p.m.
Wednesday, at 9.30 a.m.
Thursday, at 9.30 a.m.

PARA.TAB: From the termination of the last sitting in the second week of sittings, the House shall stand adjourned until 12.30 p.m. on the third Monday after the termination, unless the Speaker shall, by writing addressed to each Member of the House, fix an alternative day or hour of meeting. The 4-weekly cycle will then be repeated.
Adjournment and next meeting

TAB.TAB: At 10.30 p.m. on a sitting Monday or Tuesday, at 7.30 p.m. on a sitting Wednesday and at 5.30 p.m. on a sitting Thursday the Speaker shall propose the question—That the House do now adjourn—which question shall be open to debate. No amendment may be moved to this question:

PARA.TAB: Provided that:
(a) if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, that division, and any division consequent upon that division, shall be completed and the result announced;
(b) if, on the question—That the House do now adjourn—being proposed, a Minister requires the question to be put forthwith without debate, the Speaker shall forthwith put the question;
(c) a motion for the adjournment of the House may be moved by a Minister at an earlier hour;
(d) any business under discussion and not disposed of at the time of the adjournment shall be set down on the Notice Paper for the next sitting, and
(e) if the question—That the House do now adjourn—is negatived, the House shall resume the proceedings at the point at which they had been interrupted:

TAB.TAB: Provided further that, if at 11 p.m. on a sitting Monday or Tuesday, at 8 p.m. on a sitting Wednesday or at 6 p.m. on a sitting Thursday, the question before the House is—That the House do now adjourn—the Speaker shall interrupt the debate, at which time—

PARA.TAB: (f) a Minister may require that the debate be extended until 11.10 p.m., 8.10 p.m. or 6.10 p.m., as appropriate, to enable Ministers to speak in reply to matters raised in the preceding adjournment debate; at 11.10 p.m., 8.10 p.m. or 6.10 p.m., as appropriate, or upon the earlier cessation of the debate, the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting, or
(g) if no action is taken by a Minister under paragraph (f) the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: Time limits

TAB.TAB: The maximum period for which a Member may speak on any subject indicated in this standing order, and the maximum period for any debate, shall not, unless otherwise ordered, exceed the period specified opposite to that subject in the following schedule:

ROW.ENTRY: Election of Speaker or Deputy Speaker—
Discussion of definite matter of public importance (under standing order 107)—
Question for adjournment of House to terminate the sitting—
5 minutes(no extension of time to be granted)
Provided that, if no other Member rises to address the House, a Member who has already spoken to the motion may speak a second time for a period not exceeding 5 minutes.
Censure or want of confidence motion accepted by a Minister as provided under standing order 110—
Prime Minister or one Minister deputed by the Prime Minister
Limitation of debate—Motion for allotment of time (under standing order 92)—
Leader of Opposition or one Member deputed by the Leader
Leader of Opposition or one Member deputed by the Leader
Prime Minister or one Member deputed by the Prime Minister
Leader of Opposition or one Member deputed by the Leader
Other bills (Opposition or other non-government Member)—
Prime Minister or one Member deputed by the Prime Minister
Consideration in detail of a bill—
Each Member—Unspecified number of periods each not exceeding
Consideration of amendments made or requested by the Senate—
Each Member—Unspecified number of periods each not exceeding
Question "That grievances be noted" (under standing order 106)—
Proposed resolution relating to tax or duty—
Leader of Opposition or one Member deputed by the Leader
Suspension of standing orders (under standing order 399)—

Extension of time—with the consent of a majority of the House or of the Committee, to be determined without debate, a Member may be allowed to continue a speech interrupted under the foregoing provisions of this standing order for one period not exceeding
Provided that no extension of time shall exceed half of the original period allotted.

SPEECH.PARA: Routine of business

PARA.TAB: The House shall proceed on the days indicated with its ordinary business in the following routine:
Monday

1. Presentation of, and statements on, reports from parliamentary committees and delegations. 2. Orders of the day for the resumption of debate on motions moved in connection with committee and delegation reports (debate concluding no later than 1.15 p.m.). 3. Private Members' business (debate commencing no later than 1.15 p.m., debate to be interrupted at 1.45 p.m.). 4. Members' statements (at approximately 1.45 p.m.). 5. Questions without notice (at 2 p.m.). 6. Presentation of petitions. 7. Private Members' business (in continuation for 1 hour). 8. Grievance debate (debate to continue for 1 hour and 20 minutes). 9. Notices and orders of the day.
Tuesday
1. Questions without notice. 2. Presentation of papers. 3. Ministerial statements, by leave. 4. Matter of public importance. 5. Notices and orders of the day.
Wednesday and Thursday

1. Notices and orders of the day. 2. Questions without notice (at 2 p.m.). 3. Presentation of papers. 4. Ministerial statements, by leave. 5. Matter of public importance. 6. Notices and orders of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: Interruption for question period

PARA.TAB: At 2 p.m. on each sitting Monday, Wednesday and Thursday the Speaker shall interrupt the business before the House in order that questions without notice can be called on:
Provided that:
(a) if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, the division shall be completed and the result announced; and
(b) the Speaker shall fix the time for the resumption of the debate on any business under discussion and not disposed of at the time of interruption.

SPEECH.PARA: New business

PARA.TAB: No new business may be taken after 11 p.m., unless the House otherwise orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Precedence to government and private Members' business

PARA.TAB: Government business shall, on each day of sitting, have precedence of private Members' business except on each sitting Monday as provided by standing order 101.

At the conclusion of grievance debate the Speaker shall put forthwith and successively, without further debate or amendment, any questions on which a division had been called for earlier in the day, and which had been deferred pursuant to standing order 193.

SPEECH.PARA: Private Members' business—procedure

PARA.TAB: In the period during which private Members' business is accorded precedence pursuant to standing order 104, notices and orders of the day relating to private Members' business shall be called on by the Clerk in the order in which they appear on the Notice Paper. When the time allotted by standing order 102C or 104, or by the Selection Committee, for an item of business has expired, consideration shall be interrupted by the Chair and the question before the Chair shall be put:

Provided that, where the Selection Committee has determined that consideration of a matter should continue on a future day, at the time fixed for interruption, the Chair shall interrupt proceedings and further consideration of the matter shall be set down on the Notice Paper for the next sitting.

Notices by private Members of their intention to present bills shall stand referred to the Selection Committee which shall give priority to them over other notices and orders of the day and determine the order in which they are to be presented. Upon the respective notice being called on by the Clerk, the Member in whose name the notice stands shall present the bill and may speak for a period not exceeding five minutes in support thereof. The bill shall then be read a first time and the motion for the second reading shall be set down on the Notice Paper for the next sitting.

If the motion for the second reading of any private Member's bill is agreed to by the House, further consideration shall be accorded precedence of other private Members' business and the Selection Committee may allot times for consideration of the remaining stages of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Grievance debate

TAB.TAB: Notwithstanding standing order 105, the first order of the day, government business, on each sitting Monday following the conclusion of private Members' business shall be a question to be proposed by the Speaker, "That grievances be noted" to which question any Member may address the House or move any amendment.

PARA.TAB: If consideration of the question has not been concluded after 1 hour and 20 minutes, the debate thereon shall be interrupted and the Speaker shall put any questions then before the House, and after resolution of those questions, shall forthwith call on the next order of the day, government business.

SPEECH.PARA: Statements by Members

TAB.TAB: At 1.45 p.m. on each sitting Monday the Speaker shall interrupt private Members' business in order that statements by Members can be called on. A Member, other than a Minister, may be called by the Chair to make a statement for a period not exceeding 90 seconds. The period allowed for these statements shall not extend beyond 2 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: Replies to questions

TAB.TAB: The reply to a question on notice shall be given by delivering it to the Clerk. A copy of the reply shall be supplied to the Member who asked the question, and the question and reply shall be published in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: If after the expiration of 60 days of a question first appearing on the Notice Paper, a reply has not been delivered to the Clerk, the Member who asked the question may rise in his or her place at the conclusion of the question period and request the Speaker to write to the Minister concerned, seeking reasons for the delay in answering.

SPEECH.PARA: Questions to Speaker

TAB.TAB: At the conclusion of the question period, questions without notice may be put to the Speaker relating to any matter of administration for which he or she is responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: When division may be taken

TAB.TAB: A division shall not be proceeded with unless more than one Member has called for a division. If one Member only calls for a division, that Member may inform the Speaker that he or she wishes his or her dissent to be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and in Hansard and the Member's dissent shall be so recorded:

PARA.TAB: Provided that, on sitting Mondays, any division called for in the House during the consideration of private Members' business on a question, other than a motion moved by a Minister, shall stand deferred until after the conclusion of grievance debate.

SPEECH.PARA: First reading

TAB.TAB: On the presentation of a bill by a Member, or on the receipt from the Senate of a bill for the concurrence of the House, it shall be read a first time without any question being put.

SPEECH.PARA: Second reading and explanatory memorandum

TAB.TAB: After the first reading a future day shall be appointed for the Member to move "That this bill be now read a second time" and the bill shall meanwhile be printed:

PARA.TAB: Provided that if copies of the bill have been circulated among Members the second reading may be moved immediately after the bill has been read a first time. The debate on the question shall then be adjourned to a future day.

In the case of a bill presented by a Minister other than an Appropriation or Supply Bill, an explanatory memorandum signed by the Minister and including an explanation of the reasons for the bill shall be presented to the House at the conclusion of the Minister's speech on moving the second reading.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference to Main or other committee

TAB.TAB: At least seven days after the first reading and before the resumption of debate on the motion "That this bill be now read a second time", a motion may be moved without notice "That this bill be referred to the Main Committee for the remainder of the second reading and consideration in detail stages" or "That the bill be referred to the [here insert title of committee] for consideration and an advisory report". A motion to refer a bill to a committee for an advisory report may specify a date by which the committee is to report to the House.

PARA.TAB: Provided that, in the case of bills presented by Ministers:

(a) a Minister may present a list of bills proposed to be referred to the Main Committee or other committees and move without notice either immediately or at a later time "That the bills be referred to committee(s) in accordance with the list"; and
(b) the bills referred to the Main Committee may be considered by it after details of the reference have been published in the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference to Main Committee after advisory report presented

TAB.TAB: When a bill has been referred to a committee for an advisory report, and the committee's report has been presented to the House, the bill may be referred to the Main Committee for the remainder of the second reading and consideration in detail stages in accordance with standing order 217A.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration in detail unless—

TAB.TAB: After the second reading, or when proceeding under standing order 221, after those proceedings have been disposed of, the House or the Main Committee, as appropriate, shall forthwith consider the bill in detail unless—

PARA.TAB: (a) the bill has been referred to a select committee in accordance with standing order 221, or
(b) if the bill is being considered in the House, the House grants leave for the question "That this bill be now read a third time" to be moved forthwith, or
(c) if the bill is being considered in the Main Committee, the Committee grants leave for the question "That this bill be reported to the House without amendment" to be put forthwith.

SPEECH.PARA: Motions to print or take note

TAB.TAB: On any paper being presented to the House as provided in this chapter, a Minister or an Assistant Minister may move without notice either or both of the following motions: 1. That the paper be printed; 2. That the House take note of the paper:

PARA.TAB: Provided that, at the conclusion of the period for presentation of papers in the routine of business under standing order 101 on each sitting day, one motion may be moved that the House take note of certain papers presented that day, and the resumption of the debate on the motion to take note of each of the papers shall be made a separate order of the day on the Notice Paper:

Provided further that, if any of the motions contained in this standing order is not moved by a Minister at the time of the presentation of the paper or papers, a motion for printing or taking note of a specific paper may be moved, on notice, on a subsequent day.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) New standing order 100A be inserted after `BUSINESS':
Notice Paper

TAB.TAB: All business before the House shall be set down on the Notice Paper in accordance with the standing or sessional orders and the Notice Paper shall be published.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Standing order 217C be omitted.

Mr Speaker, I move this motion and further motions today against a backdrop where the coalition has been concerned for many years about declining standards in the Australian parliament. There is no question that there has been a lot of public concern about standards in the parliament and that has expressed itself in many ways. Accordingly, in the recent election campaign, the government flagged its intentions to introduce a series of measures by which we believe standards can be raised. It is also our view that, in addition to sensible procedural changes, the standards in parliament can be raised simply by a change of approach and attitude by the government of the day emanating from the Prime Minister.

Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made his views on this very clear when he addressed the House for the first time on the question of your election as Speaker. Today we follow up those first remarks by the Prime Minister in a more detailed way to put additional substance to the government's intentions in this regard. In doing so, let me also by way of preliminary remarks say that there can be no doubt about the backdrop by which we introduce these amendments. Let me remind people that it was a sad fact under the previous government that standards fell as low as they did.

The previous Prime Minister, for example, said—I was in the chamber when he said it—that question time was a privilege extended by the executive to the parliament. That really was an incredible statement to make. In fact, it is a denial of one of the basic precepts of our democratic institution. These people, on the other side now, acquiesced in that. Until it is repudiated, I would have to say that it still represents their view. The same person, with the acquiescence of those opposite, once described the Senate as swill. That, again, is a basic denial of the rights of people to be represented in the Senate—and the Senate is one of the great creations of the Australian federal parliament, providing a wide diversity of views and giving people, particularly those in outer areas, an opportunity to be heard and to thereby fully participate in the democratic process.

There are three motions to be put before the chair. Let me put them in context so that the first motion is properly rounded out. The first motion relates to a series of changes to the standing orders. I will come to each and every aspect of those in a moment. The second refers to the broadcast rules, another of the Keating legacies which I will say more about in due course.

The third motion which I will present to the House relates to arrangements for next Monday. As the parliament resumes we need to make some minor procedural changes for when the House gets into full swing. I foreshadow a further motion to deal with arrangements for the later part of today.

The motion now before the chair, and which is detailed in the Notice Paper, covers a wide range of matters. Can I just start by referring to comments by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) yesterday in congratulating the Speaker on his election. The Leader of the Opposition said:

Generally speaking, we chose when we were changing standing orders to refer those to the Procedure Committee. So we will be providing an opportunity tomorrow, when the standing orders get placed, for a gesture from the parliament as to whether there will be an assertion of the parliament over the executive by a reference of those standing order changes to the Procedure Committee.

You could have knocked me over with a feather! As I will demonstrate, virtually all of the proposals we have for the parliament today come from the Procedure Committee. It shows the incredible ignorance of these people opposite or, if that is too generous, the incredible arrogance of these people who have rejected and failed to take into account the recommendations of the Procedure Committee. Rather than you putting it to us that we should put it to the Procedure Committee, you ought to have the decency to acknowledge that these matters have come from the Procedure Committee—and you never had sufficient respect for the Procedure Committee to take up its earlier recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —So did the finishing time recommendation.

—Let me come to that matter first because I am happy to come to some of the timing questions. The motions being put before the chair include various changes to the sitting times of the parliament. Members will notice that we are proposing to bring question time back from 3 o'clock to 2 o'clock and that there will be no rostering of ministers for question time.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike in the last parliament when we had this incredible and ridiculous system of rostering, under the Howard government all ministers, including the Prime Minister, will attend question time every day and be available to answer questions. It was a feature of the Keating administration that the rostered day off for ministers was introduced. We do not accept the rostered day off system—we never did. It is a denial of one of the essential traits of this place, that ministers must be accountable to the parliament.

There is no doubt that the roster system removed an element of accountability in the proceedings of the House. As those who have been here for a number of years will know, when you have a minister on the run, part of having that minister accountable is the fact that they know the pressure is building on them. In a rostered day off situation, they know that if they can get through today, they have tomorrow off and they can sit in their offices, have a cup of tea and watch the proceedings on the monitor. You are making their lives easier than it is in the public interest for them to be. In making this change we make a significant change to the operation of the chamber and thereby enhance accountability of the executive to the parliament. So do not give me the message about accountability when you talk about the Procedure Committee.

PARA.BREAK: In respect of the change to question time timing, that is another of the Keating traits. It was a barely disguised ruse to take question time off the live broadcast. We have broad casts of the parliament as a result of the initiative of the Senate, where we pursued the matter and required the broadcasting of that chamber. The former Prime Minister and the former Leader of the House, the now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, were totally opposed to broadcasting the proceedings of this parliament. They did not want people to see the way they treated the parliament. They wanted to censor the proceedings of this parliament because there was such an adverse reaction from the public to the lowering of the standards under the previous administration. That was the fact of the matter. So we required the television broadcasting of the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the previous government—Mr Beazley and others—do? They changed the sitting time for question time, knowing that the ABC would then not broadcast live question time in the House of Representatives, knowing that the ABC would prefer to run Sesame Street. You hid behind Sesame Street to deny the Australian people the opportunity to see their representatives accounting in the parliament of the day.

Those opposite refer to the Procedure Committee. Its advice on this matter was that question time should be no later than 2.30. So on this very first matter you acted against the recommendation of the Procedure Committee as part of your political device to deny people the opportunity to see a live broadcast of question time. So we are bringing back question time to 2 o'clock. I think that in itself will be a very useful measure to buttress our reforms to enhance accountability in the House.
Secondly in respect of the sitting hours, the motion before the House proposes longer sitting hours to enable responsibilities to be carried out fully and properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Against the recommendations of the Procedure Committee.
—You are entirely predictable, I must say, even on day one.
—I said something about it yesterday but you were pretty silly and didn't pick it up.
—You said a lot yesterday which would worry Beazley.

—Yes. How is the campaign going on day two? Contrary to the impression that I suspect the shadow minister will be putting up, the fact is that this matter of sitting hours has been back and forward to the Procedure Committee over many years. In 1986, for example, they at that time decided not to make any changes. In 1993 they decided to make some changes to introduce the sort of system that operated under the previous government. Then in 1995 they reviewed the matter further. They decided to stick with the existing system, but in fact they did take the views of a number of our colleagues and of those views expressed by colleagues there were apparently—
—Six were in favour, six were against.

—Thank you very much. That is my point. There were 12 submissions and of those submissions six were basically in favour and six wanted to make some changes. The changes that they were proposing were to have a later sitting pattern and to have a properly defined meal break, which does provide people with the opportunity to enjoy a meal in the parliament and of course to see people in what is otherwise a very busy schedule for most members.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than being oblivious to the matters raised by the Procedure Committee, we have properly taken those into account. We think this is a fair balance. A few years ago we sat late every night. Now we have what I think is a fair combination. We finish early on Wednesday nights so that people can get out. On Thursday nights we finish early so people can catch their flights. As people are here on Monday and Tuesday nights, the parliament will sit. That will certainly enhance the opportunities for all members of the parliament to speak in the parliament and to put the views of their constituencies. We think we have reached a sensible balance, and we are therefore proceeding with that proposal.

The motion also implements some other key recommendations put by the Procedure Committee. The government will bring back the practice of having second reading speeches at the time bills are introduced so that members will have available to them a comprehensive package of information—the bill, the explanatory memorandum and the minister's second reading speech—to assist their understanding and appreciation of the legislation. This, in our view, is essential to ensure that this House is able to have the most informed debate possible. I think the shadow minister is nodding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.
—Well, it is a pity you did not implement it. I am happy to note his support for that. We are proceeding with that measure.

SPEECH.PARA: A further measure is that the House intends to return to the previous informal arrangements for agreeing to cognate debates by way of a suggestion being put from the chair immediately before the first resumption of debate on the second reading, thereby returning to a previous convention and arrangement that worked well in the past. We are now reintroducing it.

Recognising the importance of the grievance debate to private members, a set period of 80 minutes for grievance debate will be provided on each sitting Monday so that there is certainty for members who wish to raise issues of importance to their constituents. Whilst I understand that the opposition was prepared to support a set period of only one hour in its response to the Procedure Committee report, I am hopeful that they will see the merit in this extended period. In other words, they were going to give only an hour; we are giving more. It is a set period. For those who are new to this place, the grievance debate is particularly important because it gives you an extended period within which to make a contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten minutes more.

—Yes, but it is a set period, which you were not prepared to give. It is a guarantee. We think guaranteeing members their rights is important. I say to all new members that the grievance debate is a very important opportunity for you if you have a big issue and you want to make a substantial contribution. The grievance debate has a particular precedence and authority within the chamber, and I think this is a very good measure for all concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: A further measure proposes to standardise the speech time limit for consideration of amendments to legislation, regardless of whether they are amendments made or requested by the Senate or amendments moved in this House. The speech time limit will be the same; that is, an unlimited number of five-minute periods for each member on each question before the chair. I hope the opposition might support this reform as well. It is another one of the recommendations from the Procedure Committee, and I think it is a very sensible one.

In relation to questions on notice, members will be able to request the Speaker to follow up with ministers if answers are not provided within 60 days instead of 90 days, as in the last parliament. This is an important measure in the context of promoting open government. Again, we look forward to opposition support along the line of its response to the Procedure Committee report.

There are two additional matters, largely procedural, which were not the subject of the Procedure Committee reports—and I will make the reason for that clear. We intend to restore as permanent standing orders old sessional orders 150, which deals with questions to the Speaker at the end of question time, and 322, which deals with the single motion to take note of papers. So we are picking up some sessional orders and putting them into the standing orders. I am sure that will have the support of all members.

The last measure is that the motion seeks to give explicit and formal authority for the publication of the Notice Paper similar to that provided by the standing orders for the Votes and Proceedings. This will ensure that all matters in the Notice Paper, including questions on notice, whether in printed or electronic form, are covered by parliamentary privilege.Similar action has been taken in the Senate following a recommendation from the Senate Procedure Committee. Again, we think that is sensible.

There are a few other purely consequential and machinery amendments in the motion. I believe this is a good balance. It does give proper prominence to the rights and opportunities for private members. We believe the sitting times are very reasonable, taking into account the views of the people as expressed over a substantial period and taking into account the views of the procedures committees.

We believe that we are now redressing in the standing orders a series of the Keating measures, all of which effectively downgraded the significance of parliament. They certainly were tainted politically to provide the government of the day with an advantage and to reduce accountability. It will be set in the memory of the Australian people that the previous Labor administration cared little for parliamentary forms and processes and denied people their basic rights by the way in which they denigrated parliamentary processes. We today, on the first formal day of business of this parliament, start the long business of restoring the parliament to its proper place in the Australian democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I say at the outset that the opposition does commit itself to assisting the Speaker and you in the orderly operation of the House. I want to take up the point which the Leader of the House, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), finished on, and that is restoring the proper running of the parliament to some sort of order. That of course is a two-way street. If there is to be the cooperation of the opposition, there has to be the involvement of the opposition in procedures that come before it. Just as there was no discussion with the opposition on the election of the Speaker and the issues surrounding the so-called independence of the new Speaker, so was there no discussion with us about these proceedings which we are debating today.

SPEECH.PARA: I will go further and remind the House that on numerous occasions we had complaints from what was then the opposition of not being given adequate notice of government business; yet the issues that we are debating today in relation to the first notice of motion on the Notice Paper were tabled late in the day yesterday, and we did not see items 2 and 3 until the Notice Paper was released today. So what has happened on the first occasion that the new government has had to restore a proper sense of running and order of business to this House? It has failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was announced in a press release on 31 March.

—Their claim is that the basis upon which they let us know was a press release that was issued on 31 March. How many times were you critical of us making announcements through press releases and not having the decency—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —How many times! A litany of them. How many times were you critical of the issue being announced by way of press release and not being done through the forms of the House? So let us have none of this hypocrisy about the new approach. The government has in fact failed on its first day of business.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we did not see items 2 and 3 until the Notice Paper appeared today. I say this at the outset: this is not a very encouraging start. I hope it is not going to continue to be the norm because if it is it is going to make that task of cooperation which we are committed to that much more difficult. I simply want to place that on the record at this stage.

Having said that, the opposition does acknowledge the sense of a number of the government's proposed changes to the standing orders, and in respect of those we will be supporting them. For example, we do accept the amendment that will enable the mover of a bill to proceed to the second reading speech immediately. That makes sense. We also support the requirement for questions on notice to be responded to within 60 days.

We recognise that the government has a mandate in relation to the change of the roster, and we also recognise that mandate in the starting of question time in the parliament. But let me make this point on the starting of question time in the parliament coming back to 2 o'clock as distinct from 3 o'clock: we did not introduce the 3 o'clock time to avoid the media. How could you ever do that? We did it because we recognised in government the importance of enabling the Prime Minister and ministers to attend important functions outside of the parliament and still having the opportunity to get back here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Long lunches!

—What about the circumstances of today? There is going to be an amendment on the very first day that we are moving back to a 2 o'clock question time start; there is going to be an amendment today to make it 3 o'clock. We all know the circumstances for that, but I think there does have to be an acknowledgment that there are many occasions in which senior ministers and the Prime Minister in this House simply cannot be back by 2 o'clock. Today is one of those examples, but it is not limited to that. So let us not kid ourselves that there was no merit in the 3 o'clock start. We do acknowledge that you campaigned on the basis of the 2 o'clock start and we are not going to oppose it. I simply make this point: let us hear none of this argument that says that we put question time on at 3 o'clock to avoid some form of scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: The other area which we support is the changes to the broadcasting recommendations. As the Leader of the House has indicated, these were recommended by the Standing Committee on Procedure. We are not going to oppose those. However, the opposition does perceive significant difficulties associated with the proposed amendments to standing orders 40, 48A and 103. So we will be moving amendments to those particular aspects. In effect, what these amendments do in the suite of amendments that are before us is to alter the hours of sitting of the House principally by extending the sitting hours to 11 p.m. as distinct from 8 p.m. on Mondays and Tuesdays.

Before I come to the argument about the Procedure Committee, let us just understand what we are achieving here. The net effect of the government's proposals is that, whilst the House would be required to be around, either in recess or sitting, for an extra 4½ hours a week, the actual gain in sitting time is only 1½ hours. That comes about because the changes mean no net gain in sitting hours on Tuesday and only 1½ hours net gain on Monday.

I can see your backbench, Leader of the House, looking very pensive about this because they are starting to understand the circumstances in which you are changing arrangements. For a net gain of 1½ hours, you are requiring the place to sit around for an extra 4½ hours. That comes about because we are required to be here for the hour and a half dinner break. Those who have experienced it know that it is very difficult to get out of the place and back within that time of an hour and a half. The requirement is essentially to be here for that time but then stay on to 11 o'clock.

There are a number of reasons why we oppose this motion. The first item is on the agenda because we receive a lot of lecturing from the other side of the House about fiscal responsibility and cutting expenditure, but the costs associated with this little exercise are going to be very significant indeed. The members of staff and the support staff in the parliament that will have to be kept back to accommodate this arrangement are going to increase the cost of running this facility, this business, this House, significantly. I think it is an extravagance in those circumstances and particularly strange in an environment in which the government is, as I say, lecturing us constantly on the need to tighten up on spending.

The second area goes to the impact on one's health. Past experience has shown that late sittings do have a deleterious impact on the health of members' staff. This point was alluded to by the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) when this debate was on previously. She quoted Senator Herron—as we all know, a medical practitioner—on people's abilities to function when they are operating in the night-time hours as distinct from the daytime hours. We are not the only ones asserting it. There is an array of medical evidence that suggests it is a far more effective basis for operation to have people working in the daylight hours rather than being expected to continue fully up to date and fully operating late into the night.

BREAK.PARA: The third area of opposition is the impact it will have on families. We all know in this place that our families are affected whatever happens, whenever we sit. Whether we sit till 11 o'clock or not, we are away from them for most of the four days we are up here. But what about our support staff? Doesn't this government, which talks about the need for family based policies, have some regard to the impact that families are going to suffer by the fact that people who work here have to stay back for the extra time?

The fourth area I draw your attention to is that when this was debated on a previous occasion it was the media that indicated that they would, as a result of the 8 o'clock change, be prepared to give more consideration and reportage to adjournment debates. I know you have a lot on your backbench. Maybe that has more to do with content, but I would have thought that, with those people on the backbench who want to get into the adjournment debate as a means of getting their points of view up, this is an important consideration for them to take on board.

Finally, the most compelling reason for our amendments is: why change? The existing system works. It was originally referred to, as the Leader of the House has indicated, a standing committee which set the pattern of sitting hours that we now have. It took into account all the facts and reported on the adverse consequences. Whilst there was a dissenting report to that initial set of recommendations, the opposition committee members' part of that dissenting report did not oppose the change to the late night sittings from 11 o'clock back to 8 o'clock. That was the original report that determined the basis upon which we sit.

There was then a review, and that was contained in Time for review: bills, questions and working hours issued in June 1995. In that report, the committee noted that there was general acceptance of the new hours. The committee was reluctant to interfere with the pattern that was working well or to break the regularity of the 8 p.m. rise each day. The committee recommended that no change be made to the hours of sitting of the House. There was no dissenting report put to that. This was the opportunity for members to have made their submissions if they were complaining about it, but, as the Leader of the House indicated, only 12 submissions were received and there was essentially no dissent to the view that we should persist with the change.

We heard the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talk yesterday about the supremacy of the parliament over the executive. What we have here today is essentially an executive decision going against what the previous parliament determined. I would say that the sensible thing to do here is that, if the government has a claim for changing the hours, it should go back to the Procedure Committee. It should be referred back to the body that made the original decision, reviewed it and found it to be effective.

It is for those reasons that the opposition is not prepared to support the proposed motion. We do propose amendments to the government's motion. In essence, these amendments, which have been circulated, do refer the issue of sitting hours to the Procedure Committee—the body that the Leader of the House so heavily relies on when it suits him to assert his other arguments for change, but not in this case. Secondly, because I do acknowledge the government's right to extend the sitting hours of the House—and this side of the House does—in the interim, pending the report of the Procedure Committee, to achieve that extra net 1½ hours, I believe we should add half an hour each to Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, the circumstances at Port Arthur do override much of what we are talking about this week; I appreciate that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me conclude on this point: we are not opposing the bulk of what the government is proposing. We are opposed to the change in the sitting times and will move an amendment accordingly. We are not opposing the change to the broadcasting of proceedings contained in notice of motion No. 2. We are not opposing notice of motion No. 3, but I would be keen to hear the response by the Leader of the House, because our understanding from discussions is that government business which is listed for next Monday will only include the address-in‐reply debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that:
(a ) if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, the division shall be completed and the result announced; and
(b ) the Speaker shall fix the time for the resumption of the debate on any business under discussion and not disposed of at the time of interruption.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Precedence to government and private Members' business

PARA.TAB: Government business shall, on each day of sitting, have precedence of private Members' business except on each sitting Monday as provided by standing order 101.

SPEECH.PARA: At the conclusion of grievance debate the Speaker shall put forthwith and successively, without further debate or amendment, any questions on which a division had been called for earlier in the day, and which had been deferred pursuant to standing order 193.

PARA.TAB: In the period during which private Members' business is accorded precedence pursuant to standing order 104, notices and orders of the day relating to private Members' business shall be called on by the Clerk in the order in which they appear on the Notice Paper. When the time allotted by standing order 102C or 104, or by the Selection Committee, for an item of business has expired, consideration shall be interrupted by the Chair and the question before the Chair shall be put:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that, where the Selection Committee has determined that consideration of a matter should continue on a future day, at the time fixed for interruption, the Chair shall interrupt proceedings and further consideration of the matter shall be set down on the Notice Paper for the next sitting.

Notices by private Members of their intention to present bills shall stand referred to the Selection Committee which shall give priority to them over other notices and orders of the day and determine the order in which they are to be presented. Upon the respective notice being called on by the Clerk, the Member in whose name the notice stands shall present the bill and may speak for a period not exceeding five minutes in support thereof. The bill shall then be read a first time and the motion for the second reading shall be set down on the Notice Paper for the next sitting.

If the motion for the second reading of any private Member's bill is agreed to by the House, further consideration shall be accorded precedence of other private Members' business and the Selection Committee may allot times for consideration of the remaining stages of the bill.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding standing order 105, the first order of the day, government business, on each sitting Monday following the conclusion of private Members' business shall be a question to be proposed by the Speaker, "That grievances be noted" to which question any Member may address the House or move any amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: If consideration of the question has not been concluded after 1 hour and 20 minutes, the debate thereon shall be interrupted and the Speaker shall put any questions then before the House, and after resolution of those questions, shall forthwith call on the next order of the day, government business.

PARA.TAB: At 1.45 p.m. on each sitting Monday the Speaker shall interrupt private Members' business in order that statements by Members can be called on. A Member, other than a Minister, may be called by the Chair to make a statement for a period not exceeding 90 seconds. The period allowed for these statements shall not extend beyond 2 p.m.

The reply to a question on notice shall be given by delivering it to the Clerk. A copy of the reply shall be supplied to the Member who asked the question, and the question and reply shall be published in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: If after the expiration of 60 days of a question first appearing on the Notice Paper, a reply has not been delivered to the Clerk, the Member who asked the question may rise in his or her place at the conclusion of the question period and request the Speaker to write to the Minister concerned, seeking reasons for the delay in answering.

PARA.TAB: At the conclusion of the question period, questions without notice may be put to the Speaker relating to any matter of administration for which he or she is responsible.

A division shall not be proceeded with unless more than one Member has called for a division. If one Member only calls for a division, that Member may inform the Speaker that he or she wishes his or her dissent to be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and in Hansard and the Member's dissent shall be so recorded:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that, on sitting Mondays, any division called for in the House during the consideration of private Members' business on a question, other than a motion moved by a Minister, shall stand deferred until after the conclusion of grievance debate.

PARA.TAB: On the presentation of a bill by a Member, or on the receipt from the Senate of a bill for the concurrence of the House, it shall be read a first time without any question being put.
After the first reading a future day shall be appointed for the Member to move "That this bill be now read a second time" and the bill shall meanwhile be printed:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that if copies of the bill have been circulated among Members the second reading may be moved immediately after the bill has been read a first time. The debate on the question shall then be adjourned to a future day.

In the case of a bill presented by a Minister other than an Appropriation or Supply Bill, an explanatory memorandum signed by the Minister and including an explanation of the reasons for the bill shall be presented to the House at the conclusion of the Minister's speech on moving the second reading.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reference to Main or other committee

PARA.TAB: At least seven days after the first reading and before the resumption of debate on the motion "That this bill be now read a second time", a motion may be moved without notice "That this bill be referred to the Main Committee for the remainder of the second reading and consideration in detail stages" or "That the bill be referred to the [here insert title of committee] for consideration and an advisory report". A motion to refer a bill to a committee for an advisory report may specify a date by which the committee is to report to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that, in the case of bills presented by Ministers:

(a ) a Minister may present a list of bills proposed to be referred to the Main Committee or other committees and move without notice either immediately or at a later time "That the bills be referred to committee(s) in accordance with the list"; and
(b ) the bills referred to the Main Committee may be considered by it after details of the reference have been published in the Notice Paper.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reference to Main Committee after advisory report presented

PARA.TAB: When a bill has been referred to a committee for an advisory report, and the committee's report has been presented to the House, the bill may be referred to the Main Committee for the remainder of the second reading and consideration in detail stages in accordance with standing order 217A.

After the second reading, or when proceeding under standing order 221, after those proceedings have been disposed of, the House or the Main Committee, as appropriate, shall forthwith consider the bill in detail unless—

SPEECH.PARA: (a ) the bill has been referred to a select committee in accordance with standing order 221, or
(b ) if the bill is being considered in the House, the House grants leave for the question "That this bill be now read a third time" to be moved forthwith, or
(c ) if the bill is being considered in the Main Committee, the Committee grants leave for the question "That this bill be reported to the House without amendment" to be put forthwith.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Motions to print or take note

PARA.TAB: On any paper being presented to the House as provided in this chapter, a Minister or an Assistant Minister may move without notice either or both of the following motions: 1. That the paper be printed; 2. That the House take note of the paper:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that, at the conclusion of the period for presentation of papers in the routine of business under standing order 101 on each sitting day, one motion may be moved that the House take note of certain papers presented that day, and the resumption of the debate on the motion to take note of each of the papers shall be made a separate order of the day on the Notice Paper:

Provided further that, if any of the motions contained in this standing order is not moved by a Minister at the time of the presentation of the paper or papers, a motion for printing or taking note of a specific paper may be moved, on notice, on a subsequent day.
(b) New standing order 100A be inserted after `BUSINESS':

PARA.TAB: All business before the House shall be set down on the Notice Paper in accordance with the standing or sessional orders and the Notice Paper shall be published.

SPEECH.PARA: (c) Standing order 217C be omitted, and

(2) the House refers to the Standing Committee on Procedure the question of whether further changes should be made to the times of sitting of the House for report before the House adjourns on 9 May 1996".

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting that the opposition feels it necessary to shorten the sitting times in this place. The reason is quite obvious—they have not got enough members to make up the speakers lists. In fact, you would be aware, sir, that there is now a question which compares the Labor Party with a Toyota Tarago and asks, `What is the difference?' Of course, it is that the Tarago has more seats.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that there is a huge challenge for this parliament to get some decent legislation through for the purpose of turning around a very damaged economy, to reduce the level of debt and to legislate in all the areas to ensure that Australia can take its place in the world by the turn of the century, so that our young people can maintain the living standards which have been propped up over the last 13 years by the simple process of borrowing money. That is a substantial legislative task. It is the responsibility of this House to allocate the necessary time to debate these matters. I can assure the opposition that if they do not want to participate in the debate there will be plenty of people on this side who will do so and who will make the appropriate contribution. That is why the time is needed—to do a job.

The Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) would be the first to want shorter working hours. It was all he ever knew when he was in the union movement. All he ever wanted to do was shorten working hours. In the process, as we know, because of his activities and those of some of his mates, on one occasion, because they demanded more pay for less work, 40,000 of their members in the metal trades were sacked. It is something you should admit when you are fighting with one another in your party forums, as I am sure you will, as you continue to analyse the reasons why there are only 40 of you left.

The reality is that you do not need the time to debate these matters, but we do. We are going to deliver the debate. There will be none of this business of the executive treating this parliament with contempt, denying people an opportunity to properly put points of view, even denying the opposition the opportunity to put appropriate points to government which, from time to time in the last parliament, almost saved your hides. I can remember sitting down with a former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, now no longer a member of this place, and telling him that I had saved him from himself. He had the good sense to accept my amendment on that occasion.

When you come up with a good idea—and I am not holding my breath—we will not be too slow to recognise it if it is in the interests of the people. We will not have the outrageous approach used by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) when he used to say, `If you've got the numbers, why don't you use them?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you didn't.

—I didn't have the numbers. That is different. I would like to take a moment to refer to the motion relating to the broadcasting of proceedings. We will give Australians the opportunity to watch their parliament in process.
—Order! The honourable member will remember that the motion he is talking about is not yet before the House. You will confine your remarks to the motion before the House.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I picked that up on the basis that the Manager of Opposition Business did not make mention of that in his speech and I thought we were dealing with them cognately.
—No, we are not.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will continue with the reference to these other matters. When we look at this particular set of amendments, it is somewhat difficult to see why a lot of the matters have been included because they seem to be exactly the same. I assume it is only that they have chosen to rewrite the whole of the clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: But up‐front the point is that you want shorter working hours. You are proposing, as we see here in your amendment, to reduce the day by bringing on the adjournment debate at 8 p.m. on sitting Mondays and Tuesdays and 5.30 p.m. on Wednesdays and Thursdays.

The simple fact of life is that on two days of the week it is reasonable and possible for members to accommodate those additional hours. There are a lot of people who would be denied the opportunity to make their contribution in this place if those hours were not made available. So the reality is that we see no problem with that and, of course, we support it.

But I might add that, all in all, it is about time that a government stood up at the beginning of a parliamentary term and put these motions and these proposals down in the standing orders—not as a knee-jerk reaction, as has so often occurred in times gone by. In fact, as you would remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, we had the Speaker of this House stand up one day and make recommendations to us which we as a parliament had authorised him to make; and the next day we had the Leader of the House, on the then Prime Minister's instructions, come in here and pull the rug out from under his own Speaker—a practice of course that is not unique to the Labor Party.

There was a fellow called Jim Cope, and they would not even support him when he tried to discipline one of their ministers. They left him sitting in the chair, a lame duck Speaker. Of course, at that time he had had the courage to do what was necessary. He resigned from the chair; others have just kept the money. So the reality is that we are in this situation again.

But there would be no doubt other members here who wish to refer to the specific provisions, the subject of this motion, and the opposition's amendment which I reject wholeheartedly. The reality is that I would like to give them time to make some remarks.
