Apparently I will get the opportunity to talk about broadcasting a little later, and there are some quite significant comments I want to make on that subject. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset of my remarks could I congratulate you on your election to the position of Deputy Speaker of this House. I am sure that you will undertake your role in a forthright and impartial way.
—You are absolutely correct.
—You and I agree on so many things; it is mostly the things that you agree on that I find I have to agree on.
—I did not know that.

—Anyway, enough of this love talk. The House needs to know that the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), as usual, has got things wrong. The opposition is suggesting here not that we are against the quantum of hours that the government wants to run this chamber for; we are just suggesting a different set of hours. We are about the same quantum. I know that the member for O'Connor has difficulty comprehending things that are not in pictures, but perhaps if he has a look at the amendment of the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) he will gather what I am putting.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess in a lot of ways we owe the Liberal Party a favour in not making the member for O'Connor the Speaker of this House because we would not get these sorts of inflammatory speeches from him otherwise—although I guess if he had become the Speaker he might have started making them from the chair and would have broken a bit of new ground there. The spread of hours of the House probably does not matter all that much to the member for O'Connor. The member for O'Connor I do not think would mind if we sat here till midnight because he, among all members, has the simple expedient for getting around whenever the House sits: he just gets himself thrown out at question time whenever he has a pressing engagement. Whether it is to go to the races or whatever, the member for O'Connor can always find a way to get out. Maybe, to accommodate him, we should have put an amendment in that would provide for the adjournment debate to be at half past one—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tuckey amendment.

—And that could have been the Tuckey amendment. But our proposals to amend the proposition put forward by the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) to amend standing orders 40, 48A and 103 should be considered by all members of the House. I would hope that the government might see that what we are suggesting here is not a method to frustrate them; we are suggesting something which would be suitable to all their members as well as ours.

SPEECH.PARA: We accept, as the Manager of Opposition Business has said, that we have had a view on some parts of a number of the matters in this notice of motion, and the present government have had a different view. All of them have been canvassed throughout the House and during election campaigns—and you have had a view and we have had a view. You are now taking the political position you have had, and that is fair enough. We do not object to that. You won the election; you get to do what you want to do.

But the point is that you cannot have it both ways. You cannot have your leader stand up here, as he did yesterday, and you cannot stand up here in this debate and say that you want to do things differently now—`We're going to have a quieter, more pleasant, more friendly House of Representatives'—without coming in and discussing any of these things with the opposition. You cannot say that you want to dramatically change the rules as to when this House sits without talking to anyone about it because—

TALK.START.PARA: —You've changed your attitudes, have you?

—Hang on, we have the echo from the back over there. Mr Deputy Speaker, the fact of the matter is that the issue that the Procedure Committee's reports have brought down which has been the most widely discussed in this House over the years has been the times of sitting. The one thing that there was widespread agreement about was that 11 o'clock was just too late. There were agreements and disagreements about what the earlier time ought to be. But the one thing there was unanimity on was that 11 o'clock was just too late.

SPEECH.PARA: The unfortunate thing was that the Senate stole a march on us and changed its sitting hours to finish at 8 o'clock. The House of Representatives followed suit. If the government arranges to pass today's motion, and if the Senate does not change its mind, what will we be doing then? We will have had all the pain and there will be no gain. I do not think the Senate will change its hours at all. As a result, the Senate will be getting up at 8 o'clock and we will still be here at 11 o'clock.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Why is the Chief Opposition Whip speaking at the dispatch box? My understanding is that that privilege is not accorded to him. He should be speaking from his place.

—Thank you for your point of order. The reason is that the member for Watson is the Deputy Manager of Opposition Business and has secured the approval of the Speaker to speak at the dispatch box when speaking in that capacity. He will not be speaking at the dispatch box when he is speaking on other matters.

—I am getting worried, Mr Deputy Speaker: I am tending to agree with you on everything. The point is that the Senate is unlikely to change its sitting hours. We will have the position where the Senate will sit till 8 o'clock and we will sit till 11 o'clock. That is just ludicrous. When we go back and look at what people have said about the changes—
—Are you going to speak on this, Trish?

—The Manager of Opposition Business has just asked the member for Adelaide whether she is going to speak in the debate. She has been raised to the very powerful and important position in the House of one of the government whips. I congratulate her on that.
—She's been gagged.
—The manager tells me that she seems to have been gagged. We will be interested in hearing what the government whip has to say.
—We are very interested in what she has to say.

—In that case we are very interested in hearing what she has to say. We would like her to join in this debate. I will remind the member for Adelaide, who is the government whip—and the member for Mackellar might know that if she reads the press release—of what she said in the debate in this House on 21 December 1993. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: We need to consider our health—
Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, it was a while ago, and it was when the big debate on the hours took place. If she has changed her mind she can tell us about that in a few moments. She said then:

SPEECH.PARA: We need to consider our health—not only that of members and senators but also that of our staff and those who run this place. Our working hours and conditions simply would not pass the test of any sensible occupational health and safety guidelines.
She went on to say:
As commentator for the Australian Frank Devine wrote:

. . . many Members resist the abolition of marathon sittings out of sheer machismo. `Ordinary people may be prone to fatigue but watch me mate, I can go on forever'. They like to think their stamina gives them an advantage over rivals but the probability is that it gives them only the capacity to stay on their feet while virtually brain dead.
I think the member for Adelaide was right. It is a terrible criticism of the Leader of the House, but I think she is right. She went on to say:
British psychiatrist Hugh Freeman writes in The Human Brain and Political Behaviour—
and that is something that one would never say about the Leader of the House; the human brain and political behaviour never entered into his arrangements. This fellow said:
. . . fatigued decision‐makers tend to become irritable and impatient when any doubts are raised about their proposals so that their subordinates find it prudent to keep silent.
I hope you are not standing over the government whip and stopping her from speaking on this. She went on to say:
He says that weary decision makers `make major decisions when they are not thinking clearly'. Perhaps there is a clear message in this for the Prime Minister.
She meant the previous Prime Minister, but I think her words are very apt at present. Perhaps there is a message in this for the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, even though you and I have come to a great friendship here in the last fifteen minutes I think I probably need to remind you of what you said at that time. In the debate on 28 October 1993, when we were talking about members' health and the incidence of marital breakdown, you said:

If that is true, I can understand why that has happened; it is because of the stupid lifestyle we have. The second is the incidence of heart attack. I totally support the proposition that we should reform the procedures of this House. I am particularly very enthusiastic about the idea of getting the House up at 8 o'clock, certainly on three out of the four nights a week, if not the four nights.

As I said earlier, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are always correct in the things that you have said. The member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) was a member of the Procedure Committee that brought in the original report. As the member for Moncrieff will no doubt say in the debate, there was a fair bit of disagreement about what should happen at the edges of these hours arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a minority report.
—There was indeed a minority report. I thank the member for Moncrieff for reminding me of that. I remind her of what she said about that:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important if we reform the sitting hours that there be a consensus—
Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the House might listen to this. The member for Moncrieff said—
—Coming from you, mate!
—You should listen to what your distinguished colleague said. She said:

BREAK.PARA: It is important if we reform the sitting hours that there be a consensus and that both opposition and government needs be met, otherwise we get the worst of all worlds.
That is what the member for Moncrieff said. She said that we should have consensus on these things. Perhaps the Leader of the House might take up what she said.

Her colleague and partner in crime at that time was my dear friend the member for Moore (Mr Filing). The member for Moore was the Leader of the House's other nominee on this committee. In relation to the minority report, the member for Moore said on 28 October:

The honourable member for Moncrieff and I as authors of the dissenting report have little difference with the majority on the question of sitting hours. We were pleased to see that after some criticism of the original timetable circulated the committee has accepted the view of members of the coalition that Monday and Tuesday mornings had to be kept free for the shadow ministry and party meetings respectively.
So, in the end, the member for Moncrieff and the member for Moore came around to the view of the range of people on the committee.

The opposition is putting to the government a proposal which will allow them the same quantum of hours but at a more livable time. The government made a lot of points during the election campaign about being in favour of families and about being in favour of a more friendly style. How can this place operate effectively if members who have brought their families to Canberra have to be locked up here until 11 o'clock at night? It seems like the government have this really bizarre attitude that they are going to turn this place into a big boarding school and that members could not be let out at 8 o'clock at night because that might lead to dancing or something. We think the government ought to consider the opposition's point of view on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the alternative?

—The honourable member asks what the alternative is. Maybe he can tell us what he thinks the alternative is. The opposition is also saying to the government that they should consider the costs of their motion. They are out there sacking public servants, but for a bit of ideology they want to add 4½ extra hours to the sitting times and gain only 1½ hours of debate. That will cost a lot of money.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You reckon it won't cost you any money. In the Department of the House of Representatives alone approximately 50 people will have to work longer hours. That will cost the department about $50,000. In other parliamentary departments there will be the same sort of thing.
—Have a look at your travel allowance.

—If you have a look at my travel allowance, sport, you will find that I did not do too much. So you have picked the wrong target. If the government looks at the other departments, they will find that this will cost them hundreds of thousands of dollars. The families of the staff members who work here are going to be put at further risk. It is all right for us as members of parliament to say, `We'll sit here till 11 o'clock and won't we have been pretty good.' If we sit until 11 o'clock, about 100 people will not get out of this place until after midnight. The car drivers will be sitting outside the building clocking up double time and triple time because they will not have got their 10‐hour break, and their family lives will be put at risk as well. All this just so the Leader of the House can get another hour and a half of debate!

BREAK.PARA: Mr Somlyay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What the opposition is saying to the government is that we are quite willing to facilitate that extra hour and a half debate. If they want that, we will facilitate it for them. I would have thought that the member who interjected earlier would think a person's health is something to be commended. We were all very unhappy to see that you got ill, but you do not seem to worry about other people's health being putting at risk, as your colleague Senator Herron has said. I commend the amendment to the House.
—Order! I think the reflection on the member for Fairfax was a little out of order, and I caution you against that.
—I am happy to withdraw if the member thinks I reflected on him.
—I do not know what he thought, but I thought it was a little on the personal side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan, Kathryn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I want to congratulate you on your well justified elevation to the position of Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives. I also congratulate the member for Casey (Mr Halverson) on his election as Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) made some reference to the fact that I was a member of the Procedure Committee when it brought in the report About time. In fact, I was the deputy chair of that committee. I note that some other members of the committee are in the chamber today but not the chairman, who became the High Commissioner to London after the report was tabled.

I have a number of things to say, and I do not intend to respond in any great length to the comments of the member for Watson except to say this. In 1979, when I was in a previous political incarnation in another chamber, I chaired a government members' committee that looked at sitting hours. After extensive consultation with staff, members of the opposition and everybody else, we brought in a report which was thrown out by the government of the day. In 1981 that committee was revived following the premature death of Senator John Knight at the age of 38. The committee brought down another report which was again rejected by the government of the day but which led to some amended hours in the Senate following a free vote in the Senate.

Through all that procedure various people said to me, `Look, we really have gone down this path endless times before.' Former Senator Fred Chaney's father had also apparently tried to do something about the sitting hours when he was a member in the 1950s. There are a lot of new members in the chamber today, and I say to them that they will have this debate in the parliament a lot of times in their political incarnations and they will all get a go at it. The member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) will get another go at some time in the future, as I hope I will.

TALK.START.PARA: —We want it now. It's good now.

—It is good now and we will spend a couple of minutes debating it, but the motion the government has moved does far more profound things than changing the sitting hours. The government's motion goes to the heart of the operation of this chamber and indeed of parliamentary democracy. So I am not going to spend all my time commenting on sitting hours, as the honourable member for Watson did, except to say this. The member for Moore (Mr Filing) and I put forward a dissenting report to the report About time which included sitting hours. We put forward a different set of hours, and that was rejected by government and opposition alike. I have to say that there was not any consensus. I recall that there was a certain amount of ramming down necks, as the member for Moore will bear out. In fact, there was not much interest at all in consensus when discussing the dividing issue of sitting hours. I hope in future whenever the subject is debated again—and I am sure it will not be this year—that we might again canvass some of those options.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of this debate is far more important things. It is the matter of the parliamentary roster. I pay tribute to the member for Hotham (Mr Crean). I am pleased to see that he is the Manager of Opposition Business. I paid him this tribute before when he was a minister in the previous government: he was the only minister who, when conducting his own business in this chamber, took pains to meet the political and parliamentary niceties. It is a welcome change that we will have someone who acknowledges the importance of parliament running affairs for the Labor Party in this parliament. I am sure he is more than a little embarrassed by some of the things that he had to do and say today, but I hope that is an indication that over time government and opposition in this chamber will move forward to a better parliamentary procedure. The motion that the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) has put down today is a first step in that process.

The first point is the matter of the question time roster. Many were the times when we were sitting on the other side of the House that the then Leader of the House, now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), got up and was wont to use as defence on things like the debacle of the question time roster we had: `Oh, but reforms were recommended in the Procedure Committee report.' In fact, only a minority of the reforms that were recommended in that report were implemented by the then government and we had bastardised versions of other recommendations.

For the record, and for the interest particularly of new members, the then opposition, by consensus with the government on that occasion, did agree to a trial of a limited roster in question time. It was that on Mondays—and Mondays only—there would be a limited roster, on the understanding that if the opposition wanted to question a minister who was not on the roster it had the right to veto that minister's absence. So the opposition had the right to call for a minister who was rostered off—only on that Monday—to be in here to answer questions. That is all the roster was. We agreed under some pressure but wanting, maybe, to be reasonable, to free up question time a little, so that on the Monday of sitting weeks some ministers could be absent by agreement.

However, there had to be consultation between government and opposition. The Leader of the House now, who was then the Manager of Opposition Business, is well aware of the fact—and would agree with me—that every now and then the then government used to come out with a new roster—never mind only for Mondays, but for the whole week. There was never any consultation by the government. It was a case of: `We'll fax it through to your office.' The Leader of the House agrees. That is as much consultation as there was. It was faxed to everybody else at exactly the same time and it was, simply, `like it or lump it'. There was no consultation. There was no to or fro between government and opposition. It was just: `cop it sweet'. That was the record of the Labor government here.

The Howard government has now decided to scrap the roster because it was a mess, it was a debacle, it was an insult to the people of Australia. Question time is a critical time for government and opposition members to question the executive government. It is not the members who are important in this; it is the people on whose behalf they do the questioning, the people they represent—the people of Australia. Question time is a critical time in the operation of our whole parliamentary democracy. It is not for the benefit of opposition members or of government members but for the benefit of the people of Australia.

I will make a quick reference to the previous 3 o'clock timing of question time versus the 2.30 timing which was recommended by the Procedure Committee and the 2 o'clock timing being proposed today. The 2.30 timing was an attempt at consensus and consideration. At the time that it appeared to be emerging that the committee was going to come to a 2.30 recommendation—and somehow these things had a way of appearing in print in the newspaper; we never did quite identify who was responsible for all those leaks, although I think if you read the debate you would have a fair idea who most of us thought it was. The ABC communicated with the committee and pointed out that if we had a 2.30 start to question time, and if we went the normal 45 minutes that the House then had for question time, we would be overlapping its children's program and that this had serious programming implications for it.

I do not watch the ABC at 3 o'clock in the afternoon ever, whether parliament is sitting or not. It is a time when I am at work so I was not aware, as I am sure nearly all of the other members of the committee were not aware, of the ABC television programming imperatives at 3 o'clock. So we proceeded to a 2.30 recommendation in the knowledge that that would mean the truncation of the broadcasting of the House of Representatives, although we always hoped that the ABC might be prepared to shift a few minutes for us. In the event, when we started on that procedure—
Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly what I am talking about. I point out to the member for Prospect that she was quite happy to sit there while members of the opposition raised the issue which I am rebutting, without feeling the need to raise the matter of relevance with the then occupant of the chair.

SPEECH.PARA: So we had embarked on that procedure in ignorance of the ABC situation. The Keating government, in its party room, jettisoned the committee's recommendation of 2.30 and went for 3 o'clock, which it knew the ABC absolutely would not accept. It knew that there would be absolutely no room for manoeuvre and for broadcasting the House of Representatives question time, which prior to that time had been broadcast on alternate days with the Senate. So we had the situation where the Senate was then broadcast every day and we were broadcast at midnight, or 1 o'clock in the morning or something like that, apart from the little colour pieces that used to appear on the evening television news.

So in moving back to 2 o'clock, the government has made a decision. The 2.30 time was proposed by the Procedure Committee out of consideration for ministers and ministers' commitments, to make it a little easier for them to attend question time than 2 o'clock did. This government has taken the one decision it is perfectly entitled to decide to take, that is, that ministers are going to have to be here at 2 o'clock. It is not asking for any leeway for its ministers. I do not see how anybody could possibly object if the government has decided to inflict on itself something that the Procedure Committee would have been a little kinder to it about.

I also welcome the change in the second reading speech situation. For the benefit of members who were not here, there was a time, when it was moved that a bill be read a second time, that the minister would then give the second reading speech, that is, the speech to the parliament and to the public about the content of a bill that is being presented for debate together with its rationale. The debate would then be adjourned after the second reading speech, the procedure for many years. What the Keating government did was knock out the minister's second reading speech at that time.

Under Labor, we did not get the minister's second reading speech until the bill was going into its full-scale debate, which meant that shadow ministers and members participating in the debate did not have access to that speech, to that explanation or to the political rationalisation, did not have the minister's words to echo or rebut, whatever the case might be. I know that there were some ministers who, when approached by the shadow minister, would make the second reading speech available in advance of the debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Always.

—Not always. The member for Prospect can speak only for herself. That is absolutely not right. You were a parliamentary secretary and I was a shadow parliamentary secretary. I know the difficulty we had in getting out of the office of the minister for health a second reading speech on any health bill. I know because in those days I had to speak on health bills on behalf of the opposition. You could not get it, except maybe half an hour beforehand if you were lucky. There was many a shadow minister who could say the same.

SPEECH.PARA: We shall return to the opposition the courtesy and the advantage of knowing the content of the second reading speech. It is not a case of returning it to the opposition but, rather, returning it to the people of Australia. When a law is proposed in this parliament members are entitled to know the rationale and real implications of that law so that they are able to debate it in a way that their constituents are entitled to expect they would. I welcome that change. That was also a recommendation of the Procedure Committee which was not taken up by the previous government.

Finally, because time is limited, I want to say a few words about the grievance debate. A quite incorrect assertion was made by the opposition when that was mentioned earlier today. I welcome the fact that we will have a guaranteed minimum time for the grievance debate. In theory we had that under the arrangements that the previous government put in place, but it did not happen. There was a theoretical time for question time but it habitually went over time. This was not to the advantage of members asking questions. It was due to the fact that we used to get six‐ to 10‐minute government diatribes—they were not answers to questions. We had record low numbers of questions despite a record length of time for question time. On Mondays it was the grievance debate that was truncated by the extended answers to questions by then government ministers. That was what happened to the grievance debate.

The Procedure Committee addressed this when it revisited the earlier changes and it recommended a guaranteed minimum time for the grievance debate. If you go back to that report that revisits the About time changes you will find that the truncation of time for the grievance debate was specifically addressed. It became a specific subsequent recommendation of the Procedure Committee that the grievance debate ought to have a guaranteed time. I particularly welcome that review and that aspect of the motion moved by the Leader of the House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I formally congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, on your election to this very important position in this parliament. I think this particular debate is timely and relevant. I want to congratulate the government for taking some of the initiatives it has in respect of the matters that have been brought before us today. I also want to take up the challenge which was issued by my good friend the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that if there is a good idea then people should be prepared to listen to it. I would like to make a couple of suggestions in respect of how additional improvements could be made in terms of the work ability of this place which the government may wish to consider.

PARA.BREAK: Much has been said about sitting times. Much has been said about occupational health and safety issues. I am pleased that the views of both sides of the House about occupational health and safety have been quoted in this place. There is no doubt that they are con siderations that we need to put in place and into perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: When talking about extending sitting hours, it is not simply a question of what is best for the 148 members of the House of Representatives. What we are talking about is the effect that would have on the people who work within this building and service the needs of the 148 members of the House of Representatives. As many people are probably aware, the fact that people associated with the Department of the House of Representatives put together information for us about the day's proceedings and tidy up what actually happened during the course of the day means that, at 11 o'clock at night when the bells ring and members can go home or wherever else they might want to go, many of those people will have to remain here. They will be expected to be here at 7.30 or 8 o'clock the next morning to get prepared for the ensuing day. I think those sorts of issues are worthy of consideration.

The Leader of the House (Mr Reith) states in the last section of the motion before us today that the Standing Committee on Procedure should actually review any further changes to the times of sitting of the House and report back. I hope that might embrace this specific matter about the occupants of this building and the effect changes to sitting times might have on them. He might also consult with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this because I know the Prime Minister is health conscious. I know that he is concerned about his level of physical fitness, as we all should be.

I think we have to extend that argument to include the people who work directly for us in our offices and the other occupants of this building. This does not just affect the clerks and their staff but also affects Hansard, the people in the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff more generally and a whole range of people. I think these issues are worthy of further consideration.

I want to very briefly say something about the 2 o'clock kick‐off for question time. I frankly think that is a change for the better. One of the things that has always been of great concern to me in this place is that we have become very much a disseminator of entertainment and not so much a disseminator of information. If a wider audience tunes in—the half a dozen people that like to watch question time at 2 o'clock in the afternoon on the ABC—they will start to actually see what happens in one segment of the day, not the whole of the parliamentary day. Look at us now. There are a range of people in here who hold a range views. The question time frenzy and activity is not evident here. That is always the case, save for the one hour of question time.

But information dissemination through live television coverage is very important. At the risk of offending standing order 82 on anticipation of debate, in respect of the proposition by the Leader of the House on broadcasting what can go out, I quote the former leader on this side of the place: `You've got it dead right.' So I congratulate you for that particular change.

I would also make a couple of suggestions to the Leader of the House which you have not picked up here, because I do not think that some of these changes you are suggesting go far enough. They certainly do not address the sorts of issues that used to ring around my ears in question time, particularly the relevancy of answers given by ministers or indeed the length of answers.

My colleague the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) mentioned in passing the length of answers which ministers gave. Can I suggest to all newer members in this place that, if they have not already, they get hold of the standing orders and they read standing order 144 relevant to questions and 145 relevant to answers. You will see an amazing difference. The subtlety even escapes people in the media in this place, because 144 lists very carefully rules applying to questions. Taking it further and getting the House of Representatives Practice and looking at the way Speakers have interpreted this, you will see very tight rules on questions.

But when it comes to answers, and again the point made by the member for Moncrieff on whether it be relevancy or length, the standing orders are silent, save for 145, which says answers must be relevant to a question. Then it is up to the incumbent in the chair to determine whether an answer has been relevant or not.

Time and time again in my incumbency in that position, members of the opposition would rise in their places, stride manfully—or womanfully—to the dispatch box, often because they were frontbenchers, and say, `Mr Speaker, a point of order. I draw your attention to the length of answers of this minister,' or `I draw your attention to the relevance of what the minister is saying.' Time and time again the occupant of the Speaker's chair had his or her hands tied because of the procedures dictated by this place.

I say to the Leader of the House, because he was one that frequently took up those concerns with me when I was Speaker, it is time that we addressed that very seriously. The Procedure Committee in the past made recommendations about this. The Senate have actually acted on it—there is one minute for a question and, I think, four minutes for an answer. It is time that we looked at ourselves and asked whether a time limit is required in that respect. Or will we see, as part of the new approach in this place to government, those ministers on the front bench, when asked a series of very serious, far‐reaching and searching questions by opposition, give relevant and short responses? Only time will tell. But it may well be that this is an issue we will revisit. It may well be, and it may not be too far down the track, that people on this side of the parliament will rise to seek the call from the Speaker to raise the issue of relevancy and the length of answers of ministers, just as they always have done. If we are to get this place to work a little more effectively, particularly at that time and especially now with the change to 2 o'clock when we will see a live broadcast of our question time, at least two days a week I would imagine, then maybe we need to clean up that part of our act as well.

PARA.BREAK: I might just say to the member for Moncrieff in response to her contribution on the 2.30 or 2 o'clock or 3 o'clock start to question time, that 3 o'clock actually is when Sesame Street is on the ABC. In negotiations which were held when the government decid ed to change question time from 2 o'clock to 3 o'clock, it was true that the ABC said they would not under any circumstances interrupt children's programming to put on the House of Representatives. So it had to be on for all the insomniacs at 1 a.m. the next day. Whether it goes to the question of one children's program upsetting another and competing needs, I am not sure. But, seriously, those are the sorts of things that we must keep in mind, too, when we talk about information rather than entertainment coming out of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue which I should mention where I said I did have a couple of suggestions—and I hope the Leader of the House is listening to this—is the fact that the second chamber may be put to better use. When this particular facility was put in place, the idea was that by establishing virtually a duplicate of the House of Representatives we might see non‐contentious legislation, committee reports and others go there for consideration. I suggest to you, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that maybe that is something that can be revisited. Maybe a lot more material from the House could be referred to the second chamber, to the Main Committee, for consideration. In that way not only would we increase the time in which that particular body sits, but the amount of material, legislation, debates and other things that members are so concerned about might not be enacted through this place. If we are serious about giving ourselves time for debate, for serious issues to be considered here, then there is nothing wrong with that happening in the Main Committee. I just suggest to the Leader of the House that that might be something that he needs to look at. It may require some changes to the way in which that particular second chamber was established. I am not quite sure whether it would need changes to the standing orders, but perhaps it may.

Let me conclude by again saying to the Leader of the House that I think it is important for us to look at sitting times very carefully in terms of occupational health and safety issues. Many arguments have been mounted in this place. I understand the Leader of the House's desire and need to have more business go through this place, but my suggestion to you is that it might better suit our purposes if the Main Committee was put to further use. The beneficiary from this arrangement to extend sittings in this place on Monday and Tuesday nights can only be the Hyatt, with the fixed meal time being put in place. There is no question about that at all and good luck to them.

However, we do need to consider the occupational health and safety issues carefully. I suggest to you, Leader of the House, that you act on your convictions and act on what you always put to me when the roles were somewhat reversed in the last parliament. You should look at standing order 145 and see whether you are prepared to recommend some changes to the standing orders so that definitions of things such as the relevance of answers and length of answers are picked up. You should make some genuine suggestions as to how question time may improve even more. I understand that you have a genuine desire to do so, and I can only applaud that.

With television coverage now being broadcast live, more people will watch it. It will and should be about information; it should not be about theatrics or entertainment. I have no doubt there will be some theatrics and entertainment, and there is always a place for some of that. But at the end of the day, if we are serious about changing the way this place operates, I would hope that some of those suggestions gain favour from the government and are given serious consideration. The other proposals—such as changing standing order 150 to make ministerial replies 60 days—are excellent. I heartily concur with the other changes that you have proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to follow the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) in this debate. I think his contribution was meritorious and I agree with many of the issues he raised, particularly those associated with the standing orders surrounding question time. It is interesting to note his observations as he views question time from a different perspective, now that he no longer occupies the chair.

SPEECH.PARA: May I take this opportunity, as an aside, to compliment the member for Cunningham on his role as Speaker of this House. He was an adornment to the office. I know on occasions that we on this side were critical of some of his decisions, but he demonstrated a kindly authority in the chair that was appreciated by members. Frankly, I think there was a reasonable degree of order in the House on most occasions when the former Prime Minister was not present, and the departure from this House of the not lamented former Prime Minister does give us a new opportunity to raise the standards of parliamentary debate and, hopefully, the way the public sees this House function.

In the context of making asides, may I also congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, on your return to the Speaker's chair, if in a somewhat slightly different position, but obviously as elevated as possible from somebody in opposition. I also congratulate Speaker Halverson and the others who will fill that chair in this new parliament. You have a very important role as Speaker and Deputy Speakers to exercise your authority in this place and ensure that the tone of the chamber reflects the fact that this is a place of business and that a workmanlike attitude needs to be demonstrated.

But that responsibility is not entirely yours. All members of this chamber have a responsibility to ensure that our 38th parliament is better than the previous one and that it functions in a way which will restore the public's confidence in the way in which our democratic process works. Sad as I am to say this, the fact is that the Australian people have been losing confidence in our federal parliamentary system because of their perception that parliamentarians have been out of touch with the feelings of ordinary Australians and have not behaved in the way they should have.

That impression has been largely gained by the short news clips of question time shown on television. These were sadly often rowdy and showed that the debate seemed to be out of control and irrelevant. That is sad for members of parliament and detrimental to the standing that we have in our own communities but, more importantly, it is a threat to our very democracy.

BREAK.PARA: If people lose confidence in our parliamentary system, the very future of our democracy is at risk. This place is supposed to be at the centre of our democratic system and, if people do not have confidence in the way we operate, they question the very reason for having a democracy and the way in which our representative system works. We need to be seen as hardworking, industrious, fair, responsible and efficient. Every member has a role to ensure that those standards are maintained.

Of course, parliamentarians are human beings so we make mistakes like others. Inevitably, some will perform better than others, but members need to always appreciate that they have to behave responsibly because their irresponsibility may damage not only themselves but the very institution of parliament.

The media also has a responsibility to more fairly represent what happens in this parliament. The brief television news clips do this parliament a disservice. They pick out a few rowdy seconds and ignore the hours of detailed debate and careful consideration of the issues of the day which may have occurred.

As I said before, the departure of the former Prime Minister will help in this regard. There are still plenty of vigorous debaters in this chamber. The current Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) have reputations—justly earned—for being outstanding contributors to this parliament but, fortunately, they do not regularly resort to the personal attacks, insults and bad language which characterised the former Prime Minister's performance. We must all make sure that we do not resort to silly name calling and making those idiotic comments that were sometimes made. By behaving better, we will be able to restore the public's confidence in this place.

The proposed changes to the standing orders that are before the House at the present time make a substantial contribution towards improving the way in which this parliament functions. I particularly welcome the Prime Minister's assurance that all ministers will be present for question time. It really was demeaning for the former government when the television cameras panned across the ministerial benches during question time and showed that they were half empty.

I am gratified to notice that members of the opposition are not opposing this change but, unfortunately, they have not given a commitment that if they were ever to be returned to government they would not resort to their previous bad habits. Are we going to have rostered days off for the shadow ministers? Are we going to have only half the shadow ministers turning up in spite of the fact that all the ministers are going to be present? I commend Prime Minister Howard on taking this initiative and restoring the accountability of the ministry to the parliament by ensuring that all ministers are present.

It is very difficult for an opposition to mount a concerted attack on a minister who may be deficient in his or her administration if that minister does not turn up every second day. You could have a minister almost ready to fall on his or her sword, and then he or she goes away for a holiday. The momentum is lost by the next occasion. We on this side of the House are confident in our ministers' capacity to perform. They do not need to hide behind a bush every second day. They will be here to answer questions.

It is also particularly important that the second reading speech be provided at the time a measure is being introduced into parliament so there is adequate time to fairly consider what is intended by the legislation. That will also contribute to the quality of the debate when matters are before the House.

I also want to mention the importance of the role ministers can play in raising the standards of the House. It is important, as the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) said, that ministers be present when their legislation is debated in the chamber so that they are able to respond to important issues raised by opposition and, indeed, government members.

PARA.BREAK: Worthwhile suggestions often come from the other side and need to be incorporated in legislation. What has been happening in the parliament over the last six or so years is that this House has been used as a rubber stamp and the real, detailed consideration of legisla tion occurs in the other place. That has lowered the significance of debate in this chamber, but that will be restored if ministers are here, are prepared to take on board suggestions which are made during the debate on legislation and are prepared to make amendments where necessary in this place, rather than having the humiliation of having to accept amendments that are initiated in the Senate and then need to be reintroduced in this place.

BREAK.PARA: I hope also that ministers will be more involved in the second chamber. I was interested in the comments by the member for Cunningham on the second chamber. If we are to make that second chamber a really meaningful part of the debating processes of the parliament, ministers need to attend there as well or, if it is a debate on a committee report, the committee chair should attend so that place has the dignity and aura associated with the debate of a federal parliament.

I also note with interest that a ministerial statement is scheduled for today. I hope that is an indication that in future government policy announcements will be made in this place rather than by press release, at the National Press Club or at other places. I note the criticism that this matter we are dealing with now came on the Notice Paper only this morning, but this is the first working day of sittings. It would have been impossible to put it on the Notice Paper earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there are other ways to tell us.
—You were told earlier. You were told way back in March that it was our intention to do this.
—What about talking to people?
—There was only a press release available to us. Were you suggesting that we call the parliament back during the election so we could put it on the Notice Paper ?
—Order! The honourable member for Hotham will cease interjecting and the honourable member for Wide Bay will address his remarks through the chair and ignore interjections.

—I am delighted that changes that will significantly improve the conduct of this House are being proposed to the standing orders. The honourable member for Cunningham has made some very worthwhile suggestions in relation to the conduct of question time and I hope they can also be addressed. These things come up every couple of weeks in question time. They are deferred and there is no further action.

BREAK.PARA: I was on the Procedure Committee in the parliament before last and we presented at least ten committee reports. Very few, if any, were acted on by the government of the day. One of the first was in relation to the opening day procedures. After every opening day the word goes around, `Why on earth are we doing all this walking around the place?' Everyone knows how to fix it, but we never get around to doing it. It is not considered to be a high priority so when the next opening of parliament comes along, lo and behold, no change has been made to the standing orders so we go through all this unnecessary walking to and fro again.

I hope these sorts of issues will be addressed by the incoming government. It has demonstrated great good faith in the initiatives announced today that will be implemented as a result of these motions. More work still needs to be done and I am confident that the incoming government will address these issues one by one and, as a result, we will have a better parliament and the people of Australia will have more confidence in the way we are working.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in remarks earlier about the problem of Sesame Street preventing question time at the new time of 3 p.m.—a time that was set in the last parliament—being broadcast. Remembering the state of the previous government and often the inability of ministers to answer questions, one could argue that the choice of question time or Sesame Street was the choice between two puppet shows.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also no doubt that those changes, the so‐called concessions to the Procedure Committee report, were made only to benefit the government. It was able to restrict the opportunity of members, particularly at question time, to represent their constituents properly and get answers from ministers about the administration of portfolios and the spending of people's tax money.

Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I congratulate you on your election to your illustrious position. May I make the point which was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) yesterday that there is clearly a great expectation with the election of this new government, a government committed to improving the standards in this chamber—standards of behaviour; standards of debate; standards of processes; and, in the case of ministerial responsibility, standards of ministerial accountability to the chamber—that, as a consequence, what is happening today and what will happen in the next few days and weeks of the parliamentary session will be of great interest to the community. They will be watching us and saying, `Are we really going to get some changes or aren't we?'

In looking at the government's proposed changes to the standing orders, I am very much encouraged in certain of the aspects. In particular, I am encouraged by the changes relating to question time, which is certainly a critical part of our working day. It is the part of the day which most people outside of the parliament get to see as far as media attention is concerned. It is the point at which the House of Representatives effectively works, or can or should work, because it is a time when members can direct questions straight to a minister about important matters relating to the administration of their portfolios.

I wish to make a couple of comments in response to comments made earlier by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) in relation to earlier debates about the changes which were made in the last parliament, particularly to sitting hours. I was one of the authors of the minority report, as the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) mentioned, that was published alongside the report of the Procedure Committee. We had some concerns about the way in which the sitting hours were being changed.

There were certainly some strong concerns about the length of sitting hours. I recollect that Senator Herron, a very compelling person, a person of great standing in the medical community as well as now a minister of the Crown, had some very strong concerns about the health effects of sitting late. However, I am prepared, as I suppose a measure of trying to ensure this place works more effectively, to compromise. And it is a compromise: on Mondays and Tuesdays we will sit to 11 o'clock and the Wednesday and Thursday sittings times are being retained.

That is something that I, as a member of this chamber, am prepared to accept. I certainly do not have any problems with the consultation process at this stage. There was certainly a fair bit of debate in the community about the changes that were necessary to make this chamber work more effectively. But if the Procedure Committee is to have an effective role—I particularly direct my remarks via you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the Leader of the House (Mr Reith)—there has to be some acknowledgment by the government that all of the work of the Procedure Committee is not merely an exercise in futility. That certainly was the case in the previous government's term of office. It was certainly the case when I was a member of that committee.

The member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is sitting nearby, was a very good chairman of that committee. I was very impressed with his chairmanship of the committee. I do not want to put words in his mouth, but at times I felt that he, too, felt utterly frustrated at times when we wanted to make changes and the then Keating government refused to make them.

I am certainly keen to see the Procedure Committee become a very effective and integral part of our processes—so much so that I would like to see, for instance, one of the Independents have by right a position on that committee so that they are able to participate and ensure that the interests of independent members are also represented in relation to any changes.

Just as an aside in relation to sitting hours: I am conscious that no doubt the changes to sitting hours have a big impact on the catering arrangements here. I noticed yesterday's circular to members mentioned there have been some substantial savings. I know they are part of the government's cost‐cutting measures. I certainly hope these changes to sitting hours are not going to be called the Hyatt clauses. I imagine that it is important for a catering contractor to have members in the House at some stage in the evening so they will buy dinner in the dining rooms. I hope that is not the case. I suggest the changes are, as has been presented, designed to allow the government and of course the House of Representatives to operate more effectively.

Question time is absolutely critical, as I said earlier. The 3 p.m. starting time was wrong. The member for Moncrieff, the Deputy Speaker and I were critical of this. Interestingly, the 3 p.m. starting time effectively pushed the MPI off the scene as far as the media were concerned. In other words, there was no time between the MPI being staged and the electronic reporting of the day, particularly by television, for the MPI to be properly processed. So, if you were trying to launch an effective message in the MPI of the day, you could not count on any sort of television coverage whatsoever.

That obviously suited the previous government because the MPI is often a vehicle for the opposition to raise during the day matters of importance and of course of note in the day‐to‐day running of a country. It is the only opportunity in some instances. Having that forced into oblivion as far as the media was concerned meant that an effective platform for proper scrutiny of ministerial responsibility was lost. I commend the Leader of the House for reintroducing the start of question time at 2 p.m. I think that is a very good change, and the government is to be congratulated.

After skimming through the amendments proposed by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), the Manager of Opposition Business, I see the only differences are the sitting times. Am I right that there is no other difference whatsoever?

TALK.START.PARA: —Finishing times.

—Yes, the finishing times. They are the only effective differences. In considering the opposition amendments, one would purely and simply need to decide whether or not they want to sit late on Mondays and Tuesdays only.
—But still giving the same length.

—I understand. I listened with interest to the debate. I understand the rationale. I listened with interest to particularly the former Speaker's comments about the preparation time needed by House of Representatives staff for the next sitting day. I am prepared, as I said earlier, to enter into a compromise on this and support the government's amendments to the standing orders because I think there is an opportunity—

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Prospect, in her previous incarnation on the second bench of the government, would have been totally uncritical of any changes or any matters raised by the government. I am saying that I am prepared to compromise on this aspect. I think there is room for compromise. However, I will be looking at it, as I am sure a number of other members will be, to make sure that it is worth the effort—in other words, it does do something to make this place operate more effectively and does not result, as the member for Watson described, in people standing up brain dead in the chamber, which would be an unfortunate state of affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point relates to questions on notice. No doubt the new Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull), who is sitting at the table, would be very quick to respond to questions on notice, being a very efficient minister. I am also conscious of the fact that at times members will, as we used to do ad nauseam, leap up and ask the Speaker to write to ministers to ask them to respond to questions.

I think it is proposed that the time frame for providing answers be changed from 90 days to 60 days. I was one of the people who proposed in the first place to have this changed in the standing orders. I was sick to the back teeth of having to wait six months to get an answer from ministers, who had all these staff to do the job. Now we have ministers with fewer staff, and less pay in some instances, and the job will be done more quickly. That is a productivity increase. I am pleased to see that. We certainly hope we will get effective answers for our constituents' concerns more quickly—and, I might add, they will be real answers, not just prevarication, as has often been the case in the past.

The member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), as a parliamentary secretary, often took up causes. That leads me to my next point: the Main Committee. I was a critic of it in the first instance. I thought it would be just a second-rate chamber. But it has become an effective forum for members to raise their concerns—particularly in the very important take note debates, which have now become a very good medium. For those new members contemplating their participation in debates in the future, I suggest that they look for these take note debates. They are very useful ways of participating and getting your constituents' views across in the Main Committee.

The one failing of consistent nature the previous government had was the fact that they did not have a minister or often a parliamentary secretary in the Main Committee during the second reading debate on a bill. That is an important part of any debate. If you are going to raise matters on behalf of constituents, then quite clearly you want to have somebody who will actually do something about it there and then with you in the Main Committee so that they can hear what you have to say.

The member for Prospect, who is an adversary in political terms, did take up the cudgel a couple of times when I raised matters and I appreciated that. That is a good way of getting your constituents' concerns across and it is a valuable piece of time in our daily lives in the House of Representatives.

I hope the government will insist on having either the appropriate minister or parliamentary secretary in the Main Committee when the second reading debates are being held and not have—as was the case in the previous parliament—the Chairman of Committees, for instance, who might have had some sort of relevance in getting the bill through the chamber on behalf of the government. That is absolutely critical to the better interests of this chamber and I hope that will be something the government will take note of and make sure does not happen again. I am sure that if that is the case we will see the Main Committee become, as it already is, a more effective place in which members can raise matters of concern on behalf of their constituents.

One of the criticisms in recent times is that this chamber has become more and more dominated by the interests of the big parties. I was in a big party at one stage and now I am an Independent member. Through cooperation, and with the ability for members to properly represent constituents not only at question time and in debates but also in committee work and all the other things that provide us with those opportunities, we will hopefully see a more effective House of Representatives that will be seen by the rest of the community to be doing its job.

All of us will have our own standing in the community raised from the bottom of the list, as I saw the other day, or just above state members of parliament, to a higher standing—perhaps up towards medical practitioners. I note that one of the new members is a medical practitioner and has taken a drop in the public standing of about 20 points, according to the list that was published in the Bulletin recently. By making that chamber work more effectively we can raise our standing and indeed raise the reputation of the system to which we all subscribe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very conscious of the time and there are new members who want to make their maiden speeches. I understand that they have friends and relatives in the gallery, so I will restrict my comments to a maximum, I hope, of 10 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, though, a few matters that I want to get on the record in connection with these proposals. I appreciate the fact that at the start of a new parliament of this kind, when there has been quite a substantial change, there are time factors involved in the government getting legislation and motions into place. But I just want to put on record my concern, and it is a concern that should be shared particularly by new government members.

BREAK.PARA: Until yesterday we saw these proposals only by way of a press release dated 31 March. I hope this will not be a government by press release. It is not fair to the opposition and it is not fair to government members. In connection with that matter it is important to draw attention to the fact that, since they did appear in this way, quite clearly they were not matters that were considered by the government parties. They may have been, but it is most unlikely that they were. It is most unlikely that the government parties endorsed all of the proposals in this motion and those which are to follow.

As the former chairman of the Procedure Committee which brought down the report Time for review, I endorse most of the provisions that have been included in this motion. As members know, that report was a review of the initial report About time, which introduced those major changes.

I want to do two things in connection with those reports. Firstly, I want to draw attention to the fact that—as indicated by the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), the former very competent deputy chair of that committee—while she and the Independent member for Moore (Mr Filing) had a minority report in the About time report, their report, which also referred to sitting hours, did not in any way contest the time when the House would rise on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays. That time was to be 8 o'clock. That was proposed by the committee initially. It was also endorsed by the member for Moncrieff and the member for Moore in their dissenting report.

The following quote was a unanimous response from members of all parties who participated in the Procedure Committee. In the report which reviewed those proposals, paragraph 9.2.8 on page 33 states, `It is recommended that no change be made to the sitting hours of the House.' A lot of the proposals that the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) has brought forward on behalf of the government are of course proposals which were suggested in Time for review and which I endorse.

I do not endorse the sitting hours. I really believe those sitting hours are nonsensical. If it really is a matter of finding the additional 1½ hours, then members know that our alternative proposal is the sensible way to go about it. Could I say to new members that, after you have been here for a while and are sitting around this place until 11 o'clock at night, I do not know what you will say to your constituents when they ask you how you can give sensible consideration to legislation when you are sitting into the middle of the night. That is what you will be asked, and the Leader of the House knows it.

The point has also been made about the enormous additional cost that is going to be involved. If we look at these proposals, we will sit on the Monday until 11 o'clock at night instead of 8 o'clock and we will achieve an extra 1½ hours of debating time. But we will not make up any extra time on the second day, on the Tuesday. Although there will be an additional 4½ hours that we have to remain in this building, we will have only 1½ extra hours for debating time. That is not sensible. I make that point emphatically.

If it is not sensible, then you need to examine the real reasons why these changes have been introduced and why we are going to be required to stay in this building until 11 o'clock at night instead of getting out at 8 o'clock. I can only speculate about that, and I am sure you will as time proceeds—as you well should. Medical experts and members of the former parliament have indicated their concerns about those sitting hours and about members and staff being kept around here until 11 o'clock at night. It is nonsensical. They really should not have been introduced and I am disappointed that they have been. We can only speculate about the real reasons why they have been introduced.

I want to emphasise a few other points in the limited time that I am going to take. The member for Moncrieff referred to the sitting hours proposed in her dissenting report and that of the Independent member for Moore to the initial report Time for review. I have emphasised that there were no proposals for a change to the end of the sitting day in their dissenting report. In connection with the grievance debate, the member for Moncrieff referred to the fact, as the Leader of the House has indicated, that there will be a firm time of one hour 20 minutes placed in the standing orders for the grievance debate to give backbench members—private members of this chamber—the right to make a contribution. While that did not exist under the previous arrangement, I think on every occasion—I can be corrected—the then Leader of the House, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), moved that the time for the grievance debate be extended to ensure that all of that time was available.

We all accept the political rhetoric that is involved in debates of this kind and everyone, including the newer members, will become increasingly familiar with it and experienced in it. We are going to gain 1½ extra hours in debating time by adding 4½ hours to the time that we are required to be here, including finishing at 11 o'clock. We have suggested an alternative, and it really should be considered, where if the purpose of these changes is to get those 1½ extra hours you can do so by adding an extra half an hour on to the three days. Instead of getting up at 11 o'clock at night, we would get up at 8.30 p.m. You people were not consulted about this. I hope that in your party rooms you are going to have your say—and I hope you do in future—because it does not make sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Charlton will not, by example, show the new members bad examples, and you will refer your remarks through the chair.

—I always appreciate your wise advise, Mr Deputy Speaker. Could I at this stage congratulate you, the Speaker and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), the other Deputy Speaker, on your and their elevation.
—Flattery will not get you very far.
—It always has in the past, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I know. Let's be careful.

—All members will notice that, while the provision is that we sit until 11 o'clock on Monday and Tuesday night in order to provide a dinner break, we do not on Wednesday night. There is no dinner break on Wednesday night. We sit straight through until 8 o'clock. If a dinner break is not important on a Wednesday night, then why have one on Monday and Tuesday? That is not very consistent, yet people are saying, `You've got to compromise.' But this is not sensible compromise.

BREAK.PARA: If there is concern that during the dinner period when the House would still be sitting your dinner could be interrupted, look at the numbers. If the opposition calls for a division, it is going to be more symbolic than ever. We can give an assurance not to call quorums during that time, and I think we can probably also give an assurance to minimise divisions because we are not going to win any. In fact, I do not think we want to draw the attention of the national community to the fact that our numbers are so depleted. Why would we want to put them on the record?

TALK.START.PARA: —You're going to do in a minute or two.

—That is just a practice run. I believe that my contribution will be so compelling that this might well be the first occasion when we have members from the government benches joining us over here. We'll see what happens. If we need additional time, the Main Committee, the second chamber, can be used more fully. Yesterday, the Governor-General said:

BREAK.PARA: It is a regrettable fact that, for various reasons, increasing numbers in the community have lost respect for the Parliament and its members.
The government will take steps to restore that respect. It will do so without in any way reducing the scope for robust debate which is one of the most valued features of our democratic tradition.

Robust debate at 11 o'clock at night! `To restore the respect of the parliament.' There are people out there who say, `What are you people on about? You set your own hours and you sit there until midnight.' Yesterday the Governor-General issued those words on behalf of the government.

In conclusion, some young members, particularly, have said to me on previous occasions, `Look, if we've got to be in Canberra, let's sit late while we are there, so that we don't have to sit as many weeks and we can get back to our families.' That makes sense. The problem is that the sitting weeks have not been in any way reduced. This extra time is not going to make it possible for you to get back home to your families. You will be here for the same number of days, but when you are here you will sit until 11 o'clock at night.

I said we could speculate about the reasons for it. The reasons that have been given do not add up. They are not the real reasons. I think it is a nonsensical proposal. I think it is a foolish proposal. I am very disappointed that the proposal has been made because it does not accord with any of the consideration which has been given to these matters before. The additional time which will be available under the provisions that have been made, as opposed to our alternative proposal which would let us get away from this building at 8.30 p.m., will be zilch. I urge members of the government parties to give further consideration to these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I take part in this debate I would like to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, on your appointment to the chair. I know I will have the opportunity to congratulate both the Speaker and the Second Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: Regardless of what the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) said—and I will be very quick because I am mindful of the maiden speeches about to be made—some things must be made very plain, particularly for the Hansard record in the future. What we have been talking about for the last few hours is that we in the opposition support the proposals before the House but we have shown realistically how time can be better served by making, as previous speakers from our side of the House have stated, a slight amendment to the recommendations before us.

Mr Deputy Speaker, when you read the motion, it seemed to one and all a very quick fix solution. We are saying it is all very well if you want to provide a quick fix to some of your problems. But realistically, why not, with a little more consultation and a little more debate in the House, which is what has been occurring here today, look to the future and see what could be done in a way which will possibly still provide the same avenues and the same amount of time in which to have further debate and further discussion of business?

I certainly commend the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) for his suggestion about using the second chamber more fully. Certainly, that has not been the case in the past. Mr Deputy Speaker, I think you, too, would agree that it is an avenue available to all members of the parliament, particularly government members, to make sure that that second chamber is used so that there is a little more ability for members to come forward and take part in debates.

I was a little disturbed about one point. When the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) spoke, I did not mean to be offensive when I interjected. What I meant to say was that we do not need to sit here and listen to a trip down memory lane as to what has occurred since 1976. You are in government now. Let us look to the future. We in the opposition have said that some of the changes you are now making will be supported by us—and so we should support them. I refer to the 2 o'clock start for question time and the change regarding second reading speeches. I found it extraordinary that the member for Moncrieff said that she was never given a copy of a second reading speech by the then minister for health. I would like to question that further because I know that in my previous capacity, on behalf of my minister, we always made sure that the opposition spokesman was provided not only with the second reading speech but also with briefings by the department well before the actual debate took place in the House. So I find that extraordinary. They are matters that must also be corrected for the Hansard record.

One of the areas that I find quite extraordinary is something we heard from the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss)—in fact, almost ad nauseam. The member for Moore (Mr Filing) touched on it as well. I refer to the raising of standards. The Governor‐General, in speaking on behalf of the government yesterday, also mentioned it in his speech. I say to every member of parliament: you raise the standards from yourself first. Whether we sit later or whether we sit for shorter hours, whether we debate longer or whether we start question time at 2 o'clock, 3 o'clock or 9 o'clock, the standards come from the individual, first and foremost. This is something that was perpetually put out by the government when they were in opposition—that the standards of this House have gone down because of minister X, Y or Z or prime minister X, Y or Z. The standards of the House start with the individuals. Examine thy own first and then come forward with what standards, and standards in debate, should be.

When personal attacks come forward, who makes them? It is not the sitting times of the House that cause a personal attack; it is the person, the individual. I find it appalling that we should be tarnished with one brush. As the old cliche goes, you don't throw out the whole box of apples because one of them has gone rotten. Also, as the member for Wide Bay tried to say repeatedly, even the media may start reporting more fairly the actions and statements of the parliament. The sitting times, such as a 2 o'clock start for question time, will not instruct the media of this country on how they will report or not report. Those are the points we must look at in the future.

I think it is very foolish that we are going to sit on Mondays and Tuesdays at those particular times when we realise how many years it has taken us to introduce more sensible times for debate. I believe that with a little more consideration we would have had a more sensible program. As has been indicated by opposition members, we support 99.9 per cent of the procedural motion before the House with regard to the changing of the standing orders.

When we talk about consultation, it is regardless of whether we in opposition are going to be consulted. That is not the point with regard to sitting hours. I wonder how much consultation was taken with the Hansard reporters, the attendants of the House or with those people who have to prepare the House for the next day. I do not think they were consulted; I do not think they were asked.

BREAK.PARA: When we talk about consultation, it must involve more than just us, the elected representatives. It must involve the people who provide the opportunities to keep this House running and also the people who must clean up after the event and make sure the House is ready for the next day. These are points that must be considered.

I agree with a point that has already been picked up by previous speakers. It crossed my mind that, previously, the catering staff complained that we did not have an actual break and that we had a choice as to whether or not we stayed to eat in Parliament House. Perhaps on Monday and Tuesday nights the government is agreeing to say to the catering staff, `Yes, we will give you a commitment that we will provide a closed shop so that no one can move between the hours of 6.30 and 8 o'clock and they are going to have to participate in what is provided; otherwise they will go without.' After all, no‐one feels like eating at 12 o'clock at night. So if you do not eat at the desired time, that is an agreement we may hear about in the days ahead.

I agree with everything we have put forward. I reiterate and confirm, as the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) has stated, that we should have a little more consultation and a little more commonsense. Most particularly, with regard to sitting times, why don't we give a little further consideration to this matter? That is why I support the amendment that is before the House and will be voting for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP
