Within a short time of the announcement of the federal election, he slipped quietly away in the Mater Hospice for the Dying in Newcastle. He continued to assure me, until he could no longer speak, that he intended to get better and to campaign with me once more. In the end, it was almost as if he wanted to get out of the road so that he did not disrupt the campaign when it became a little more intense. I shall never forget his years of friendship and loyal support, and his wife, Joy, will always be a special friend of our family.

The electorate of Macarthur contains a number of areas that, in many ways, are a microcosm of Australia itself. There are those who are first home buyers; there are those who are seeking to establish for themselves and their families—in many cases, their young families—a way of life that is better for all of them. It is interesting to note that, in the success we achieved at the last election, so many of those that changed their votes to vote Liberal in the seat of Macarthur came from the areas that might otherwise have been recognised as Labor heartland. And they came to the Liberal Party in the manner in which they voted because they had been deserted by Labor. They were offered no hope; they were offered no understanding of what it meant to get ahead in terms of the progress they wanted for themselves and their families.

To achieve what we achieved at that time required an enormous team of supporters, including those members of the branches in the Liberal Party. And perhaps no‐one enjoyed the success of the Liberal Party in Macarthur more than the Camden branch president, David Funnell. I succeeded David as the president of the Camden branch in 1976. He has worked for the Liberal Party in every campaign, state and federal, for 25 years. He also experienced many disappointments in the federal campaigns until this year.

David led a willing team of supporters throughout the campaign and I am grateful to Debbie Dewbery, Charlotte Sheehan, Merle Kelly, Chris Neale, Andrew Ethell, the volunteers in the campaign rooms and the army of supporters who turned out on election day. I particularly want to mention Michael Ball, Max Tegel, Marcus Blackmore, Chris Brown and some generous supporters who contributed to the fundraising for my campaign.

The hard work of all of them helped to achieve a remarkable swing—the largest successful swing, I am pleased to say—in New South Wales. The areas in the electorate where the swing to the Liberal Party was greatest might previously have been regarded as Labor heartland and they came to the Liberal Party at this election because Labor had deserted them.

There are areas in my electorate, including the southern part around Mittagong and Bowral, that have genuine poverty. There is family dysfunction and there is a need for young people to leave their homes in search of work. The task ahead of me is to assist those communities to maintain their independence as a community, working, in government, on policies that provide the work, recreation and infrastructure that all self‐supporting communities deserve.

The coalition government was given an opportunity because we offered the people of Australia support for families and a recognition that the family is the best support unit capable of delivering a satisfying life. I know that in the months and years ahead this will be a pivotal part of government programs. I have never questioned what makes up a family unit, other than to say it is a support unit, and it has certainly been the cornerstone of my life. In recent weeks, I have been pleased to retreat to my family to regain my sanity from the burdens of grappling with the mess left by my portfolio predecessor, the now Leader of the Opposition.

I thank my wife, Colleen, for her constancy and her love, and my children who, amongst other things, have taught me to take my responsibilities seriously, but never myself. I also want to acknowledge on this occasion my mother, Anne, who is the most unselfish person I have ever known, and also my father, who gave, within our family unit, a long day's work every day. Sadly, he is not very mobile these days, but he is well cared for by the Sisters of St Joseph at St Anne's Nursing Home at Hunters Hill in Sydney.

My parents were Irish immigrants and between them they had 26 brothers and sisters. They left their families and the poverty and helplessness inflicted on them by the Great Depression in the late 1930s to create a better life for themselves and the children they hoped to have. They taught me to share, to be generous, to contribute to others, to work hard and to recognise God's role and the value of His support in all that we do.

They also taught me to think for myself and that is why I am a member of the Liberal Party. I have never voted Labor, as some scribes have written. The Liberal Party stands for all Australians, not any vested interest group such as the unions, and it supports reward for effort. Nothing is more Australian.

Yesterday, on the occasion of delivering his address to parliament, the Governor‐General indicated the commitment of this government to grappling with the prospective budget deficit of $8 billion. I concur with His Excellency's observations of the intent of this government to tackle our inheritance from the Labor administration through prudent and responsible management of the national budget.

I am honoured to have the opportunity to serve as a member of cabinet in Prime Minister John Howard's first government and I look forward to working with my colleagues in cabinet to fulfil the aspirations of all Australians, regardless of their country of birth or the colour of their skin.

The people of Macarthur and all Australians seek reward for their hard work and initiative. They aspire to an affordable home and a future for their children and they want to look forward to a better standard of living. I have full confidence that a coalition government will make significant progress in meeting these aspirations for the people of Macarthur and beyond.

There is much to be done in the suburbs, the towns and the villages of Macarthur. My great disappointment is that the government's first task must be to repair the damage caused by an uncaring and incompetent Labor government before we can deliver progress at a rate that we would wish for the Australian people.

I have never ceased, however, to admire the fortitude and generosity of the communities I have represented, in the giving of their time and skills to voluntary organisations. As we approach a new millennium there is a confidence and goodwill that I have not experienced since my younger days. Governments will never deliver what all might want, but if we can work in partnership with the voluntary groups and harness the skills and expertise of our communities, and if we can give greater opportunities to these groups of individuals, much can be achieved in the final years of this century that will make each of our communities better places. We must give opportunities to our young and look after our aged, who have done so much for us in the past.

In my initial maiden speech I spoke of the need to promote and facilitate small business as a job creator. I spoke of the significant contribution the coal industry could make to my electorate and the nation's exports. I also spoke of the need for proper infrastructure for the communities I represented. Those same issues exist today. More needs to be done to make better communities in Rosemeadow, Warragamba, Thirlmere, Oakdale and Hilltop and the surrounding towns.

The horticulturalists, tradesmen and service industries are small businesses, and the local miners and cement workers can, and do, contribute to our nation's wealth. I shall take a special interest in benefits for our families and facilities for our aging—whether it be at the Queen Victoria Hospital at Picton or anywhere else in Macarthur—and the enhancement of small business through a regulatory regime that gives incentives for Australians to have a go.

I pay tribute to the many colleagues who helped me in the past to develop my political skills, whatever they might be. I was fortunate to have the benefit of counsel and advice from two very good state leaders—Nick Greiner in the area of management and economics and Wal Murray on how to be practical, objective and solid in what you believe in. I had the loyalty and support of many cabinet colleagues, one of whom is in the chamber today, the honourable member for Page (Mr Causley), and I also had the understanding and knowledge of teamwork installed in me by many of those people. I was taught to stand up for what was right, even if it was unpopular. I had a great team of advisers, including the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey), in my office over those past three years in government.

The Liberal Party has given me a chance to work for my family, my neighbours, my community and my state. The Liberal Party now gives me a chance to work for my country. I thank my long‐time conference president, Roger Warner, and secretary, Margaret Hogg, for always being there, and the hundreds of volunteers in the branches who share my beliefs in the Liberal Party philosophy.

I am excited about the future. We approach the centenary of Federation and we will host the biggest peace‐time event in the world's history, the Olympic Games. We must harness the enthusiasm and skills that Australians have in vast quantities. The government has an opportunity and a responsibility to progress our nation, to take a prominent role in our region but, more importantly, to progress the individual lives of all Australians so we may all play satisfying, rewarding and fulfilling roles in one Australia.

My parents instilled in me the virtues of compassion and respect for others. I will do my best to translate those virtues into a meaningful gain for the people of Macarthur and the people all around Australia. I thank the House for the courtesies and forbearance extended to me during this address.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I join with other members of the House in conveying congratulations to you, the member for Casey (Mr Halverson) and the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) on your election to these important presiding offices within the parliament. I wish you well in the execution of your tasks.

SPEECH.PARA: I note the contents of the speech by the new member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey). It was quite a provocative speech, launching strong personal attacks on the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), former Prime Minister Mr Keating and even one of my predecessors, the great man himself, Gough Whitlam. What are we to make of those comments? It is true, as the member for Macarthur outlined, that Gough Whitlam established the modern welfare state in Australia. Can the House now conclude that the new member for Macarthur, as Minister for Finance, has set himself the task of dismantling that welfare state, leaving Australia with an American‐style system where there is no public housing and people live and sleep on the streets, and where there are no adequate long‐term transfer payments and social security and people beg on the streets?

I would have thought, according to Australian values of egalitarianism and inclusiveness, that the people of this nation would have much to be thankful for in the record of Gough Whitlam and much to be concerned about in the impending cuts launched by the new member for Macarthur in his capacity as Minister for Finance.We on this side of the House will be monitoring the new member's progress.

It is always interesting to note transformations. We heard yesterday of the quite remarkable transformation of the new Speaker. One day he was the Chief Opposition Whip, the next day a so‐called independent Speaker; one day winning 41 hard‐earned ballots in the Liberal party room, knocking Ironbar and the member for New England (Mr Sinclair) out of the race—a real knock `em down, lay `em flat sort of party battle—the next day an independent Speaker of the House of Representatives. These ironies extend to the member for Macarthur, the new Minister for Finance: one day guarding the state finances in New South Wales, guarding state grants against Commonwealth attacks, making public statements about how none of these state grants should be touched; the next day arriving in this place as the head man on the razor gang, to cut away those state grants and programs in education, health and housing.

These remarkable transformations really amaze the opposition. We will be holding not only the new Speaker but also the new member for Macarthur, the finance minister, accountable because they cannot have it both ways. A member cannot be a card-carrying member of the Liberal Party—the new Speaker has publicly said he will remain as that—and yet say he is independent. He is no more independent than I am, just as the new member for Macarthur is no more able to legitimately cut away at the finances of the Commonwealth. Given his very strong public record as Premier of New South Wales, he cannot say that none of those outlays, none of those grants, to the states in education, health and housing can possibly be touched without massive social dislocation and inequity in our society.

After 13 years many Australians have been keen to judge the character of this new government. We can tell a lot about a new government from its early decisions, its priorities, its concerns, its political strategy. What have Australians found in this new Howard-Fischer government? What sorts of conclusions are they now drawing? I think they are finding a mean streak, a nasty streak. They are finding a determination to set Australian against Australian by fanning bigotry, fanning prejudice, in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —You talk about that! What about Keating and bigotry?

—And may well the Chief Government Whip interject. A government, as he knows full well, has a range of choices upon its election. This new government could have announced, for instance, in its first bundle of decisions major changes to Australia's health structures, the rejuvenation of Australia's education system, ambitious plans following Brian Howe's outstanding work for a revolution in the way in which we provide public housing in this country, and policies that go to the heart of better government, better structures and better performance by the public sector. But the government did not announce any of those things. It pushed the buttons on the keyboard of Australian public life to fan prejudice, to fan bigotry. I will provide some examples.

PARA.BREAK: The government pushed buttons in its deliberate strategy relating to welfare provi sion. I thought the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) was trying to do Ray Martin and A Current Affair out of job by saying that she would be issuing press releases to publicly expose welfare cheats. It was shades, a reminder, of medieval England: they would be out there in the stocks and we would all go out and throw tomatoes at them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the member for Wentworth (Mr Andrew Thomson), who is at the table, applauds this sort of behaviour by a minister of the Crown. It is quite remarkable because she was really saying that she was going to fan the idea that Australians who do not earn welfare should be set against those who do.

And this was for what? What was her stunning public policy solution to this problem? She announced she would issue those press releases and one extra telephone line by which people could ring up. That probably adds to scores of telephone lines in the Department of Social Security whereby concerned Australians can report instances of welfare abuse. For no major change in the structure of government, no answers and no solutions that provide better government, she was willing to fan those prejudices in our community.

That was followed by the announcement for a relatively minor gain in the budget by placing new restrictions on migrants and their eligibility for social security payments. It is not a big saving but it sets the 78 per cent of Australians who were born here against the 22 per cent of Australians who were born overseas.

The next announcement concerned ATSIC. Again, there was no major restructuring of Aboriginal affairs and no formulation for better government and better delivery of programs for Aboriginal people. The announcement was that ATSIC would have one extra auditor—one extra auditor for an organisation which is audited more thoroughly than any other part of the public sector in this nation. What is the purpose of it? It is a deliberate strategy to set the two per cent of Australians of Aboriginal heritage against the 98 per cent of Australians who are non-Aboriginal.

The new government's next decision was the old stock‐in‐trade of tory governments: kick the public servants, kick the public sector. This is a strategy designed to set the 20 per cent of Australians employed in the public sector against the 80 per cent of Australians employed in the private sector.

Finally in this gang of five decisions came the government's industrial relations reform. The only purpose of this legislation is to set the 65 per cent of Australians who do not belong to unions against the 35 per cent who do, to drive unions out of the workplace and to set Australians against Australians in the workplaces of this nation.

So much for `All of us'. This is a government for some. This is a government for a certain part of Australian society set against the minority. It is a government that governs for a majority and kicks the minority. It does this under the cloak of so-called political correctness. We will hear about this so-called political correctness today and throughout the next fortnight from many members speaking for the first time in the House.

Political correctness is of course code for saying that governments in this country care too much about minority interests—minority interests being the interests of those who are disadvantaged. This is a group of members who think the role of government is to govern not for all of us, not for all Australians, but for a majority of Australians who are advantaged and to govern against the interests, to deliberately kick the interests, of a minority of Australians who are disadvantaged. This is a government that is for 70 per cent against 30 per cent, for 98 per cent against two per cent, for 65 per cent against 35 per cent. It is not a government for all Australians.

Over time the Australian people will understand these deliberate political strategies. They will understand the way in which the coalition is fanning the fires of prejudice and bigotry in Australia. Like the little boy who lights a fire and sits on the hill to watch the forest burn down, the government is letting these views run on talkback radio and redneck parts of the community as a deliberate, shameful political strategy.

Having been a member of this House for about two years, I can recall how the now Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), told us that we could not debate the republic because it was divisive. We could not debate the republic because it might set Australian against Australian, but we can debate Aboriginal affairs, welfare abuse, migration and the public sector, and we can kick some public servants.

This is the John Howard who adopted as his mantra in Australian politics that `the things that unite us are more important than the things that divide us'. I challenge members on the opposite side, members of the government, particularly those making their first speeches, to answer this question: what is it that unites Australia under a Howard government? What is it that has come from the first two months of its administration that unites Australians?

There is no unity between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australia because of the decisions of this government. There is no unity between the private sector and the public sector, no unity between Australians born here and those born overseas, and no unity between Australians who belong to trade unions and those who do not.

This is a government which has deliberately set Australian against Australian. This is the Thatcherite strategy of thinking—that you can govern for a majority, in her case the south of England, against the interests of a minority, in her case the north. This is a government which has set about a political strategy of dividing the nation and it is doing it for a lowbrow, low‐grade political purpose.

This really is the lowest common denominator in Australian public life and it teaches a pretty important lesson. It is always so much harder in public life to encourage people to do good things—to encourage people to actually care about the needy and to encourage people to take a broader view of what we can achieve as a society and as a nation. It is so much harder on our side of politics, the Labor side of politics, when we take on the task of trying to encourage people to think fairly and compassionately about their fellow Australians.

It is so much easier on the conservative, reactionary side of politics to light the fire, to fan it away and to get people thinking the worst of each other. So we take the high road on this side of the House and we are very glad of that because, at the end of the day, when you look at the social fabric and at the sorts of emotions that run through the community, you see that you are always out there doing good by encouraging people to think well of others.

The other thing we will hear in these first speeches, and it is an ideology across the government benches, is this concept of the crowding out thesis—that somehow the public sector is crowding out small business in Australia and that somehow the welfare state is crowding out civil institutions. I see one of the new members at the back nodding. He should understand that half of the small businesses in Australia are sole traders. Of the 800,000 small businesses in Australia, 400,000 are sole traders. From ABS data, they would have been known 10 years ago as employees—carpenters, tradesmen and computer technologists working for companies but who have now gone out to form their own businesses and are working by themselves for themselves.

How can supply‐side solutions do anything for their business? How can an unfair dismissal act do anything for the 400,000 small businesses in Australia that involve one person? Is this the idea that you have: you can generate employment by making it easier for people to sack themselves? This is the absurdity of what the government is suggesting.

There is no crowding out of small business by the public sector, because for most small businesses in Australia their success is a function of spending power. I can walk through the main street of Campbelltown in my electorate and hear nobody complaining about the award system, or about the need for micro reforms or about the supply side.

PARA.BREAK: The function and success of small business is a function of the demand side—how much people spend. Small businesses rely on ex penditure. In many parts of Australia, including Campbelltown, they rely on public expenditure. If that public expenditure is removed from the local economy, there is no private expenditure to take its place. It is self-evident that this government's strategy of cutting away at the public sector, disadvantaging already depressed regional economies by taking away those public resources, will add to unemployment. It will make the task of small business so much harder.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an easy way to understand this, and it relates to the Prime Minister's background. In the election campaign he said that he was keen on small business, because that is his family background. He was a bowser boy in inner Sydney. But he does not understand that the success of that business depended on the volume of petrol purchased. The success of that business depended on the demand for petrol and not on the supply‐side considerations for which he now has a fetish as Prime Minister. So most small businesses in Australia rely much more on spending power in the community than they do on any of the supply‐side micro reforms this government has on its agenda.

In terms of the welfare system, is the government really suggesting that winding back programs provokes some flood of private charity into the community? Is that the crowding out thesis that provokes some flood of new civil and civic institutions to take the place of government?

Government is nothing more than an expression of the collective will. It is a determination of citizens to have institutions which act in the collective interest—to raise revenue collectively and to provide programs collectively that individuals, particularly disadvantaged individuals, cannot provide for themselves. There is no crowding out thesis for small business or with regard to the welfare state in Australia.

This government throughout its term will do great damage to the Australian economy, because it has a very inappropriate set of policies in place. It has living standard initiatives based on $10 billion worth of cuts to the social wage—the $8 billion outlined by the Treasurer after the election plus the $2 billion per annum outlined during the election campaign. There will be more labour market deregulation, where the weak are set against the strong in the workplace, and of course there will be higher interest rates.

This is a high interest rate government because it has abolished the accord. It has thrown wages policy out the window, and for no good reason. With the globalisation of capital, active fiscal policy is limited by spill‐over effects on the external account and monetary policy is under the influence of convergence with the dynamic nature of capital movements between nations. You will find that most monetary policy is converging around some basic fundamentals. So one of the great expressions of national sovereignty and autonomous policy for the macro economy is wages policy. This government has decided to abandon the one thing a nation can keep within its power to distinctly influence economic outcomes.

It does not understand the basis of industrial relations. IR reform is not just a micro reform issue—extra productivity in the workplace—but also a macro‐economic issue, because it is the best way of controlling wage and inflation outcomes. Unions are the only collective institution in the economy which can possibly keep those outcomes within the inflation goals of government.

Individuals will not do it. No individual is going to listen to John Howard or Peter Costello saying, `You should turn down wage bargains you can achieve in the market.' That person will be thinking, `If I do that, and other people pursue aggressive wage bargains, I still have to pay the increase in interest rates as a product of wage based inflation.' So only unions as a collective institution in the workplace can provide the macro wages policy restraint and discipline. That of course was the key feature of the accord.

Without the accord, the first thing you are left with is huff and puff. You just have to try to lecture the public into taking a lower level of wages to what the market would pay. The second thing you are left with is an excessive use of monetary policy. If you cannot keep wages and inflation in check with wages policy, it follows that government and the Reserve Bank need to use pre-emptive monetary policy. There has to be a greater and an earlier use of interest rates. And that is what we are seeing. Do not just take it from me. The independent economic forecasting group, Syntec, recently stated in the Australian:
Gareth Evans, the shadow Treasurer, is right in saying now that under a Labor government falls in official interest rates would be occurring.

Under a Labor government with the accord in place, with a macro wages policy in place, Australia would now have a cut in interest rates. We have not had that cut because this government have foolishly thrown wages policy and the accord out the window. It is well and good for the Treasurer to talk about the current account deficit as a brake on economic growth. He is now two‐brake Costello. There is the brake he has acknowledged from the current account deficit, and the extra brake that he has placed on the Australian economy by abandoning wages policy. There is an extra brake on the Australian economy by virtue of higher interest rates—a restraint on growth.

Under the former government, after the last upswing in the business cycle Australia led the world in growth. Under the new government, with higher interest rates, without the sort of cut that would have been achieved under the accord, we are going to fall off the back of international growth. We are going to fall down the OECD growth table, all because of this government's misguided economic strategies. It is a great shame that the government has chosen in its first days to turn a majority of Australians against a minority; to turn Australian against Australian. It is a great shame indeed that on the economic policy front they have labelled themselves a high interest rate, low growth government with falling living standards for the average Australian family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Moreton, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech, and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In advance, I thank the House for the courtesy extended to me. Also, let me congratulate you on your election to your very important office. I thank all ordinary members for the down‐to‐earth decency of the welcome that has been extended to me. I am pleased that my wife, Judy, and our children, Jessica and Ben, are here today—as are my parents, Doug and Hazel, and my parents‐in‐law, John and Joan Andrews.

SPEECH.PARA: Through the course of my address I would like to tell honourable members a little about me and what I hope to contribute to and achieve during my time here. I would also like to outline a number of important matters for the record so that in years to come I can easily refer back to them. I am one of the 53 new parliamentarians, and I share the concern of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and many people in my electorate about how we conduct ourselves in this place. Many people tell me that they want to see a greater deal of decorum and more of a fair go for all than has been the case in recent parliaments. People's present perception of this place is a burden we can all discard through performance. I imagine, Mr Deputy Speaker, you also realise that with so many new members—over one‐third of us—there will never be a better time to forge some new habits and break some old ones. I am sure that all honourable members also agree. My constituents expect good conduct. I am their representative here, and I will do my utmost to justify their support in me.

Moreton has been my home for over 25 years, and four generations of my family live locally. I believe I am the only ex-student of Runcorn State Primary, of MacGregor State High and of Griffith University—all within my electorate—to have been elected to this place. It is certainly a great honour to be the first from each of those schools and the local university, and to represent them here.

I owe my election largely to the impact which two people have had on the people of Moreton. One is our Prime Minister, a man held in high regard in the Moreton electorate, and the other person is the previous Prime Minister. The election result certainly exceeded the expectations of the experts, but it did reflect the views of most local people I met. I knocked on the doors of over 13,000 homes for over 12 months and the depth of feeling amongst so many people, including the life‐long Labor voters whom I met along the way, was simply that Keating and Labor had to go.

My campaign was a very local effort, and my focus will remain very Moreton-centric. The people of Moreton rightly expect and will receive from me, both in the parliament and through departmental and ministerial channels, solid representation. The people of Moreton want this government to get the basic things right first: the family, small business, the creation of real jobs—all items which Labor left off its agenda. Labor said there was simply nothing wrong. Labor said families were well looked after and small business was booming. In Labor's mind‐set there were plenty of jobs, and increasing crime was just one of those things. Labor ignored local road and infrastructure problems, overcrowding in classrooms and increasing red tape affecting everyday people.

Each of these very real issues, ignored by Labor, all relate to individuals—people. Labor had forgotten about real people. That is why it lost the last election. I believe we must ensure that individuals recognise their responsibilities, achieve and contribute to their personal life and, by it, to their community while ensuring the protection of those less able. The great Liberal, and second Prime Minister of Australia, Alfred Deakin, set out his views 90 years ago in a major speech in 1906 on the role of government. What Deakin said of the Liberal Party then is just as true today. He said that the party:
. . . has sought social justice by trusting the people and developing the powers of self-government.
Deakin also tempered this testimony of belief in individuals with this observation:
The Liberal Party does not fear to use the social powers and authorities, which legislation and administration present . . .
He also said:
The action of the state is justified by the results.

Those words of 90 years ago set clearly the case against the previous government. The results of the actions taken by Labor over 13 years just did not sustain them. Labor lost the election based on its record.

Labor policies enforced bland, compulsory, politically correct behaviour. Traditional families were devalued. Labor laws allowed and financed children to simply leave home when they chose, and parents were told that they could not force their children to obey their authority. Is it any wonder that crime increased under Labor? Labor failed small business, the young, the hundreds of thousands wanting a job and just as many more who gave up looking for one. Labor's intimidation and control of the lives and finances of independent and pension retirees and war veterans through complex and restrictive laws were an absolute disgrace.

Labor signed away many of our rights and obligations as individuals to foreign authority and international scrutiny. Their cuts in defence spending made our national security vulnerable. Labor created a nation in which many people turned to government at every obstacle. You could easily say they turned the social security safety net into a hammock.

Labor's idea of multiculturalism was based on segmenting the community, not bringing it together. Unlike Labor, I believe Australians of all backgrounds and beliefs can unite by emphasising the similarities, not highlighting the differences. Labor's way needed legislation to force conformity and adherence. Labor's approach caused great resentment among many Australians. I believe the Howard government will build a better future for all Australians and will bring us all closer together.

Last Friday evening, 250 members of my local community gathered to form the Lions Club of Brisbane‐Chinese. This is the third such club in Australia and I was honoured to attend and extend good wishes on behalf of both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock). The formation of this club is very well supported in my electorate and will allow these good local citizens to continue to build bridges in the broader community.

Asian migrants in Moreton are those who believe strongly in the family and in individual enterprise. They chose Australia as their new home and as a place to invest because it promised so much—but like the broader community, they knew Labor was taking them nowhere fast.

As His Excellency outlined yesterday, there is much work to be done in this 38th Parliament. We have to reverse the trend Labor created where the system of the state became more important than the outcomes. Sustaining the system and protecting the stakeholders in the system became the driving force for decision making under Labor rather than ensuring real positive outcomes for the people we are all elected to serve.

In that vein, I promise the people of my electorate that I want to build an effective partnership with them. My own experience and viewpoint is not the only one to prevail in my deliberations in this place; rather, I will continue to actively seek and consider the broad viewpoint of my constituents. My role is clearly as their representative in this place and I will act accordingly in attempting to influence good and sensible outcomes from the system.

As a new member in this place, my prevailing enthusiasm is tempered and sobered by the great responsibility which we all share. The changes we must realise which everyday Australians expect us to deliver are important. Australians want early signposts from the new government that action is taking place. Australians of all backgrounds and ages want to be able to plan for the future and work to meet their goals with certainty. They do not want a repeat of the Labor years where government constantly changed rules and conditions. As honourable members would know, superannuation laws are the classic example.

Australians who invest in productive assets and infrastructure want to be rewarded, not penalised like self‐funded retirees and small business people were during the Labor years. Most of all, Australians expect this government to restore reward for individual effort. Australia must become again, as the great Liberal Sir Robert Menzies put it in his famous `forgotten people' broadcast of 1942:
. . . a community of people whose motto shall be to strive, to seek, to find and not to yield.

Of course, Australians rightly expect some government support for individual endeavour. It is a legitimate role of government to provide the infrastructure for business and individuals to use in the pursuit of their goals. In a land as broad and as sparsely populated as ours, this has been a fact since 1788.

Menzies and other Liberal prime ministers all recognised a positive role for the state to ensure equality of opportunity for all. Liberals have always ensured that those who would be otherwise disadvantaged are afforded a dignified and just role in our society. After all, the great social reforms show that we as a nation are not into the selfish, strict laissez‐faire style where some miss out and social obligations are ignored.

As representatives of the people, we have to ensure that there are the right results from our actions here, while also trying to simplify and decrease the rules and regulations affecting and restricting the freedom of individual Australians. Mr Deputy Speaker, you no doubt gather that I am not a rabid deregulationist. I believe that market forces alone have led over time to monopolies in many industries, which is often against the public good.

My personal professional experience proves to me how true this is in the case of media ownership. A look at the poor consumer performance of the banking sector confirms the effect on so many other people. Look at the engine room of our economy, the small business sector—the mums and dads, the families, the individuals who give up a lot to try to make a go of it.

In my electorate many struggle to compete, or have given up trying to compete, against the giants of retailing who have lobbied successfully for deregulation of trading hours. I am all for less but the result must always be better regulation. As Nick Greiner said in 1985:
Government intervention must be in the public interest, not that of vested, special interest groups.

In this regard the government's stated plans to enshrine workers' freedom of choice in the new industrial relations legislation must make it a worthy bill. Vested interests within the system, especially the union bosses who have forgotten the worker, are the only ones with anything to fear from any changes introduced by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith). I have no doubt that the legislation will ensure that individual workers are given the freedom to choose to bargain directly or, if they feel inadequate to the task, to empower their union to act on their behalf.

I also support voluntary unionism. After all, this process will force union bosses to be more accountable to their membership. If the union bosses perform well, the membership of the union will support them and more people will join. But if the current detached style of union leadership continues, more and more people will vote with their feet and leave unions.

The problems we face in Australia today will be the problems which my children will inherit unless we act during the life of this 38th Parliament. For my children—Jessica is six and Ben will be four in a few weeks—this week has perhaps been a bit of a boring occasion but in some ways also a great adventure. It has been their first trip in an aircraft and they have visited a very strange world called Canberra. My children sought one assurance from me before the election—that, if elected, I would take them to Sea World. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am happy to report that it was the first of my election promises kept.

My daughter's understanding of politics, though, extended a little further. She knew Mr Keating was that nasty man who did not want Daddy to win—and that meant no trip to Sea World. So she, like many others in Moreton, had a great motivation to ensure there was a change of government.

Today is a moment of great pride for my family. My parents taught me to work hard and make the most of opportunities. They were born and raised in average Australian working class families in and around Kogarah, Botany and Brighton in Sydney's south. My mother's family were real battlers; they had been around that area since the late 1700s. In fact, some of my ancestors earned a living fishing in the Cooks River and out into Botany Bay—they certainly could not do that today. My father learnt his trade as a teenager. As a fitter and machinist he has worked his way to senior management with a leading carbide tooling company. Both my parents showed me the virtue of community service—active involvement in helping others around you in the true traditional Australian way of mateship, and lending a helping hand to others less fortunate.

I now turn to my grandparents; I am blessed to have three still living. They are people of a generation which gave so much to Australia. As children, they faced the first great war. They later built families, despite the Depression of the 1930s, and then fought the Second World War. They worked hard to build a great nation and a rich heritage which in so many ways has been squandered in recent years. Both my grandfathers are former truck drivers and labourers. One, I believe, voted Labor for probably most of his life—although he has not in the last few elections. The other was born and raised in Brisbane's southern suburbs in and around the Moreton electorate.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the genealogy will continue for just a moment to let you know that the Hardgrave family were Irish potato famine refugees who came to Brisbane in 1848. One ancestor, John Hardgrave, served as alderman for South Brisbane and later as Mayor of Brisbane in 1868 and 1869. All four of my grandparents, especially, gave me a real understanding about where a dollar comes from, how hard it can be to earn a living and how important family is above all.

I would now like to thank my wife. Like so many members, I come to this place as part of a team. My wife, Judy, brings her own skills and experience to the job. It is not easy for the spouses and families of people in politics, and Judy knows this all too well. I should also like to acknowledge my wife's parents, John and Joan Andrews, residents of the electorate of the honourable member for Longman (Mr Brough). They have played a ready role in the extended family support which helps my wife and I to do our job.

So it is a great honour for me to stand here and represent the people of Moreton in this place. I am the eighth person to have been returned as the member for Moreton since this Federation seat was created in 1900. Moreton has always been a seat based on southern Brisbane suburbs. It has only ever returned two Labor members: its first member who held the seat for five years until 1906, and my immediate predecessor who held the seat for the last six years.

Between those two Labor members for Moreton there spanned 84 years of strong and effective representation by members of the Liberal Party or its various early incarnations. I can only say that I will work very hard to ensure that, based on the merit of my performance as the local member and of course that of the government, we can earn another period of trust and goodwill within the Moreton electorate to rival the earlier one.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to acknowledge a few more people. Probably the best known former member for Moreton, a man who is held in very high regard, is Sir James Killen. Sir James and Lady Killen were most effective advocates for my campaign. Jim honoured me greatly by his personal letter of support circulated throughout the electorate. The other former Liberal member for Moreton, Don Cameron, and his wife, Lila, are true friends. They have maintained their solid commitment to the local Moreton community and were always there throughout my campaign.

The Minister for Administrative Services, the member for Fadden, David Jull, has been my mentor and friend for over 22 years. He is well liked within my electorate. About 60 per cent of my constituents were very well represented in this place by Mr Jull until the 1993 election.

Another extra special mention I would like to make is of Senator David MacGibbon. I count the recent years I have worked on Senator MacGibbon's staff as a highly valuable addition to my experiences in life. Senator MacGibbon's vast experience and approach of genuine commitment to his state and nation have left a lasting impression.

My thanks also should go to my campaign director, John Caris. He directed a large and very effective local team. The Moreton Liberal campaign maintained its local focus because so many good people, active in my local area, came to help. I was lucky to have over 1,400 local people working on my campaign in one form or another—people who have long supported our party, the true‐blue believers; others who were determined to see a change for the better and wanted to make sure that it happened. The list is just too long to read here, you will be thankful to know, so my thanks and congratulations must go to all. Each is a great Australian, and I know that they are determined to keep me in touch with my local community. The partnership I offer the people of Moreton is just beginning.

I am sure that we will all consider carefully the impact of the important legislation which we will pass. As private members of the House of Representatives, we all have a role to play in advocating the right changes to ensure the right results for those we represent—and, to me, the people of my electorate will always come first.
I will finish with the advice for Liberals from Alfred Deakin's 1895 speech What is liberalism. Deakin wanted Liberals to look at the issues and to tread the paths of progress. Deakin said:
In doing so, they would make mistakes but they would leave the world on the whole a better place than they found it.
Mr Deputy Speaker, Deakin's words of 101 years ago are still true for us today as we commence this 38th Parliament. I again thank the House for the courtesy extended to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I again take this opportunity to congratulate you on your election to your high office, and I ask that you relay to the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) and the member for Casey (Mr Halverson) similar congratulations on their election.
