—I take this opportunity to congratulate the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) on his inaugural speech. This is the second time that I have been elected as the member for Perth, and I thank the people of Perth for their confidence and trust. I propose to continue to work hard to earn their continued local support. Local representation is very important, and I regard the community obligations which come from that as being a most important part of a member's role.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take this opportunity to thank my campaign director, Dr Ric Charlesworth, who was, of course, my immediate predecessor. He again was successfully able to ensure my re‐election and again successfully able to ensure a swing towards my party in the division of Perth. I would also like to take the opportunity to thank my campaign committee and, in particular, my local state parliamentary colleagues who worked so hard to help ensure my re-election. They include the state member for Perth, Diana Warnock; the state member for Maylands, Judy Edwards; the state member for Morley, Clive Brown; the state member for Balcatta, Nick Catania; and the state member for Glendalough, Michelle Roberts.

I would also like to take the opportunity of thanking my family for their help, support and sacrifice over the three‐year period of my first term. I believe in the notion of continuous campaigning so the election campaign period was simply four or five weeks on top of a three‐year term. There are the usual family sacrifices which come with that. I take this opportunity of thanking my wife Jane, my son Hugo and my daughter Madeleine, together with my mother and father who have been guiding lights and of continual support throughout my entire life.

I would like to relate a couple of Perth campaign matters to the House: one is important for those of my generation on our side and the other is a sad tale. On the Sunday after the election I was very pleased that the former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam rang me to congratulate me on my re‐election; to make the point to me of how fortunate one is to represent the city of one's state, whether it be, as in my case, Perth, or in the case of Arch Bevis in Queensland, the seat of Brisbane; and to encourage me to nominate for our party's executive, which I did. I thank my colleagues for accepting my successful nomination.

BREAK.PARA: The sad matter concerns one of the people whose advice I took over the three‐year period of the last parliament. I refer to a well‐known journalist in Western Australia, Ron Barry, a person whom I have known for many years in the various capacities in which I have worked for the Australian Labor Party during my adult life. He has been a source of good advice and considerable assistance over very many years.

Unfortunately, Ron took ill in the course of the last quarter of 1995 and the first quarter of 1996 and tragically died recently at the age of 47. He was survived by his wife Carol and three young sons: Nicholas, Simon and Christopher. Ron was a journalist who, in my view, was exceptional amongst Western Australian political journalists and who also, from time to time, worked for the Australian Labor Party. Ron was the only WA political journalist I knew who had a timetable, horizon or view that was longer than that day's deadline. He could always give you sensible strategic advice and long‐term advice rather than the tactical advice which came from a newspaper or television deadline.

I invited Ron to my campaign launch which was conducted by the then Deputy Prime Minister and now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). Ron attended with his two elder sons and told me how pleased he was that finally they were at last displaying some interest in public and national affairs. The last time I spoke to Ron was on the night of the election when, with the three‐hour time difference, we already had the bad general news. I rang Ron at home to tell him that, despite the bad general news, we had managed to sneak over the line in Perth. Ron did what he always did: he rejoiced in someone else's personal good fortune much more than he ever sought his own.

Ron will be a great loss to the Western Australian journalistic community and a great loss to the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party. Ron Barry worked for successive leaders of the WA parliamentary Labor Party from John Tonkin to Colin Jamison, Ron Davies, Brian Burke and Peter Dowding. He was an unpaid adviser to every state secretary of the Western Australian branch of the ALP since Joe Chamberlain. It was fitting that his memorial service was attended by four leaders, current or former, of the state parliamentary Labor Party. I take this opportunity to extend again to Carol my deepest sympathy in a tragedy which cut short so early a great contribution and a great life.

I have referred to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley. I was very pleased, of course, when he won the seat of Brand. On our side of the House we look forward to ensuring that, after Prime Minister Curtin and Prime Minister Hawke, in the not too distant future Western Australia will have its first naturally born Labor prime minister rather than an adopted one as was the case with John Curtin and Bob Hawke.

I take this opportunity to congratulate my colleague the member for Fremantle, Dr Lawrence, on her re‐election. I extend my best wishes to George Gear, the former member for Canning, who lost his marginal seat. I wish Wendy Fatin, the former member for Brand, all the best in her retirement.

I also take this opportunity of congratulating the independent member for Kalgoorlie, Graeme Campbell, on his re‐election. Graeme resigned from the Labor Party and won the seat as an Independent—one of the five Independents in this House, three of whom come from Western Australia. I think I am one of only two people remaining in the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party who has voted for Graeme Campbell twice in a pre‐selection. It was our national executive, acting out of my own best interests, which prevented me from having the opportunity of seeing whether I could deliver the hat‐trick. Despite the fact that in party political terms we have parted ways, I wish Graeme all the best in the course of this term of parliament.

Graeme, of course, defeated Ian Taylor, the former state member for Kalgoorlie and former state leader of the parliamentary Labor Party. I have known Ian Taylor for over 20 years. Ian is a man of great integrity. There are two things about Ian which I have said publicly before: firstly, he has always put the interests of his party ahead of himself and, secondly, he is a person who has always been decent and good natured and public life has never deformed him. He was the same when he completed public life as he was when he began it.

The night of the election was, of course, a very bad night for the Australian Labor Party, but it was also a very bad night for the Western Australian Liberal Party. That was the night when Richard Court's handcuff to Senator Noel Crichton‐Browne came home to rest. I take this opportunity of congratulating the independent member for Cutin, Mr Rocher, and the independent member for Moore, Mr Filing, on their success. Their success shows the failure of John Howard to display any form of leadership influence over the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party.

Election night was a particularly bad night for the Court dynasty in Western Australia, with Richard's older brother Ken being comprehensibly defeated by Mr Rocher. I am sure, however, that the member for Curtin would be deeply distressed and disappointed to see that the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard), as the first of his broken promises, failed to deliver on the notion of a truly independent speaker. At the Press Club on the Thursday before the election, the current Prime Minister said:
. . . that is why I am committed, if I become Prime Minister of this country, I am committed to ensuring that the Australian parliament has a truly independent Speaker in every sense of the word.

I am sure that the member for Curtin took that as being an invitation to him, and we have seen him no doubt distressed about that. I am sure that those members who have been around for a while would understand the credentials that the member for Curtin has to take on the speakership.

In my inaugural speech nearly three years ago, I made the point that, as a result of my election, there were four Western Australian state secretaries of the ALP in the previous parliament—the then Senator McMullan, Senator Beahan, the President of the Senate, the then Senator elect Chris Evans, whom I congratulate on becoming the Senate Opposition Whip, and me. I made the point that it was clearly the case that, of the four state secretaries, I had the best judgment because I had chosen the decent House. I am pleased to see that former Senator McMullan, the new member for Canberra, has come to his senses and joined us. I congratulate him as a former Western Australian on his election to this House.

I would like to take this opportunity to mention three fallen colleagues: the former member for Lindsay, Ross Free, for whom I worked for a short time while he was minister for science—he became not just an employer but a friend and subsequent colleague; the former member for Lowe, Mary Easson, whom I sat next to in the chamber in the previous parliament; and the former member for Lilley and my former Queensland counterpart, the Queensland ALP state secretary, Wayne Swan. We on this side look forward to seeing them back, and I am sure they will be.

In the course of my campaign, I told the people of Perth that there were a range of local projects and issues that I was keen to pursue in this term of parliament. I will restate those commitments now. They include: working towards the establishment of a university in Midland; working for the establishment of a railway line from Bayswater to the airport in Perth; establishing a small business enterprise centre in Morley; transferring the Bassendean railway museum to the old Midland Westrail railway workshops in Midland; establishing a swimming pool and water playground complex in Beechboro‐Lockridge; creating a sensible community development of the Maylands clay pits; and creating more sensible transport options for Northbridge and the inner city.

As a result of the election, our parliamentary party was beaten but not broken, bowed but not disgraced. We had plenty of achievements during our term in office which those on this side of the House can be proud of—including those in respect of job creation, living standards, health and education services and the protection of the environment. We have left the essential parameters of the economy in good shape—with consistent growth over a four-year period running at four per cent, low inflation and a sensible wages policy.

The features of our 13-year term in office include: increasing the labour force by over two million workers; creating more than 700,000 new jobs in our last three‐year term in office; massively increasing secondary school retention rates from 30 per cent to percentages in the high 60s or low 70s; massively increasing the number of university places; providing a massive injection of capital into TAFE facilities; creating universal access to health care through Medicare; and, in addition to some of those important economic parameters I have referred to, producing a massive increase in the diversity, range and quantity of exports, which have started the process of turning Australia into a modern trading and exporting country. In the end, `time for a change' as well as other factors got the better of us, but those are things that we on this side of the House can be very proud of.

I was very pleased that the Leader of the Opposition offered me the trade portfolio. I gladly accepted it, having a longstanding interest in trade and industry matters. I will endeavour to ensure that I do my best to explain to my own constituency and to the party's traditional supporters that trade, in very many respects, equals creation of jobs and maintenance of living standards. I note in passing that one of the very successful trade and exporting programs which was supported and sustained by our government is currently under threat—that is, the export market development grants scheme.

I look forward with interest to taking up these issues with the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer). We need to ensure that our nation continues to drive towards success, and that success will be measured by the creation of jobs and maintenance of living standards in Australia and our continuation as a major trading and exporting country.

In the short time left to me, I will not traverse the same ground covered by my colleague the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham)—that is, the failure of the current government to adopt a sensible wages policy; the failure of the current government to ensure that, at a time when interest rates can go down, they do go down; and, at a time when we have seen record low periods of industrial disputation in the course of our 13 years in office, those opposite are doing their best to ensure that industrial disputation comes to the fore again.

Mr Speaker, I take this opportunity as you enter the chair to personally convey my congratulations to you. In the course of this morning's debate on changes to our procedures, some of us took the opportunity to advise new members of the House about some of those arrangements. To those many new members opposite, I give this advice on a couple of other matters. So far as your employment is concerned—take leave; don't resign. So far as Canberra accommodation is concerned—rent; don't buy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3 p.m, the debate is interrupted in accordance with the resolution agreed to earlier this day. The debate may be resumed at later hour. If the member's speech is interrupted, the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This morning, accompanied by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) and by Tasmanian members and senators from both sides of the House, I visited Tasmania. Senator Kernot, the Leader of the Opposition and I travelled to Port Arthur and spoke to a number of the people who had been directly involved in the tragic circumstances of last Sunday. Later all of us attended a very moving and, I hope to the people most affected, helpful memorial service in the Anglican cathedral in Hobart. I hope that the gesture in a small way demonstrated the cross‐party, apolitical expressions of solidarity and concern to the people of Tasmania in these difficult days for them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to take the opportunity to inform the House that there will be a meeting of police ministers to discuss gun control issues on Friday 10 May. I myself will open the meeting and I will be putting certain proposals on behalf of the Commonwealth to that meeting. Those proposals will at a minimum include a proposal for an effective national registration of gun ownership in this country. They will also include a total ban throughout Australia on all automatic and semi-automatic weapons. Other proposals will be put as well.

The Commonwealth government will be contributing $200,000 to the appeal opened by Tasmanian television stations and already the subject of a contribution from the Tasmanian government. I have made clear to the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Rundle, that the full array of Commonwealth counselling services is available if they are needed.

I repeat the admiration of the federal government, of the state government and of all Australians for the splendid work done by the police and by the medical and paramedical services over the past few days in Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I support the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and in particular his remarks that went to expressions of appreciation for the extraordinarily good work that was done by the emergency services, by the police, by the medical services and that continues to be done by them in handling what is an extraordinary and terrible situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Both services we attended were most moving—the first one was not really a service but there was a wreath laying associated with it. There is no doubt at all that there is a tremendously and terribly shocked community in Tasmania. I think it is up to all of us to do what we can—we all have travel rights as parliamentarians—to associate ourselves directly with what has happened to our fellow citizens in Tasmania, to give them encouragement and to see the fortitude with which they are bearing their trial. They are tremendously conscious of anything that anyone else elsewhere in Australia does to identify with their period of great difficulty.

Of course, it is not just people in Australia who have been directly affected; also at the gathering were the people most directly affected, that is, families who had lost members or whose members had experienced injuries. That was tremendously moving as well.

The Prime Minister made some remarks about propositions to be put to the police ministers. He said that they were minimum propositions. The two that he announced we would absolutely endorse and we encourage him. All strength to his right arm as he uses it in whatever way he needs to in dealing with the states on this matter. He also announced a contribution to the appeal. We completely endorse that as well. He indicated that there may be other things that he wants to raise with the police ministers. If those matters could be in some way or another presented here in the House before he meets with them, that would be a good thing. If it is not possible to do that because he wants to take these matters more discreetly to those ministers, I completely understand that, but this is a matter where he might choose to find himself more broadly supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. During the election campaign the Department of Finance found a $1.2 billion dollar error in your election promises for which there was enough public detail to allow independent costings. It also found $3.3 billion worth of promises too vague to cost. Do Finance Department costings of your election commitments still leave a $1.2 billion error and a $3.3 billion `too vague to cost'? If not, what are now the costings and the assumptions on which they are based? Will you now release the revised advice to the public? Will you also release departmental advice to you on the costs of your promises provided when you assumed office?

—I ought to tell the Leader of the Opposition that advice from the Department of Finance and the Department of Treasury since the election has blown an $8 billion hole in his credibility. I cannot believe my luck.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. You would appreciate, Mr Speaker, that we would raise a point of relevance when there is a very direct question asked without answers being received.
—There is no point of order.

—I cannot believe my luck. He has had six weeks to work that out. What a question! What a terrific start! All I can say in conclusion to the Leader of the Opposition is: you will be hearing a lot from us about the way you deceived the Australian people.

BREAK.PARA: I take this opportunity of saying to the Leader of the Opposition that the day after the election I walked up from the Intercontinental Hotel to the Commonwealth office in Phillip Street—I think all Australians and particularly members of this House should understand this sequence of events—and I was handed by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet a booklet of documents, the blue book, that had been prepared for the incoming government. As he knows better than most on the other side, a like book had been prepared for him and for the former Prime Minister if he had been successful.

That book clearly spelt out the fiscal reality. It was available to me the day after the election and yet you and your former leader told the Australian public that it was too hard to assemble. You said it could not be done. I asked the former Prime Minister about this twice during the first debate and I asked him about this time without number on other occasions. I said that we would throw open to any kind of inspection and costing. My colleague the now Treasurer offered the services of his staff to visit the Department of Finance—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You laugh. You had all of the resources of the Treasury and the Department of Finance at your disposal, but what did you do? You chose to close your eyes. You chose not to ask the question. Every time you told the Australian people the information was not available, you knew that was wrong. Every time you told the Austral ian people that it was too hard to get it together, you knew that that was deceit. The fact that the information was available the day after the election demonstrates what a humbug you are on the question of fiscal credibility. If you think you have any credibility in this place asking me and the people on this side of the House about fiscal credibility, then I point out that there are eight billion reasons why you have no credibility to ask it.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Could we actually have an answer. This is the chap who gave us a $22 billion problem when we walked in. A 60c tax rate and $8 billion worth of tariffs were built into it. Could we have an answer to the question.
—The Leader of the Opposition is stretching a very long bow. I was under the impression the Prime Minister was winding up. Has the Prime Minister concluded his response?
—I have.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen speculation about what may or may not be in the August budget? Has the Prime Minister also seen speculation about whether or not the government will fulfil certain election commitments? What is the Prime Minister's reaction to this speculation and will the government be responding to every piece of guesswork which emerges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes. The answer to the second part of the question is that I can do little better on this occasion than draw upon the words of the new shadow Treasurer. On 28 February 1995 he had this to say in relation to a question about budget speculation:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . as I said yesterday, that to suggest that the government is going to introduce any new taxes on the tourism industry is nothing more than budget speculation and obviously neither I nor anybody else is going to be in the business of confirming or denying any particular element of budgetary speculation, not because to do so would be to reveal anything about that particular proposal, but to do so on any particular individual item immediately raises questions about multiple others . . .

In effect what he was saying was that he was not going to give a running commentary on every piece of budget speculation. Let me say that I am not going to do so either. The budget will be introduced and introduced well by the Treasurer in August.

Can I say very deliberately to the honourable member and to all honourable members that the new coalition government takes very seriously the commitments that were made to the Australian people in the lead up to the election. I believe that keeping faith with the Australian people is a very important element of restoring the process of trust in government that was almost totally destroyed by the now defeated Labor administration. The way in which the members of the Keating government systematically and cynically dismantled their election commitments immediately after they were elected in 1993, as apparently the now defeated former Prime Minister acknowledges, was one of the major reasons that they were so ignominiously defeated on 2 March this year.

The fact that the former finance minister, the now Leader of the Opposition, has left us with an $8 billion black hole makes the task that we have far more difficult. I want to say to the Australian people that I place enormous personal store and the members of my government place great collective store on keeping faith with the Australian people and meeting the commitments that were very much in the minds of the Australian people before the election.

I know there will be a lot of speculation—some of it will be mischievous; some of it will be natural. To those people who believe that in some way we are going to respond in a running commentary sense to every piece of speculation, I say they are wrong. We are not. Let me repeat the commitments that I have given since the election about the protection of the more vulnerable members of our society.

To those people who would try to scare the daylights out of vulnerable people in the Australian community, to those opposite and others in the community, I invite them to pay very careful attention to what I said in the speech I delivered to the Australian Council of Social Service in October of last year. I meant what I said in that speech. I meant it then. I meant it during the election campaign and I continue to mean it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of that answer there ought to be no problem for the Prime Minister to release the costings of his election promises which have nothing at all to do with the budget. Why can he not now release the costings of his election promises which will enable us and everybody else in the community to make a judgment about how likely he is to be able to hold to those undertakings?

—The Leader of the Opposition, very early in his term, is beating around rather aimlessly. Can I simply say to the Leader of the Opposition that anybody who comes into this parliament with the discredited record you have already developed on fiscal consistency has no capacity to demand anything of what this government will do—and you will not have your demands answered, thank you very much.
—My question is directed to the Treasurer. What is the Treasurer's response to media reports that there is no hole in the budget brought down for the current financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen media reports suggesting that in fact there is no hole in the budget.
—Of course there is no hole.

—And I hear brave frontbenchers on the other side echoing that statement. Of course, the author of that particular claim is the Leader of the Opposition—the Leader of the Opposition who has taken to denial, asserting that there is no hole in the budget for the 1996‐97 year. In fact, he is going so far as to try to suggest that the Treasury itself has not identified such a hole.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it entirely clear that on the day after the election and on the Monday thereafter the Secretary to the Treasury disclosed to the Prime Minister and to me the state of the accounts as forecast by Treasury for 1996‐97. They were put out not in a press release from the government. They were put out in a press release from the Treasury, signed off by the Treasury itself.

Let me make it entirely clear that, if any member of the then government before 2 March had asked for the figures, they would have received exactly the same figures—exactly the same figures. I am now told that, as early as September in the previous year, the joint economic forecasting group was warning the government that its budget would not be as bottom line as was said in the budget papers and there was a blow‐out on the cards for 1996‐97.

Faced with the central deceit of the 1996 election campaign, the Leader of the Opposition has now entered a mode of denial. He reminds one of the president of the Flat Earth Society saying, `I do not accept the world is round'—`I do not accept that there is a budget hole.'. The fact is that there is a budget position which this previous administration, this Labor administration, allowed to fester and which it refused to disclose to the Australian people.

Let me make it entirely clear that correcting that position, making good on the Australian accounts and making up for the failure of the Labor administration will be a first priority of this government—and it starts with a basic honesty about the position, an honesty which no amount of denial from the Leader of the Opposition can cover up.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Treasurer is so clear‐cut on that $8 billion, which must be the subject of public debate, will he release the figures that go to the costings of his election promises, which would suggest on the face of it a starting point deficit somewhere north of about $4 billion of that $8 billion? If that is his concern, surely the public is entitled to a purview of information that you already have on your costings and that ought to be made available to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it entirely clear that, when the government announces its budget, the full costings will be disclosed in that budget, as is always the case.
—Why not now?
—I will tell you why not now: because we are not releasing the budget in May. We are doing an August 20 budget, in case you had not figured it out.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say in relation to these costings that the costings debacle of this the worst Minister for Finance in any administration since Federation was a situation where the Department of Finance was essentially called in to do political work during the campaign, and he knows it; where the Department of Finance came back and essentially disputed your figures in relation to costings.

The fact was, when the Department of Finance came back, you who had supposedly discovered a $4.9 billion hole were severely embarrassed. When it came back and it asked for further information at the very time we were offering to give it further information, you declined, you refused, you would not allow it.

When the costings were finally released, let us all remember they were released with one of those shabby documents on the front—not done by the Department of Finance but done by the minister's political officers. Let us also remember that it was the embarrassment about the failure of your costings in relation to the coalition that led to the forged letters affair.

Remember the day when the costings had completely fallen apart and it was the Treasurer, embarrassed by the failure, who produced documents about as reliable as the costings. They just happened to be under forged signatures. The high point of Labor Party accountability during the election campaign! This was the finance minister who on 1 February said this during the election campaign:
We're operating in surplus and our projections are for surpluses in the future.
On the same day he stated:
As far as we're concerned, the Treasury estimates that we had in connection with the last budget—and they were Treasury estimates—they stand for good and we stand by them.

Let me tell you, at that time the Treasury estimates were showing an underlying deficit for 1996‐97 of the order of $8 billion difference from what you were showing. Let me say you would have known it. You either knew it or you refused to find it out. You either knew it or you refused to ask. On these questions the previous Labor administration stands condemned and they stand condemned for one reason: the truth is now out and the truth has caught them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen reports that there is some opposition to the introduction of a charter of budget honesty? What is he doing to answer such opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The object of the charter of budget honesty, a measure that we announced during the election campaign and a measure which we will introduce as a government, is to ensure by legislation that government accounts are clean, transparent and disclose to the Australian people the true state of the books.

ANSWER.PARA: We would hope that there would be bipartisan support for a charter of budget honesty on both sides of the House. It was for that reason that I was intrigued to read in the West Australian newspaper on Saturday, 20 April a story by Randall Markey of an interview with the now Leader of the Opposition. It said:
He rejected Mr Howard's promise to introduce a charter of budget honesty requiring the government to throw open its books before an election to avoid political manipulation.

But what really interested me was the reason he gave as to why he was against the charter of budget honesty. The Leader of the Opposition said, `The Treasury is straight; the politicians are not.' A moment of self-realisation from the Leader of the Opposition—`The Treasury is straight; the politicians are not.' During the whole of the campaign, at his disposal, at his fingertips, was the opportunity to ring the Treasury and to have the Treasury disclose to him what it disclosed to the Prime Minister and me on the Monday after the election. He refused to do it. Instead, he went throughout that campaign maintaining that there was a surplus and that there would be a surplus for years to come.

BREAK.PARA: It is to stop that kind of behaviour, it is to make sure that that kind of deceit is not practised in the future, that this government will introduce by legislation a charter of budget honesty so that the Australian people know the situation before an election begins and so that elections can be conducted on the basis of the facts and not on the basis of deceit, as governments in the past have sought to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a further question to the Prime Minister on the charter of budget honesty. Is it not a fact that one of the arguments that you presented for the charter of budget honesty, and the context in which you presented it, was that it would provide an opportunity for a full costing of opposition and government promises against the figures revealed in the so-called charter of budget honesty? In the light of that, why will you not release now costings of your election promises—given to you in that blue book by the departments, which you now admit, obviously, you received the moment you got into office—and allow the Australian public to share whether or not there is a $4 billion hole in your promises?

—The answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question is in two parts. The answer to the first part of the question is that the charter of budget honesty is to stop anybody in future `doing a Beazley'. The answer to the second part of the question is that the budget will be brought down on budget night—on 20 August.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Why is there a need to reform Australia's industrial relations system? What are the problems with Australia's industrial relations system which necessitate the government undertaking major reforms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for his question. The answer to the question of what is wrong with the existing system would take longer than the time we have been given for question time. There are many features of the existing system which obviously cry out for significant reform. The existing system was one of the factors which led to the worst recession for 60 years—a product of the economic incompetence of the previous government, including the current Leader of the Opposition. Over the 13 years of the previous administration, many Australians have seen falling living standards instead of higher living standards—something which we on this side believe Australians should be able to expect from the Australian economy—under the current industrial relations system. In respect of jobs, the current system fails to give people the opportunity to make a contribution to themselves, to their families and to our wider society by enjoying a job. No more is that apparent than it is for young people. It is a national disgrace that we have very high levels of youth unemployment in Australia. In some parts of regional Australia, youth unemployment rates of 30, 40 and 50 per cent are, sadly, far too common.

ANSWER.PARA: Given the challenge that this presents to the government, we have announced, and did so prior to the election, a set of comprehensive reforms to the industrial relations system. Included in those reforms will be a guarantee of the basic civil liberties of Australians at work—that is, the basic civil liberty to make a decision on whether or not they want to be in a union. We intend to enhance the right of people—to give them the choice—to decide which union they are in.

We are also intending to introduce with our package a set of reforms that will ensure that parties to agreements and those covered by awards will be expected to meet their obligations under those agreements and under those awards. Furthermore, in respect of third parties, we will be introducing effective secondary boycott provisions, restoring to the Trade Practices Act provisions based on the old sections 45D and 45E.

Lastly, as an indication of the problems, I do not think anybody could reasonably deny the significant problems that have arisen as a result of the previous government's introduction of a new part to the Industrial Relations Act in respect of unfair dismissals. That system has been responsible for a lot of people being unable to obtain work. Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales—a Labor Premier—said that the existing system is in fact a disincentive for employers to give people a job.

We intend to change that system. It is going to be a fair system to both employers and employees. The great thing about that system is that it will give people a chance of a job, which was denied by the previous administration. The sum total is that we do have a significant package. We have been consulting very widely on it. It is aimed at giving people a chance of a job and boosting living standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. Can he tell the parliament, supreme as it is over the executive, whether his department has prepared the costings of the coalition's pre‐election promises and the means by which they are to be paid for and, if so, when he proposes to table those in the parliament, consistent with the charter of budget honesty? If he is not prepared to do any of that, can he tell us whether it is his position that such an enterprise is unnecessary because, so far as he is concerned, he is not bound by any election commitment made before he entered parliament? Does he recall saying in this respect, as reported in the Australian Financial Review on 19 April, that he was prepared to break election commitments and he was particularly well placed to do so as finance minister because `I haven't got the baggage of those election commitments'? Is that still his position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Those opposite did not listen to the Australian people before 2 March. They did not listen to all the signs that were out there that they were out of control, that they had no care, that they were mismanaging the economy, that they were simply walking away from their roots and that they were leading Australia down the path to wilderness. Today, they have demonstrated to me in no uncertain terms that they are not prepared to listen to the Prime Minister or the Treasurer who have made it abundantly clear that the budget will be delivered in August—and all will be revealed at that time.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Governor‐General said yesterday, this government will proceed with prudence and responsibility, something the Leader of the Opposition knew nothing about in the role he played prior to 2 March. Let me also make it abundantly clear that the promises that were made by all members of the government, all who had a responsibility leading up to 2 March, bind me as much as they bind anybody else. I stand by the process that will deliver prudent and responsible government in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. The Deputy Prime Minister will be aware of claims that Asian leaders would not deal with the coalition in government. Given those claims, can the Deputy Prime Minister inform the House what progress has been made in implementing the coalition's trade policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This was one of the most shabby claims made during the course of the election campaign. The Labor Party put partisan interests ahead of Australia's national interest in a way for which they should have been ashamed. I thank the member for Parkes for his question because it allows me to say that the coalition government hit the ground running. Firstly, there were excellent talks between Prime Minister Howard and Prime Minister Bolger and with Prime Minister Mahathir in the first few weeks of the coalition government—a very constructive dialogue opened up by our Prime Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, Minister Downer moved quickly to cover a lot of ground and made very successful visits to Indonesia, Singapore and Thailand, meeting with their heads of government and other ministers in the course of taking up that portfolio and building an effective dialogue with Asian leaders. Thirdly, the Treasurer, in the second weekend of government, went to Kyoto in Japan to meet his APEC economic minister counterparts, once again opening up effective and constructive dialogue with that important regional organisation. I went to the Philippines and met with President Ramos and others.

The key point is that we also moved in another practical way in trade policy. We announced in January that we would be appointing an ambassador to APEC and the government has done that already. Ambassador Peter Grey accompanied me to Manila two weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was doing exactly the same job before the election, as you well know. This is cosmetic rubbish.

—I remind the former foreign minister that it was a whole lot more than that. It was a constructive step to deliver our commitment with regard to APEC. It registered with the Philippines government at several levels, including with President Ramos. I remind you further, lest you have forgotten since you left the portfolio, it is the Philippines government that is hosting APEC this year. The summit will be in Manila and Subic Bay in November. How dare you add your voice to the Labor claims, which were very grubby and partisan.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, during the course of these visits, again as part of building an effective dialogue with Asia, we took some practical steps. I was pleased to be able to initial a bilateral agreement between Australia and the Philippines which will reactivate trade between Australia and the Philippines in certain categories of fruit and vegetables, something you had done little about during your occupancy of the treasury bench.

I say once again that our relations with Asia ought to be, by and large, of a bipartisan nature—people on both sides of the parliament have been committed to that. You did yourselves little service in Asia or Australia with those ugly claims launched by your former leader during the course of the election campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the line of questioning to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer on the subject of charters of budget honesty, I ask the Prime Minister whether he recollects the following quotation:

BREAK.PARA: I have been told that there was a possible figure of $8 billion but until the final figuring was worked out, the final figuring was in fact given to me the evening before.
That was during the 1983 election.
But in any event, Laurie, that was a projection of what the scene might have been. You know as well as I do that the projections you get out of our forward estimates are things that can change.

Do you recollect that quote from when you were dealing with a $22 billion budget hole, a fact that you did not reveal to the Australian public and which you also said was something on which forward estimates would be notoriously unreliable and therefore not worth having? What has changed since then?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes, I do recollect that quote. The answer to the rest of the question is that it makes not one iota of difference to what has already been said.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister would be aware of the terrible injuries and deaths inflicted on innocent victims in South-East Asia and other places caused by anti-personnel mines. During the election campaign a number of my constituents approached me about what we might do. I ask the minister to advise this House about what Australia as a nation intends to do about achieving a global ban on the production, stockpiling, use and transfer of such mines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Mallee for that question. I know the member is very concerned about this issue. I think it is probably true to say the issue of land mines is one that is of concern to all Australians. I have received, both in opposition and in government, an enormous amount of correspondence from people urging Australia to take something of a leadership position in the context of the inhumane weapons convention review conference, which is now under way.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of in particular the community concern expressed on this issue, after the election I called for a review of the previous government's position on landmines, in cooperation with my colleague the Minister for Defence, with a view to ensuring that we establish a constructive position at the inhumane weapons convention review conference. As a result of that review, the government announced on 15 April that Australia would support a total ban on the production, stockpiling, use and transfer of landmines and that for our part as a country we would implement a unilateral suspension on the operational use of landmines.

This took the position of the Australian government considerably further than the position of the previous government, as the member for Holt is only too well aware. The previous government's position was a somewhat confused, vacillating position. The confusion of the previous government was brought about by one simple fact: there could never be any agreement reached between the then foreign minister and Senator Robert Ray, the then defence minister. The squabble between the two, which I know the member for Holt would well remember—we find out about these things quite quickly after an election—left Australia with a position which was by no means one of leadership.

As a result of the position that we had taken, a number of countries have followed in our wake—not least of which are Germany, New Zealand and, to a limited extent, the United Kingdom. I believe the leadership position that Australia took is one that has changed the whole dynamics of this debate internationally. As a result of that position we have a better chance of achieving the sorts of outcomes that we want to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Americans have come to you, Alexander, have they?

—The member for Brisbane intervenes. He is just one of two Queensland Labor Party members left in this House, and he is the leader of the two! I must not take up too much time of the House, but I conclude with a point about the United States because the member mentioned the United States—and I am glad he did. Yes, the United States has been consulting very closely with the Australian government on this issue. The United States government is now reviewing the position that it held at the conference last year.

BREAK.PARA: I am very glad to say that the Australian government has had a very constructive input and, more than that, many leading figures in the United States have congratulated Australia on its position and have recognised the humane position we have and, above all, the leadership role Australia is playing now in the inhumane weapons convention review conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Do you accept the assessment of Syntec—not exactly a Labor front organisation—that, given last week's excellent inflation and wages growth figures, if Labor was still in office, with the accord still intact, falls in official rates would now be occurring? If you do not accept that assessment, why not—without bluster, evasion or equivocation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It always amazed us that Prime Minister Keating used to call the Senate unrepresentative swill. Let me say this: we have heard this claim made by the shadow Treasurer on doorstops. I must say I find it an extraordinary claim. Members of the House will recall that, between August and December of 1994, official interest rates were lifted in three bites by 2¾ per cent, and they stayed there and have not moved since—for some 18 months.

ANSWER.PARA: The claim of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Holt, is that after 18 months if only those opposite had been allowed to hang on to office for another four weeks those rates would have fallen, that he has been robbed, that they were just beaten by the bell, as it were, in their failure in relation to official rates over the past 18 months. They are the football team that, if they could have played for another three minutes, would have brought home the victory with another six-goal finish.

I make it entirely clear, as Treasurers have in the past, that it will not be the business of this government to speculate on movements in interest rates. We have made it clear that we expect the Reserve Bank and the Reserve Bank Governor to operate independently and to do so in the conduct of monetary policy.

BREAK.PARA: We have also made it clear that the government must play its part to ensure that it is creating conditions which are conducive to a lower interest rate regime. Let it be entirely clear that the government's proposal, a proposal to bring the budget into balance over the next two years, is directed towards that aim. If this opposition attempts to defeat or frustrate that central economic policy goal, it will do so knowingly and knowing that it is directing higher interest rates and pressure on higher rates to the Australian community.
Let me make it entirely clear—there is no clearer indictment of the failures of Labor administration—that the Governor of the Reserve Bank in March said:

Next year will mark the sixth year of economic recovery. In terms of the economic cycle we should already be in an underlying surplus and, in terms of our large current account deficit and low private saving, a substantial surplus at that.

It is a mark of failure—the absolute failure of this failed Labor administration—that six years into economic recovery, a recovery which they boasted about, they were planning to deliver an underlying deficit of $8 billion for 1996-97, and they did not have the decency to admit it. The proof is in the Treasury's own releases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Table it.

—I am quite happy to table it; thank you. I am invited by the honourable member for Prospect to table the Treasury's release, and I will. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to study it very carefully indeed.
—All of it!

—I will table all of it, because this other part is even more informative: it is my own press release. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to read that three times before bed! You will get even more illumination in relation to that. I direct you back to the comments of the Reserve Bank Governor, who nailed your failure: nothing could be more important in relation to taking pressure off interest rates than repairing the budget balance. That is what this government is committed to doing.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I ask the minister: is it a fact that over 10 per cent of Australian adults have inadequate literacy and numeracy skills? What is this government doing to address this serious educational and social issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As all members of the House know, one of the great failures of the outgoing Labor government was its failure to do anything effective in relation to youth unemployment, which, for teenage full-time unemployment, remains at the level it was at when your Working Nation program was introduced. There are many reasons for this failure, but one of the major reasons for this failure was your total inability to address the literacy needs of young Australians and of those young people coming out of school and into the work force. Far too many young people are leaving school these days after year 10 without the skills that are most essential to jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: On 18 April Senator Vanstone and I met with a reference group of employers and employer organisations. The issue at the top of their agenda was the issue of literacy. They know that the greatest barrier to providing jobs to young Australians today is the fact that far too many of them are coming out of school without these absolutely essential skills.

The Labor government failed over the whole of its 13-year period in office to effectively help young people who are suffering literacy and numeracy deficits. It is not as if the problem was not recognised. Indeed the honourable member for Batman, when he was the President of the ACTU—and normally the previous government jumped to the instructions of the President of the ACTU—said six years ago: more than one million adult Australians were unable to read a simple sentence in English, understand simple telephone dialling instructions, fill out basic application forms or follow instructions for medication or product use.

PARA.BREAK: That was six years ago, and now nothing further has been done to alleviate this problem. When the states introduced their popula tion testing in primary schools—the years when those literacy skills can best be acquired—did they get any support from the government? No, they did not. There was a deafening silence from the Labor Party. We are going to change that. The states will have the full support of this government in their population testing at primary school level—grades 3 and 5 in particular—to identify and effectively help those young people who presently are slipping through the net and are not picking up those skills.

ANSWER.PARA: We also regard it as essential that after 13 years of neglect there has been no effort to establish proper baseline data on which Australians can assess the current state of literacy and the effectiveness of literacy policies. Despite widespread concern among parents, employers and the community no such study was made during the whole of the 13 years of the Labor government. The last such study was made in 1980 under a coalition government.

Now that the coalition has been returned, we will once again have a national English literacy survey. I have already written to the state governments seeking their support for the conduct of this survey. This survey will provide a clear view for the first time in 13 years of the state of English literacy levels amongst Australian students in years 3 and 5. It will enable us to target resources effectively. It will enable us to establish national benchmarks so that the Australian people, parents and the community, can assess whether or not government policies to help Australians acquire literacy skills are working.

Literacy is far too important to be left to fads or chance, or sacrificed on the altar of partisan politics and interest group and lobby group politics as it has for the last 13 years. It has been said that language is the most important technology that we possess. It is time that we made sure that this technology is provided to all Australian children at the years when they are best able to acquire it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training a question about youth unemployment. Is it a fact that when you left office in 1983 the number of young people looking for full-time work was 150,000? Is it a fact that when you came into office a couple of months ago the number of young people looking for full-time work was 88,000?

—These sound like the sorts of numbers that the former minister for employment used to cast around. We know that he is no good at numbers so he might like to ask the Speaker to help him with this. You have totally neglected that group of young people coming out of school in the teenage years. When you introduced the Working Nation program, teenage unemployment amongst those seeking full-time work was 28 per cent. It is essentially at exactly that figure today. You have failed young Australians; you have betrayed a generation; and now effective action will be taken by the new government.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will recall having previously expressed concern about the plight of homeless youth in Australia. What action is the new government taking to ensure that all those who are best able to assist these street children are able to do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When I addressed the Australian Council of Social Services in October last year as Leader of the Opposition, as well as putting down some broad approaches to the welfare safety net and the approach of the coalition in government to the welfare safety net, I announced that I would have a pilot program to tackle, specifically, one aspect of youth homelessness that caused a great deal of concern to a lot of people in the community. That was whether the youth homeless allowance was too freely and easily available and whether, in the process of the allowance being made available, the legitimate roles of families were not being properly catered for.

ANSWER.PARA: I believed then, and I and the government continue to believe, that there is a very important role to be played by the voluntary welfare organisations in the process of assessing entitlement. I promised that the new government would establish a series of pilot programs to see whether, through the early intervention of voluntary welfare agencies, a better assessment process about long-term entitlements could be established.

Pursuant to that commitment, within a couple of weeks of being elected I convened a meeting of the leaders of the major voluntary welfare organisations in Australia, including the Salvation Army, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Society of St Vincent de Paul and the Anglican Care in Queensland. That group of people broadly endorsed the government's approach. I am pleased to announce today the terms of reference and the membership of a prime ministerial youth homeless task force that I have established out of that meeting to examine how those pilot programs might be put together. That task force is going to be chaired by Captain David Eldridge, who is the chairman of the Salvation Army's eastern division in Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good choice.

—Yes, he is a good choice. I appreciate the endorsement from the Manager of Opposition Business. Captain Eldridge has had many years of experience in providing services for young homeless people and their families. The principal, but not the sole, object of this exercise is to see whether through the use of the expertise of the voluntary agencies we can get a better steer as to whether a young person who claims to be entitled to the homeless benefit ought to get that benefit on an ongoing basis.

ANSWER.PARA: The pilots will operate on the basis of a person getting the homeless allowance for a provisional period of six weeks and then the person will be taken, in a sense, into a case management or care situation by an individual agency. That agency will see whether any reconciliation with the family can be established. They will counsel, talk to and assess the young person and, after a period, they will make a recommendation to the department about whether there will be an ongoing benefit granted. The final decision will still be made by the department.

I think—I may be wrong and the outcome of the pilots will demonstrate it—that there is a role for these agencies. I think they are the best agencies in Australia when it comes to assessing at the coalface. I do not think any agencies come within a bull's roar of organisations like the Salvation Army and the Society of St Vincent de Paul. They bring to the assessment of welfare issues great compassion, but they also bring a hard‐headedness to it, because they know how hard it is to raise money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you give them the same resources as we gave them?
—The honourable member interjects, but we have no intention of asking these organisations to embark on these pilot programs without adequate resources.
—Will you give them the same resources as we gave them?

—Do you really want me to go into the detail of some of the funding that you gave to voluntary welfare organisations? You might be a little embarrassed because there was something of a decline in them. I am delighted to announce the formation of the task force today. Fuller details will be provided in a press statement. It is an important, sensible and practical initiative to see whether the resources and the expertise of these organisations cannot be more effectively harnessed with appropriate levels of government assistance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I am assuming that the minister knows the importance of the agricultural industry and the mining industry to export earnings and that he knows how important export earnings are. I ask the minister whether he is aware of the devastating consequences that would accrue to the marginal areas of these industries if they were subjected to an excise on diesel fuel—that is, category 1 diesel oil. If so, is he taking any steps to make sure that this does not occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I begin by making the observation that, unlike the previous administration, we really do understand the importance of regional Australia and the industries out there which contribute so much to the nation's economic wealth and its export performance. In case those opposite had not noticed, they were resoundingly rejected by the people who live out there and who participate in those industries.

ANSWER.PARA: The beginning of the task of restoration of the fortunes of the bush lie in sound economic management and sensible industrial relations reform—the things that your mob would not take on board. The first task is to address the great big black hole which the current Leader of the Opposition left behind. I will say one thing for him: I always felt he looked a little embarrassed when he was trying to defend the indefensible. There was a bit of conscience left there. He always looked worried and uncomfortable with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not much.
—No, not much, but it was there.
—Don't overstate it.

—No, I wouldn't overstate it, but it was there. I will give him credit for that much. Let us make it quite plain that you left us with an appalling problem and we have got a big task—restoring the Commonwealth budget to surplus by real reform. I simply say to you now, in common with what you have already been told, that I am not going to speculate on the work of the ERC. I am not going to encourage speculation. But while we are at it, I close by making this point: next time, why not address the question to the appropriate minister, who may very well choose to make a comment, and that is the minister for customs.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Would you tell this House the advantages to employees and employers of award simplification?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Award simplification is a very good idea. In fact, the advantages of it are, very simply, that it gives our businesses the chance to employ more people and to pay them more. To pay people more and to give people the chance of higher wages in the future are obviously a key part of what we want to do. This has been missing in the industrial relations system in recent years. One of the legacies of the previous government is that, when you take everything into account, many people were paid less and their living standards fell as a result.

ANSWER.PARA: In a sense, the idea of award simplification is not just shared by those on this side. In fact, when those on the other side were in government, on a number of occasions they said, `Yes, it's a good idea, there are real advantages in doing so.' We give them credit for saying so. The real problem with those on the other side is they were never actually able to implement such a process of award simplification. The previous Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said in April 1993:

Let me describe the model of industrial relations we are working towards. It is a model which places primary emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards provided by arbitration tribunals.

It is a model under which arbitrated awards and arbitrated wage increases would be there only as a safety net. This safety net would not be intended to prescribe the actual conditions of work of most employees but only to catch those unable to make workplace agreements with employers. Over time, the safety net would inevitably become simpler. We would have fewer awards with fewer clauses.

That is the one thing on which I agreed with the previous Prime Minister. The sad truth is that, after 13 years of Labor, they were never able to implement that policy. In fact, it was people like the member for Batman when he was President of the ACTU who vetoed sensible reform that could give people the chance of a job and higher wages in the future.

There is a new government. We are intent on giving people a chance of a job. We are intent on giving people a chance to enjoy higher pay. We will be introducing in our package a means by which that can happen. It will be done under the supervision of the commission. It will be done on the basis that people are guaranteed their wages. It will be done fairly. It will be done in a reasonable way. I believe it is one of the many things that can be achieved that will give people a much fairer go in the industrial relations system in the future.

BREAK.PARA: I asked my department to pull out a couple of average awards as they are today, as a legacy of these people opposite. I got a couple. One is in the motor vehicle industry area and it has 202 pages. I have got another one here which has 260 pages—that is for the meat industry. The meat industry is one area where, if we could get some sensible reforms, we can protect people's pay and in fact give them a chance of more pay in the future. We can create more jobs and boost our export income, which will start to fix Australia's massive and chronic debt with which you people left us. So is it a good idea? It is a great idea. It is just a pity that you people never had what it takes to give us the leadership to make these ideas happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I noted with interest your comment a minute ago that you were not going to speculate about budget outcomes. I refer you to your comments on the Channel Nine Sunday program a couple of weeks ago when you ruled out cuts to the diesel fuel rebate for the farming sector, describing fuel as `the lifeblood of our primary industries'. Will you confirm those comments? Will you also confirm that they apply to the mining industry?

—I thank the honourable member for his entirely predictable attempt to get me to speculate. I have indicated clearly that I am a member of the ERC. I am going to play the game with a straight bat. I will neither engage in speculation nor encourage it. You should go out to the bush and try to justify what you got up to during your 13 years of abysmal failure of policy for rural Australia.
—I address my question to the Prime Minister. What are the consequences for living standards of all Australians if the budget deficit is not addressed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what very clearly emerges from this first question time of the new government is the very strange approach of the Leader of the Opposition. He is into a complete denial situation. He is really denial‐squared. The first piece of denial is that it really does not exist. That is the first bit. The second bit of denial is that, if it does exist, it does not really matter.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the things I think ought to be burnt into the consciousness of every member of the now defeated Labor government is that, for the 13 years they were in office, unarguably the area of their greatest economic failure was that they gave to this country the worst current account deficit in the Western world—and that is what it was in 1995.

No matter what other things they may talk about—and I have never been one to say that every single thing that the former government did in the economic area was wrong; I have never done that, and I will not be changing that approach in the future—can I say to the Leader of the Opposition: the one thing you got comprehensively wrong every year, and you left it in an absolutely shambolic state when you left government, was the current account deficit.

There are two reasons why we have a big current account deficit and a large foreign debt. The first reason is that we are badly in need of micro-economic reform. Until that is tackled, you will not start to reduce the current account deficit. The second reason, as you well know and even I think the shadow Treasurer knows—and anybody with any economic literacy on the front bench of the opposition knows—is that we have an appallingly low level of national savings.

Now those two things have to be tackled. You know as well as do I that, unless we tackle the budget deficit, unless measures are taken to reduce the size of the budget deficit, unless we have an honest approach to the budget deficit through a charter of honesty, we are never going to boost our national savings. So every time you deny that there is a budget deficit problem, every time you deny that even if there is a problem it does not matter—every time you engage in that double denial, you are demonstrating a complete indifference to fundamental economic problems that you yourself asserted existed when you were in government.

BREAK.PARA: Do not think you win any respect from anybody anywhere in the community by repudiating propositions that you intellectually know are sound propositions. One of the problems with people like you, Mr Leader of the Opposition, when you have been round for a while, is that there are a few other people who also have been around for a while who remember what you have said. One or two of them on occasions have remembered. I have remembered what you have said, and I have remembered it very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we remember you.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: New Format for Bills and Acts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Before attending to the formal statement, Mr Speaker, since this is the first opportunity I have had since your election to speak at the dispatch box, may I offer you my congratulations on your election.

SPEECH.PARA: The ministerial statement relates to a new format for bills and acts. The format currently in use for bills introduced into this parliament has evolved gradually since 1901. It has been only in the last 10 years or so, however, that attention has been paid to the effect on readers of the format in which legislation is set out. This has happened in the context of a growing community expectation that legislation that affects people ought to be accessible to those people.

The accessibility of legislation has several aspects. First, of course, the text of the legislation needs to be comprehensible to its intended audience. As well, legislation needs to be physically accessible to its intended audience—that is, people need access to up‐to‐date versions of current legislation, whether in the form of reprints of acts or electronic databases containing consolidated legislation.

For those who still use printed copies of legislation—which, of course, includes members of this parliament—the page design and layout of legislation also affect its accessibility. Document design is now recognised as a matter which can have a significant impact on the comprehensibility of documents and on how effectively documents communicate information. With this in mind, the Office of Parliamentary Counsel has undertaken a project to improve the design and layout of bills, which of course will also impact on the design and layout of acts.

The result of this project is a new format, which has been adopted by the office for future bills. The main features of the new format are these: there is a substantial increase in the amount of `white space' on each page. This makes the pages look less forbidding, and this in turn contributes to the reader's confidence in dealing with the text. Running headers are used on the top outside corner of each page. The inclusion of section numbers in the running headers will make searching for particular provisions easier. The inclusion of chapter, part and division headings in the running headers will make it easier for readers to interpret individual provisions in context.

Section and subsection numbers are separated out from the text, to make searching for particular provisions easier. Vertical spacing, variable font sizes and different margins give visual clues to the hierarchical relationships between different elements of the text. The text of bills will no longer be right‐justified. The use of a `ragged' right‐hand margin makes text easier to read because it means that the spacing between words is the same in each line, rather than varied to ensure a straight right‐hand margin. All bills will contain a table of contents. Among other things, the table will show all acts amended or repealed by the bill. The first page of a bill will now be a cover page including the long title. The table of contents will start on the inside cover page.

Several bills were introduced in the last parliament in experimental formats. Now that the new format is settled, it will be used for almost all bills introduced from now on. The new format will also be adopted for reprints of existing acts. There will be a longer transitional period for reprints, because it will take some time to convert all existing electronic versions of acts into the new formats.

I would like to thank a number of people who advised the Office of Parliamentary Counsel during the development of the new formats. These include: the clerks of both houses of this parliament, the Tax Law Improvement Project and the Corporations Law Simplification Unit—in particular the communications experts working with each of those groups—the Australian Government Publishing Service and the Communication Research Institute of Australia.

Those of us who are familiar with the current forms of Commonwealth legislation will need some time to get used to the new formats. However, I am confident that these formats represent a genuine contribution to the accessibility of Commonwealth legislation.

The work of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel goes relatively unnoticed, but in my view the Parliamentary Counsel perform the role of unsung heroes and heroines in the legislative process. While there are some people who have criticisms of the drafting from time to time, on most occasions there is none and the silence that goes with it is not really an appropriate recognition of the work done by Hilary Penfold and her officers. I present the following paper:
