INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The impact of interest rates and Australia's economic outlook of the Government's decision to abandon the Accord and wages policy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —If the government had not abandoned the accord and wages policy as it has, there would be no reasonable doubt that we would be looking right now at a significant reduction in interest rates—one that home buyers need and deserve; one that business would enormously welcome as a further incentive to invest; and one that would be tremendously welcomed by those unemployed men, women and youngsters around the country who are hanging on a further stimulus to economic activity to get them back into the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear from everything that the Reserve Bank has been saying in recent weeks that we are not going to see an interest rate reduction right now. Why not? Because there is significant uncertainty about the future movement of wages growth in present circumstances and whether that will be consistent with the achievement of the underlying target rate, about which everyone agrees, of inflation of two to three per cent.

Why is there, in turn, that uncertainty? Because the coalition has torn up the accord, because it has abandoned wages policy as a crucial instrument of economic policy management in this country and because it has created a climate of conflict and confrontation with the trade union movement—a movement which, if the accord had been maintained, would have been absolutely committed allies in the economic management of this country.

It is not just the Australian Labor Party that is saying all this. Virtually every significant economic commentator in recent days and weeks has nominated uncertainty over wages growth as the key influence on future monetary policy. Syntec—which I said during question time is not a Labor front organisation; we all know that—has been the most explicit of all commentators in this respect, saying in the Australian of 25 April, just last week:
The opposition is right in saying now that under a Labor Government falls in official interest rates would be occurring.
This is not just out of a clear blue sky so far as Syntec is concerned. It made the point weeks earlier in a corporate brief to its clients on 1 April. It stated:

The cyclical picture in this Brief suggests that if Labor had regained office in a setting of wage‐ restraint embrace with the unions, Australian rates would have fallen soon after the election. Such is the tension between the Coalition and the unions, however, that that is not in prospect.
Again, talking about the government, Syntec said on 12 April:
A Government without the need to keep the labour market suppressed enough to deny the unions their wages push would be looking for an interest rate cut about now.
A Labor Government with any sort of post-election Accord would have been legitimately looking for a cut in interest rates.

That is the judgment of the financial community as articulated by an organisation which has traditionally been no friend of ours. It is simply making an objective judgment as it sees it about the condition of the economy and the condition of the policy environment now prevailing.

By 25 April, this judgment had been very much reinforced for the entire financial community by two sets of figures which confirmed that we were absolutely on track as a country in meeting our growth and unemployment reduction objectives. Inflation, you will recall from the figures last week, was confirmed at decreasing, so far as the normal headline rate is concerned, from 5.1 per cent to 3.7 per cent for the 12 months to March—with the underlying rate, which most policy makers regard as a bit more crucial, running at just 3.3 per cent but universally expected to fall below three per cent later this year.

The second set of figures to come out last week related to wages growth. That was confirmed as having come back to a remarkably low 4.2 per cent—absolutely consistent with the accord target, and with every reason to expect that, had the accord remained in place, that target would continue to be met. All this emerged and these figures came out in the context of an economy with an overall growth rate currently running at three per cent—the highest amongst the major OECD economies, and that is something to be very pleased about—even at the bottom of our business cycle.

Putting all that together, conditions were exactly right for an interest rate reduction. There was no need to fear overheating of the economy—inflation was down, wages growth was subdued and the accord was in place as at 2 March to keep things that way. At the same time, the economy was running at one per cent less growth than it needed to be running—that is, around four per cent rather than its present three per cent—to get the assault on unemployment back on the road. We all know that if we are really going to make a big impact or a significant net impact on unemployment we have to get the growth rate up from three per cent, where it is now, to where it has been for the last three years, which is four per cent.

The only reason that reduction has not already happened is, as I intimated previously, that the Reserve Bank of Australia is nervous, and understandably very nervous, about what the future wage growth will be and whether, in the absence of the accord and in the whole moderate social wage compensation strategy that is associated with the accord, it can be down around 4½ per cent, which is where it needs to be held if we are going to maintain inflation at that underlying rate of between two and three per cent. The Reserve Bank is concerned that in the new political environment, after 2 March, where the accord has been torn up and where wages policy has been abandoned as an instrument of economic management, wages growth will not now be able to be sustained at the level which has been achieved under the accord and which has clearly been demonstrably achieved over the last six months.

There is no point in saying, as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) will undoubtedly bellow in his reply, that the budgetary circumstances have changed all this. It is no good talking about inflation, wages growth and growth of the economy as a whole as at 2 March and then saying, `We now have a big deficit problem to contend with.' It is no good saying that the prospect of a deficit next year—if there is no further revision; we expect there will be in growth numbers to change that figure—has removed any possible case for a cut in rates now.

The point is this: there is simply no natural and automatic trade‐off between budget cuts and interest rate reductions. In fact, if the government's budget cuts involve, as seems inevitable if these targets are to be met—and certainly we heard nothing from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) or any of the other ministers today to suggest otherwise—the slashing of social programs in areas like health, education, housing and child care, then interest rates are much more likely to rise than to fall.

Why do I say that? Simply this: in that budgetary environment, in that policy environment, workers will seek higher wages than they would otherwise have been minded to seek in order to compensate for cuts in essential social services. Faster wages growth, not fully backed by productivity improvements—and it is difficult to see that it possibly could be backed by productivity improvements in the context I am describing—means higher inflation and that means not lower interest rates but, of course, higher interest rates.

The only chance of a linkage that I can see between government budgetary policy and lower interest rates is that, if this government succeeds in its slash and burn of some $8 billion worth of savings over the next couple of years, the contractionary impact of all that on the economy will be such that we will desperately need interest rate cuts in order to restore the level of economic activity back to where we are now. That is the only rational connection I can see between the budget cuts enterprise and interest rate cuts. Otherwise all the pressures are running the other way.

But, putting aside all that speculation, just look at what the financial community is now saying. Even after taking full account of all these budget scenarios that are running around, the overwhelming view of private sector economists at the moment is that you will not see an interest rate cut at all in the Australian economy. In fact, the overwhelming view is that the next move in interest rates, whenever it occurs, six months, nine months out, is going to be up, not down.

So that is the first economic return this government has delivered to the Australian people since the election. The first economic return, the first economic benefit, we have had from them is the loss of otherwise almost certain interest rate cuts right here and now. You have lost it; you have blown it for the Australian people. You have blown it for home buyers. You have blown it for small business. You have blown it for the unemployed who are hanging on this because of your manic, ideological preoccupation with tearing up accords and abandoning wages policy.

Let me turn, finally, to this larger issue of economic policy that is involved in all of this. By abandoning wages policy as an instrument of macro‐economic policy management over all policy management in this country, John Howard, the Prime Minister, is taking us straight back to the two-instrument economic policy of the past—that past, which the Prime Minister well remembers when he was Treasurer, when the whole emphasis was simply on fiscal and monetary policy, and you did not have wages policy as a crucial third leg of the tripod. That two‐instrument economic policy was what delivered Australia their lamentable average growth record under the Fraser‐Howard government of 2.1 per cent. That was the average growth that was delivered under that particular economic strategy the last time the Prime Minister was in office under the Fraser‐Howard government.

It was the three‐instrument approach—fiscal, monetary and wage policy, together with structural policy there in support as well and, more recently, a savings policy through superannuation—with wages policy as a key third item that in fact delivered under the Labor government an average 3.7 per cent growth for the whole of our 13 years in office—a 3.7 per cent average versus a 2.1 per cent average. The crucial difference in the approach, apart from all the micro‐economic reform we introduced, was our total reliance on wages policy as a crucial third leg in the economic policy strategy.

Of course, there are some other strands to Labor's economic legacy that will continue under this government, that will not be torn up: micro‐economic reform and the new emphasis throughout the economy on productivity improvement will, hopefully, continue, and that will be helpful in keeping things moving. But will that be sufficient to stop us sliding back to what seems now to be the generally accepted speed limit for developed economies like the United States of around 2½ per cent growth? That is the prevailing, understood constraint that exists in most of the other developed economies, particularly the United States.

Unless you break out of that constraint and bring wages policy into play as a crucial supplementary instrument to add to monetary policy and to add to fiscal policy, you run a number of risks. You run the risk of losing the cooperative as distinct from the heavy‐handed fiscal and monetary routes to maintaining low inflation. You certainly lose every chance of maintaining the kind of profit share that has been enjoyed by business right throughout the 1980s and continuing up to the present day. With that risk of higher inflation and lower profit sharing and the lower investment that goes with it, you lose the growth that you need to bring us to what remains a very achievable target of just five per cent unemployment by the year 2000. We can meet that target by creating 220,000 new jobs each year. That is a very achievable target of four per cent or thereabouts growth of the kind we averaged during our last three years in office.

We can get there as a nation. As a country we can do it. But we can only get there through a sensible, intelligent, rational application of all the tools of economic management that are available to us. If you tear up some of those tools for no other reason than a Thatcherite, ideological preoccupation with small government and distaste for the trade union movement, distaste for the accord and a belief in letting the market rip in every available context and not doing that which is necessary to continue an enormously productive partnership of the kind that we have had over the last 13 years, that is the result that you produce—the incapacity to produce these kinds of outcomes.

So it is a very high risk game that the government is now playing. For ideological reasons, as I have just said, not for rational economic reasons, it is putting at risk the whole future course of decent economic management in this country. It has already certainly denied an interest rate reduction here and now which would have been, as we all know, of enormous value to Australian home buyers, of enormous value to Australian business and of enormous value to those unemployed Australians who are desperately hoping for an increase in economic activity to get them back to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) on his maiden speech, as one should do in circumstances like this, but of course the content of it was essentially flawed. The claim that here we are, two months after the 2 March election, and interest rates would have fallen but for the election of the coalition is preposterous. I suppose that, after suffering the humiliating defeat and after being held to account by the Australian people in the way that the Australian Labor Party was, one would have to think up some way of consoling oneself that the Australian people got it wrong and you got it right. Whatever consolation this may give you, it is not grounded in fact. It is a preposterous claim. Only somebody who is a fool or a knave would try to run it. It is easily disposed of, and I will dispose of it by referring to one media report. The Deputy Leader based his claim on the Australian of 25 April 1996. The economics editor in the Australian had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's new shadow treasurer, Gareth Evans, entered the fray yesterday for the first time with the claim that an interest rate cut would have been on the cards now if John Howard had not scrapped the accord.
This is silly stuff, since it is perfectly obvious the excessive rate of wage increase that is alarming the Reserve Bank took place under the Accord.

`This is silly stuff'! All one should have done was turn to the front of the newspaper rather than the back, and of course the facts speak for themselves. But I would like to try to draw some more interesting political lessons out of the speech which the member for Holt has just made because it illustrates what is going to be a very difficult choice for the opposition.
On 20 March 1996 the Sydney Morning Herald, under the headline `Beazley cuts close links with the ACTU', carried the following statement from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley):

BREAK.PARA: The quite symbiotic relationship in the accord policy making process, if you like, disappears. The union movement has to make its own way.

It goes on to say that Mr Beazley hedged on a new accord, pointing out the circumstances which led to the original deal no longer existed. That was a very interesting statement from the Leader of the Opposition and one which I congratulated him on making at the time. Plainly, he realised the failures of the accord. If the accord had been a success, you would not now have a minority of votes in the House of Representatives approaching 40.

The accord was clearly and patently a failure and the Leader of the Opposition—I think on 20 March 1996—recognised that and tried to come to terms with it, as indicated in the Sydney Morning Herald headline `Beazley cuts close links with the ACTU'. I would recommend that path to the opposition. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, of course, unable to break the symbiotic relationship and aware that the Labor Party fronts in this chamber as the political wing of the ACTU, comes into this chamber and runs nonsensical propositions that, if only we had the ACTU directing economic policy, how much happier it would be.

Let me tell you: the ACTU directed economic policy for 13 years and the results speak for themselves. Thirteen years of the accord gave us the worst current account deficit in the industrialised world—worse than Mexico's. Thirteen years of the accord took net foreign debt from $23 billion to $185 billion. Thirteen years of the accord found that the average compound growth rate in the CPI was 7.2 per cent in Australia whereas it was 3.8 per cent in the G7. Thirteen years of the accord led to an increase in Commonwealth debt now approaching $100 billion. Thirteen years of the accord got Australia an $8 billion deficit after four or five years of economic recovery.

On 2 March it was the voice of the Australian people that said that the political wing of the ACTU, the Australian Labor Party, which has let Australia down so badly, will be banished to the benches of the opposition because it is time to start rebuilding this country. The truth is that it is time to start rebuilding this country. I have to tell you: it gives us no joy to have been passed an Australia which we find in the position that it is currently in.

In the speech that was just given by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, there was no appreciation whatsoever as to how Labor failed Australia—no apology; no recognition; no attempt to come to terms with it; and no attempt to deal with it. We heard the statement from the Leader of the Opposition that he considered Prime Minister Keating a legend of the Labor Party. I know it is the opening of the parliament, but I was thinking of making this a bipartisan policy because there are 20 new coalition members on this side of the House who do consider Paul Keating to be a legend—because of the contribution that he made to their election on 2 March. But there was no attempt whatsoever to come to grips with the fact that the accord and the economic policy of Labor over 13 years failed and failed Australia badly.

The interest rates which we are left with now are the result of the accord. The interest rates which were pushed up at the end of 1994, because this government was running such a lax fiscal policy, were a direct consequence of the accord—three increases over the period from August to December 1994—and persisted for the last 18 months. For the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to walk in here with the preposterous claim, `If we had only had another month they would have fallen,' is just to indicate how out of touch this opposition has become.

We had expected that on 2 March a little bit of reality therapy would have been delivered but, alas, it may take a few more defeats to deliver that reality therapy. I speak for our backbench: we are very happy to engage in that therapy over the next couple of years to make sure.

The fact is that throughout the period of the accord Australia had stunted productivity and high interest rates and a government that was addicted to debt and deficit. They were debt and deficit junkies, running a $100 billion build‐up in Commonwealth debt—to $100 billion. So we get to the situation where public debt interest under you—

TALK.START.PARA: —Five per cent.

—No, get it fixed in your head that we are talking about Commonwealth debt. Do you know the difference between Commonwealth debt and net foreign debt—a Commonwealth debt of about $100 billion? I will let you in on a secret: the Commonwealth owes 100 per cent of Commonwealth debt. We got to a situation where, after health and social security, public debt interest—servicing our debt—was rivalling defence and education spending. It was a policy of spending today and building debt for the children of tomorrow. The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) used to talk about the `let the children pay policy' of living beyond our means today and passing on to future Australians the results of that profligacy.

BREAK.PARA: When we talk about balancing the budget we talk about a policy for future Australians so that this generation can stand up and say to them, `We were the people who decided to live within our means and give children a fair go.' This government is not going to compete. It is not going to follow the profligate policy of Labor, the intergenerational stealing from the future which was the policy of debt which Labor led us into.

We can stand here with pride and say, `It will take some tough decisions.' We would have expected to inherit an Australia which was in much better shape but I tell you that the sooner we start on undoing that deficit, the sooner we can stabilise borrowing and the sooner we can give a better future to the Australians who will inherit this country.

If the accord was such a great success, how is it that at the height of the accord, in 1989‐90, home interest rates got to 17 per cent? How is it that the overdraft under this great, successful accord was at 21 per cent? How is it that Australia, even today, as a result of this accord is suffering some of the highest bank prime interest rates in the world? We still are. It is a legacy of 13 years.

In April 1986 Labor gave Australia record home mortgage interest rates of 15.5 per cent. In 1989 they hit 17 per cent. Labor, under the accord, had taken Australians into the worst recession in 60 years. Australians have not forgotten how Labor raised the interest rates again 1994, how they went down the same path because, as far as they saw it, it was more important to use taxes to buy votes. The great day of reckoning came on 2 March. It is going to take this government some time to undo the damage, but we will make sure that we do.

Let me say in relation to the accord that the great failure of the accord—and those opposite know it—was that the accord could never build productivity in this country. The reason the Reserve Bank says that it has a target for interest rates of around five per cent is its premise of a two per cent increase in productivity. A two per cent increase in productivity will bring the underlying inflation rate down about three per cent. But you can bring that underlying inflation rate lower if you can boost productivity—and the very cornerstone of our reform program is to boost productivity by having a new system of industrial relations which will allow employers and employees to agree. That will boost productivity. It will be a system of industrial relations in which there will not be third‐party interference, one which encourages cooperation in the workplace and which, above all, can get the productivity gains which we need in this country.

Out there in the Australian economy were all these areas crying out for reform and improvement. The waterfront, transport and communications were crying out. The previous government for 13 years had put them in the too‐hard basket because Bill and the ACTU said no. Bill said, `No, let's leave cabotage in place.' Bill said, `No, let's run an uncompetitive waterfront.' Bill said, `No, we can't do anything about the stevedoring industry.' Bill said, `No, we can't have agreements in the workplace.' Well, on 2 March, the Australian people said yes. They said, `We don't want to hive off those areas of the Australian economy which, under the accord, have been quarantined from improvement.'

We want the opportunity to boost productivity and, on the back of boosted productivity to boost wages and give Australia the opportunity to grow without running into the perennial speed limits that defeated the previous government over and over, the speed limits of the current account and interest rates. On 2 March the Australian people decided that there was a much better way than the accord‐Labor way—the low productivity, high interest rate, high current account, high debt, high foreign liability way that you had, over 13 years, put the Australian economy into.

We say to the Australian work force that there is an opportunity with a better system to build a new relationship. We say to the Australian employees that on the back of low inflation and high productivity we can deliver better wage outcomes. We say to them that there is the opportunity for cooperation and consensus in the workplace and, if it does not suit the union fiefdoms or those who need the trade union movement to organise their preselection to this place, that is not a reason for holding back the opportunity.

We also say to those in the work force that there is an opportunity to build that consensus and come to that agreement with a new system of industrial relations which can become the model for cooperation and which can allow the opportunity, free of third‐party intervention, for employers and employees to agree. It will be a better system of industrial relations.

In relation to a better system of industrial relations and in relation to fixing the fiscal problem, taking up competition and engaging in the reform which those opposite declared off limits, with the growth that Australia can expect, means the legacy of the new government under the change the Australian people made on 2 March will be an opportunity for a better future and an opportunity to put behind a decade of defeat. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in seconding the motion moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans). The Treasurer (Mr Costello) failed to address the issue in this motion, which essentially is: a lack of wages policy in the economic armoury of a government keeps pressure on interest rates and monetary policy because you are limiting your options.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the Treasurer wants to say about his ideological view of the accord, he cannot get away from the fact that a government, if it is serious about addressing the economic equation, has to come to grips with having a wages policy. A simple reality in this country is that you cannot have a wages policy unless you have a dialogue with the people who set wages. There are no federal powers to do it.

In the absence of those federal powers and because of the role that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission plays in setting wages in this country, based on arguments and pressures that the ACTU, unions and others pursue, what is needed for a wages policy is, first, a preparedness to engage them in dialogue and, secondly, a basis on which they can negotiate—not the gun at the head or take it or leave it approach, which the government have always accused them of doing and which they are now presenting them with, but a sensible approach.

In this debate there is no point the Treasurer making a segmental analysis about why we have problems. Any Treasurer worth their salt knows they need a balance between fiscal, monetary and wages policy if they are to achieve the improvement they seek. With no wages policy you get imbalance. It is impossible to get the balance that we were able to generate in our period of office. Lack of a wages policy simply means heavier reliance on monetary policy, which is why interest rates are not coming down, and heavier reliance on fiscal policy, which is why the government has a slash and burn mentality in the lead‐up to this budget.

The Treasurer squibbed two issues that were directed to him today by way of questions. Firstly, he was asked whether he would indicate when there would be a fall in interest rates and, secondly, whether his inability to do it was due to a lack of wages policy. What was his answer: `It is not the role of government to speculate on the movement of interest rates.' Yet when he was in opposition he constantly asked us as a government to speculate on interest rates, on when the next drop would be. What a hypocrite!

PARA.BREAK: The second issue that was addressed to him was in the context of budget honesty and opening up the books. He was asked to release the costings associated with his prom ises and that of his government in the lead-up to the last election. What did he say? He said that we are not going to get them. In other words, the government will release something before an election but they will not give it to us after the election. They will keep that hidden from us. Even though they have the information, they will not give it to us. Some honesty! Some indication of the primacy of this place over the executive, where you will keep that information hidden amongst the Expenditure Review Committee and maybe amongst some of the other members in cabinet, when you will not let the parliament understand the basis upon which your fiscal challenge is really being directed!

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the so‐called $8 billion hole behind which you want to hide, to confirm what the shadow Treasurer has been saying over the past couple of weeks let me quote what that hole is supposed to be made up of. I can quote no better source—other than my colleague the shadow Treasurer—than the Governor of the Reserve Bank, who had this to say on 28 March in Sydney:
Of the $7 billion deterioration since May 1995 in the budget estimate for 1996/97, for example, 90 per cent—
which is the point that the shadow Treasurer has made on a number of occasions—
reflects revisions to the economic forecasts.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying it's a $7 billion hole rather than an $8 billion hole?
—I am quoting the Governor of the Reserve Bank. He then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The latest parameter forecasts are subject to further changes. My own hunch—
this is the Governor of the Reserve Bank, who has been in the job a lot longer than you have, with respect, Mr Treasurer—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never been in the job of Governor of the Reserve Bank.

—You have been there eight weeks and you have not done too much in terms of giving us the information you said could be produced in 24 hours. We have not seen it in eight weeks. The Governor of the Reserve Bank went on to say:

BREAK.PARA: My own hunch is that growth in 1996/97 will be a bit stronger than 3¼ per cent, implying a lower starting point deficit.

This House needs to know what your promises will cost, because we found before the election a $1.2 billion gap and there is still $3.3 billion sitting out there because they did not have enough information from you when you were in opposition to be able to do the costings. They have had that information ever since 2 March. They have had the ability to work with you, and we have seen not one iota. You come into this House and refuse to give it to us but want to pretend that you are into budget honesty and the primacy of this place. What hogwash! Some honesty! Some primacy!

Mention has been made in this place of what the accord has not achieved. I remind the House that what we were able to achieve under accord mark VII, the one before last, over the last three years—not just the 13 years that the shadow Treasurer has referred to—is average economic growth greater than four per cent each year, the fastest of the OECD; inflation at 2½ per cent; wages growth in the order of four per cent to five per cent; industrial disputation two-thirds lower than it was when you left office; and the creation of 714,000 jobs.

In relation to those 714,000 jobs, I remind the House of what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had to say of the accord commitment to jobs. Three years ago he described the accord mark VII's jobs target of 500,000—it was 500,000 at the time—as `an insult to the intelligence of the Australian people.' What did we deliver? Seven hundred and fourteen thousand jobs. Some insult! The then Leader of the Opposition did not believe we could achieve it. But the reality is that it was an objective that the accord set itself—not just in jobs but in wages policy, inflation and industrial disputes—and it was delivered.

But what did accord mark VIII have in prospect? It went a step further. There was a commitment from the trade union movement to this. The accord said that it was `based on and consistent with maintaining an underlying rate of inflation of two to three per cent on average over the cycle'. In other words, wages policy would be delivered under the accord consistent with that objective. You have washed that away. I do not know how anyone can come into this place as a Treasurer and pretend that they have an objective of maintaining this underlying rate of inflation, yet wash away the very mechanism by which they would achieve it.

Accord mark VIII went further. It also said that the wage claims that the trade union movement would be making would be consistent with achieving a new target in terms of employment growth of 600,000 jobs over its life—in other words, at least 200,000 jobs per year, thereby taking us to that objective of five per cent unemployment which we had set ourselves.

The simple facts are that you cannot get wages policy in this country unless you get the cooperation of the trade union movement. You will not get the cooperation of the trade union movement for a ceiling on wages unless you are also prepared to guarantee a floor. The floor is made up of a number of dimensions, including underpinning award conditions. That will now be eroded by the changes to the Industrial Relations Act that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) will introduce, and it has always been underpinned by the social wage aspects—such as superannuation, Medicare and transfer payments.

If you are delivering distribution benefits to the trade union movement in ways other than money wages, then of course you can have more moderate money wage claims and outcomes. But if you cut away the ability to deliver benefits through that and indeed cut the benefits themselves, as we will see happen in this budget, then the trade union movement in this country will have no option but to pursue its claims through one avenue alone: money wages. There is no safety valve left. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your election to your office. The MPI today refers to `the impact of interest rates and Australia's economic outlook of the government's decision to abandon the accord and wages policy'. It is going to be great; absolutely terrific. Under the former Labor government we did not have a wages policy; we had a self-interest policy. What was good for the ACTU was believed to be good for the nation and the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I will quote a couple of sources. The first source is Jennie George in 1994. This was near the time the former minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton), had been comprehensively rolled by the ACTU Congress back in November 1993. He was putting up a whole new program of industrial relations reform, which included the infamous unfair dismissal rule and which gave the unions increased power over the negotiating and bargaining system.

Jennie put it well; she said, `What the employers have got to understand is that they lost the election and we won it.' The unions won the election; the ACTU won the election. We did not have a wages policy; we had a self-interest policy in the interest of trade unions and their peak council, the ACTU. I have another source. The shadow minister for employment and training, Martin Ferguson, who is at the table, said:
At every opportunity, the union movement will go out of its way to make the development of non-union agreements difficult.
He said this is to his own ex-government. He continued:
We are not going to lay doggo and let non-union agreements develop.

If we do not finally get around to doing a bit about this thing we call micro-economic reform in this country, we are going to continue to have interest rate problems, which go on to exacerbate our current account deficit and the huge, untenable foreign debt that we have accumulated after 13 years under Labor.

Today in question time the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said that there are two facets of reducing the current account deficit; there are two things that we must do if we are going to get rid of this systemic problem. One of those is to try to encourage Australians to do more about saving, and that is in a personal sense. We on this side of the House will do something about the problem in a government sense by reducing the Commonwealth's demands on public savings through reduced Commonwealth spending.

The other side of the equation is that we have to do something about industry in this country. We consume far too much from overseas. We do not produce enough of what Australians want to use. I remind the House that in 1992-93 the deficit of trade in manufacturing goods totalled $35 billion. I just recently produced figures for 1994-95 of an all-time national record of a $43 billion net deficit in trade in manufactured goods in this country. That is an outstanding record for a Labor government that was in power for 13 years!

This was a government that kept talking the entire time about employment. They talked about the needs of workers and the need for people to have jobs. What do we have? One of the highest unemployment rates in the industrialised world, the highest current account deficit in the industrialised world and this huge pall of national debt hanging over our heads every day.

The interest rate problem is significant because we pay high interest rates. We pay higher interest rates than we ought to because of our debt position, and that simply feeds upon itself. So we borrow money to pay interest on the debt that we have already accumulated. Somebody has to do something about that. Development of a wages policy of the kind adopted by the Labor government, which is beholden to the ACTU and the other unions, is not one that this side of the House will ever contemplate because it did not work.

The standard of living of Australians fell during those 13 years. You kept a clamp on wages so that the living standards of Australians could not rise. You did that because they could not contribute to productivity improvements and because the agenda was set by the ACTU. The agenda was set by the unions, not by the employees and employers working together to try to do things in a more modern way. Look at the nonsense we saw at Robe River. If five flavours of ice-cream were not provided at the canteen, everybody went home for the day. That kind of nonsense was written into comprehensive awards, as was demonstrated by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) during question time today.

Some of these awards encompass such archaic and antiquated provisions that they defy imagination. What we are talking about is simplifying those awards so that they become a core set of conditions that apply to a particular employment area. That is important because they will act as a safety net and they will make sure that people have, at base, a very reasonable standard of living. Beyond that, it is important that employers and employees work together to demonstrate and to prove up employment practices that actually lead to real productivity improvement. Then the gains can be shared amongst business, companies, industry and employees.

It is nonsense that our living standards have to fall in order to have what the Labor Party and the ACTU call a wages policy—a nonsense which must disappear from our vocabulary. I take the point that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) made today. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) is starting to distance this small opposition in the federal House of Representatives from the union movement. Why is he starting to do that? Because he knows in his own mind that every time they tried to implement good policy and good procedures the ACTU, which had a voice at the cabinet table, pulled the strings. The ACTU played the puppet and said, `No, you don't do it this way; you do it our way.' So the government was hamstrung frequently.

Back in April of 1993, we had the so-called historic win that Labor never expected to have, where Paul Keating knocked off John Hewson. On 21 April the then Prime Minister went to Melbourne and spoke to the Institute of Company Directors. He said some very important things. In describing a new model of industrial relations that he was working towards, he said:
It is a model which places primary emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards provided by arbitration tribunals.
It is a model under which compulsorily arbitrated awards and arbitrated wage increases would be there only as a safety net.
Importantly, he went on to state:
. . . we have laws which give the AIRC a role and powers that are not well suited to the present system we are trying to create.

So what happened? The former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, got busy with other affairs of state. Bill Kelty and Lindsay Fox went out into the countryside looking for jobs for young people—which was an admirable exercise—but they took their eye off the ball. The unions went absolutely mad when they realised what their industrial relations minister was going to do. Even Keating had a vision of what might happen, but the unions said no and the ACTU said no. That is this opposition's idea of a wages policy. The unions now represent only 33 per cent of the entire Australian work force and only 25 per cent of the private sector work force in Australia. That has come down very dramatically over the 13 years of a failed Labor government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is now conluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Anderson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill, and the associated Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1996, is to introduce minor but necessary amendments to ensure consistency between the current industry milk payment practices and the dairy market support legislation.

Following the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, Australia introduced new arrangements from 1 July 1995 which deliver assistance to dairy producers through a clearly defined and transparent domestic support scheme.

BREAK.PARA: The market support arrangements involve a levy on market milk, paid by producers; and a levy on manufacturing milk, paid by manufacturers of dairy products which can be recouped from domestic consumers. Exports of manufactured dairy products are exempt from levy liability.

The two levies are appropriated to the Australian Dairy Corporation, which pays support to manufacturing milk producers. The Australian Dairy Corporation also collects the levies as the agent of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

The scheme centres around being able to distinguish between market milk and manufacturing milk at the point of receival from a producer. The distinction between market milk and manufacturing milk under the current legislation is based on actual usage. Current administration of the scheme by the Australian Dairy Corporation is on the basis of industry milk payment practices and is not consistent with the legislation as it now stands.

Extensive consultation with the dairy industry has established that it would be extremely difficult for the industry to modify its current milk payment practices without causing major disruption. Accordingly, this bill retrospectively aligns the market support legislation with the existing administration arrangements of the Australian Dairy Corporation.

This bill provides for market milk to be redefined as that milk for which a producer receives a market milk payment. Manufacturing milk will subsequently be the residual of total leviable milk less market milk. These definitional changes will ensure that the legislative framework and the current method of administration of the dairy support arrangements are compatible. They have been developed in close consultation with the dairy industry.

PARA.BREAK: Two additional modifications have been incorporated into the bill. The first involves removing the imposition of the corporation, promotion and research levies on milk which is consumed, disposed of or lost on‐farm. In practice, the amounts of such milk are indeterminate and have consequently never in curred levy. The removal of the levy liability from such milk gives legal effect to industry policy and the reality of industry practice.

BREAK.PARA: The second modification clarifies the levy imposition arrangements for modified market milk and manufacturing milk by emphasising that levy is calculated on the milk fat and protein content of milk as determined on‐farm. Again this provision ensures consistency between established industry policy and the legislation.

The proposed amendments do not affect actual levy collection and support payments, as current industry practice will continue. No producer or manufacturer will be disadvantaged relative to the current operation of the scheme. Furthermore, there will be no effect on the annual amounts of revenue and outlays under the scheme. Most importantly, the market support arrangements remain consistent with the original policy intention of the scheme and with Australia's commitments to the World Trade Organisation agreement.

There are a couple of other points that I want to make. The first is to acknowledge the unbelievable performance of the Australian dairy industry in recent times. It has become the very model of a success story in terms of Australia's value added export sector. Not only has its performance in Asia outstripped the average performance of any other sector within the Australian economy, but even within agriculture, as I hope is well known in this House, the primary industry sector has shown a clean set of heels to the rest of the Australian economy. We need to commend it for that.

PARA.BREAK: The second point I want to make is to record my absolute delight at being able to carry through this place the first piece of legislation under the new administration. It is the first piece of legislation put through by a coalition government for 13 years. That is indeed an honour and something in which I take enormous pride, not only on my own behalf but on behalf of my colleagues as well. I see that the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) is to follow me. We are very proud and delighted to be able to take part in this process.I commend the bill to honour able members. I table the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

BREAK.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Anderson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill complements the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1996 in providing the legal framework for the current administration of the dairy market support scheme by the Australian Dairy Corporation.

The provisions of this bill revise the definitions of market milk and manufacturing milk, by reference to the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1996, to allow the established milk payment practices of the Australian dairy industry to continue unchanged.

The proposed changes to the market support arrangements constitute a minor legal correction and will not affect the administration of the scheme. They will apply retrospectively from 1 July 1995, the date on which the current market support arrangements commenced.These amendments also include changes which will ensure that no manufacturer is disadvantaged by the retrospective provisions of this bill regarding lodgment of monthly returns.

In commending the bill to honourable membersI note we were able to cooperate with the previous administration with regard to the 1995 legislation. I appreciate the opposition's cooperation, as I understand it to be the case, with regard to these minor amendments. I table the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Sharp, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to give effect to the government's pre‐election commitments to repeal the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act 1995 and the Ships (Capital Grants Act) 1987. These measures will save Australian taxpayers about $52 million over the next four years.

The coalition strongly opposed the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Bill when it was debated in the parliament last October. I remind the House of how this scheme developed from the deal made by the former Prime Minister and his senior ministerial colleagues, with the ACTU and the Maritime Union of Australia, to end the shipping strike called by the Maritime Union of Australia over the sale of ANL Limited and ANL's shareholding in Australian Stevedores.

For its part of the bargain, the MUA undertook to give serious consideration to supporting the government's proposed sale of ANL and negotiating an industrial agreement with shipowners to deliver significant cost savings. Well, we all know the story on ANL: the MUA opposed the sale tooth and nail and forced the government to back off from selling the line to P&O, the only prospective buyer. Needless to say, ANL made further losses which continued to be a drain on the Australian taxpayer.

As for the industrial agreement, the so‐called maritime industry restructuring agreement, or MIRA, was duly negotiated and was supposed to produce cost savings of some $200,000 per ship per year. However, the MUA has largely failed to deliver on its commitments, with the result that the promised savings have simply evaporated.

BREAK.PARA: One of the key elements of MIRA was for the industry to reduce the crewing factor from around 2.13 seafarers per berth to 2.0 by changes in work practices, improvements in safety and cutting out workers' compensation rorts. However, the quarterly survey by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics shows that over the 12 months to December 1995 the crewing factor worsened rather than improved.

Another key element of MIRA was for a peace accord to maintain an environment to minimise industrial disruption. Yet late last year, at the behest of its mates in the ACTU, the MUA took national strike action in support of a few mining industry workers at Weipa. In short, the MUA, despite the peace accord, was happy to damage its own industry and the nation as a whole in a political gesture to the power brokers of the ACTU who would rather have the MUA flex its industrial muscle than use the proper processes in the Industrial Relations Commission.

The evidence is there for all to see. The international shipping grants package has not delivered its complementary MIRA reforms; it has simply provided a windfall gain of $19 million to existing operators.

I now turn to the repeal of the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987. This scheme was introduced in 1987 with an intended five‐year life. In the words of the then minister, the Hon. Peter Morris, when introducing the bill, the legislation was to assist Australian ship operators to acquire modern, technologically advanced ships which could be operated at lower crewing levels. The scheme was subsequently extended another five years to June 1997. Hand in hand with this grant scheme went a generous accelerated depreciation tax concession.

In addition to these generous subsidies and tax concessions, there has been the financial assistance to the industry through the previous government's shared funding of early retirement and voluntary redundancy packages for MUA members. The total value of all these measures over the past nine years is estimated to have been in excess of $320 million.

While the crew levels on Australian ships are now equivalent to international standards, the crewing factor of around 2.13, which is largely accounted for by the most generous leave system of any maritime nation, is well above the international average of around 1.7. The industry is also saddled with a costly and inefficient pooled employment system for MUA members which gives employers no right to select the most suitable, appropriately trained ratings for their shipping operations. This pooled labour system, more fitting to the 1920s than the 1990s, also denies employers the opportunity of creating a strong company ethos among staff.

These factors, coupled with the high wages paid to Australian seafarers, means that Australian shipping is no nearer to being internationally competitive than it was nine years ago. The Australian taxpayer cannot be expected to continue pouring capital grants into shipping when it has failed to address the serious problems impeding its development as an efficient and competitive world‐class industry.

In addition to the winding‐up of the ships capital grants scheme, a bill will shortly be introduced to repeal the related accelerated depreciation provisions under section 57AM of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. However, consistent with established practice when tax concessions are withdrawn, transitional arrangements will enable those ships that would have qualified for the capital grant had the scheme continued for the further 12 months to still qualify for the accelerated depreciation concession. This is provided that they continue to meet the compliance criteria set out in the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 and are delivered to the shipowner and registered in Australia before 1 July 1997.

I now turn to the details of the bill. The key elements of the bill are contained in schedule 1 to the bill. Item 1 of the schedule repeals the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act 1995. In accordance with clause 2 of the bill, the repeal of the act is to take effect on 1 July 1996.

Item 2 of the schedule provides for the continuation of the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act in respect of entitlements accrued under the act up to and including 30 June 1996. Item 3 of the schedule amends the sunset provision in the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 with the effect that a grant will not be payable if the ship is delivered to the shipowner or registered in Australia after 30 June 1996.

Finally, the government has already begun consulting the shipping industry on other elements of the shipping policy reforms foreshadowed before the general election. These include such matters as the possible establishment of a second register‐type structure for Australian shipping.

Second register structures have been adopted by a number of traditional shipping nations to provide their shipping the opportunity to compete on similar terms with flag of convenience shipping. The government is examining whether a second register structure in Australia could provide the impetus to the Australian shipping industry to become internationally competitive, something that the massive subsidies paid out over the past decade by the previous Labor governments has singularly failed to deliver.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would conclude my remarks today by taking this opportunity to congratulate you on your election as the Second Deputy Speaker of the parliament. I know that you will carry out the task extremely well and in a fair and unbiased fashion. I wish you all the very best in your role. I would like to think that in the role you now have you will continue to perform in a similar fashion to the way you did when you were on the other side of the House before this parliament commenced. I table the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Prosser, and read a first time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PROSSER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to insert into the Excise Tariff Act 1921 the definition of `prescribed division' which is currently contained in an excise by‐law. The definition is necessary for determining the periods of a year for the purposes of calculating the excise duty on crude petroleum oil under three sections of the Tariff Act. The need for this legislation has arisen as a result of advice received from the Attorney‐General's Department in January of this year concerning the crude oil excise provisions of the Excise Tariff Act 1921 which rely upon the by‐law definition. It was suggested for clarity to transfer the by‐law definition into the act with effect from 1 July 1983, being the date the relevant provision which relies upon the by‐law definition first appeared in legislation.

The transfer of the by‐law definition and its retrospective commencement is proposed as a technical amendment pursuant to the Attorney‐General's Department's advice, to ensure there is no doubt about the validity of past revenue collections under the definition—item 2 of schedule 1 to the bill refers. The bill also effects a technical drafting amendment to the Tariff Act relating to gender neutral language, consistent with continuing Commonwealth drafting policy to make appropriate amendments where necessary in Commonwealth legislation to achieve a gender neutral result—item 1 of schedule 1 to the bill refers.

The principal amendment in this bill concerning the transfer of the definition of `prescribed division' from the excise by‐law into the Excise Tariff Act will not result in any additional outlays or revenue to the Commonwealth. The amendment will, however, remove any possible doubt about the validity of past revenue collections, which since 1984‐85 on `new' crude oil have totalled approximately $1.9 billion. I table the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for the Northern Territory, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins. Before addressing the Governor‐General's speech, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate you on being elected as the Second Deputy Speaker of this parliament. At some other time I will take the opportunity of congratulating the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker. Obviously, a lot of people believe that the only role of the Speaker is when he is in the chair. Being a former Speaker myself, I am aware that there are other duties that take up a considerable amount of your time. I wish you well and I hope you enjoy your position.

SPEECH.PARA: I represent the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory and I would refer honourable members to the fact sheet which was distributed by the officers of the parliament. When you see the breakdown of the members of this parliament, you will see that the Country Liberal Party is listed as a single item with a total of one member. I am the coalition member representing the Country Liberal Party in the House of Representatives. Of course, we do have a senator who is a member of the Country Liberal Party. I refer to Senator Grant Tambling who has been in the Senate for a number of years.

I must advise you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory is one of Australia's most successful political parties. It was elected to power at the first Northern Territory Assembly elections in 1974 and has been in power for those 22 years. At the conclusion of its current term in 1998 it will probably become the longest serving political party of any state government in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The Country Liberal Party was very instrumental in my being elected to this parliament. Without the party's help and that of its members in the branches throughout the Northern Territory I would not be here today. I must thank each and every member of the Country Liberal Party who worked very hard to ensure my success. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank my electorate for having faith in me in terms of representing them at this very, very interesting time of Northern Territory constitutional change and development.

Obviously, I have had some previous experience in parliament by being a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. I was a member of what we called the class of 1974. I retired from that parliament in 1994 to take time out to recharge my batteries and to seek preselection and, hopefully, once I had preselection, to go on and win the seat. I am happy to say that I did receive preselection in May 1995. I worked very hard with a lot of my former colleagues in the Northern Territory. Obviously I was successful.

The important thing is the Northern Territory's profile in terms of where we are today. The Northern Territory is 1.3 million square kilometres large. It is the largest electorate in terms of electors in the Australian region. I have 97,000‐plus on my electoral roll. That makes it the largest electorate in that sense. In terms of land mass, I know that the seat of Kalgoorlie—which stretches from the Great Australian Bight to the Kimberleys—is the largest electorate in Australia when calculated in land mass. But tonight, I would like to claim that the Northern Territory electorate, with its boundaries, is the largest in Australia by virtue of the fact that there is a water boundary from the coast of Western Australia to the Indian Ocean island territories which are part of the Northern Territory federal electoral boundaries.

The aspirations of the territorians are really that we have security, growth, progress, new wealth, protection, an enhancement of our lifestyle, a good standard of living, a future for our children and a society that recognises the rights of individuals.

At the same time, the Northern Territory has probably one of the best examples of multiculturalism. The Northern Territory is made up of many ethnic communities—totalling more than 60. When moving around the Northern Territory, it is not difficult to realise that 51 per cent of the population born in the Northern Territory are non-Anglo‐Saxon. Considering that 25 per cent of Northern Territorians are Aboriginal and indigenous, it certainly does give us the best mix in what we would consider to be a rich mix of cultures in the Northern Territory.

We also have a young population. Some say that 60 per cent of the population of the Northern Territory is under the age of 40, and some 70 per cent of that group is under the age of 25. So we must be mindful when we try to formulate our policies and we must make sure that the considerations of the young are taken into account.

When we speak about the young, we obviously speak about the young people who are working in the Northern Territory and the two‐income families who have great problems and difficulties with child-care places. I am told by constituents that, if you have two children in your family and you want to get those children into the same child-care centre, you have a better chance of winning Tattslotto. I think that is disgraceful.

At the same time, we can identify with the fact that, within the next three to five years, some 500 people in the Northern Territory will require additional aged care facilities, whether they be by way of hospices, villages or clinics. The important thing, I believe, is that we need to establish more facilities for our senior citizens, and that is something that I will be working very, very hard to achieve.

If we do not keep our senior citizens in the territory, they will leave and, because of the extended family situation in the territory, they will take their families with them to other parts of Australia. At the same time, I am aware that the Chief Minister, Shane Stone, is having very serious discussions with our Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) to try to work out a particular program to encourage migration to the Northern Territory.

A lot of you who were members of parliament years ago might have remembered when Ian Macphee was the federal minister for immigration. He tried to put in a scheme—which in those days was called the NUMAS scheme—to encourage migration to remote parts of Australia, including the Northern Territory, the northern part of Western Australia and, I think, even Tasmania. He tried to get more people to go to those areas. Without that sort of population growth, the Northern Territory would have obviously taken a lot longer to develop. My job is to use my best endeavours to make sure that the aspirations of the territory are met.

That brings me to statehood. Of course, constitutional changes started in 1974 with our first fully elected parliament, of which I was a member. The first major constitutional changes started in 1978 when we were given self-government. We were then able to make determinations and decisions in the Northern Territory, because we were territorians elected to represent other territorians.

In 1996, some 22 years later, the advent of statehood has certainly been deterred, I believe, by the last 13 years of Labor government. We were given some encouragement in 1975 when the Prime Minister of Australia, the Hon. Malcolm Fraser, said at that time that the Northern Territory could have statehood within five years. Of course, being new in terms of where we were going towards constitutional development, we said, `No. We don't think that timetable is a good timetable. We will need more time to establish our bona fides before we move into that final stage.'

We have been treated as a state in a financial sense since 1988, so that does not inhibit us from moving forward. Of course, economic development—which I hope to be able to speak about a bit more tonight—has certainly given the Northern Territory a great impetus for that final stage of constitutional change.

The biggest factor that not so much confuses people but makes them hesitant is that they are asked, `If you become a state, do you want 12 senators?' With a population of 185,000 in the Northern Territory, it would be quite unrealistic to expect at statehood that we should finish up with 12 senators. At the time, my predecessor in this place did say in his maiden speech that, when the territory becomes a state, we should not have fewer senators than the other states. I believe that he may have been wrong in that assumption.

If we go back and look at when Australia became a federation in 1901, we see that each of the states were given six senators, and I believe that the Northern Territory should start by having at least six senators. The reasoning behind that idea of our forefathers was that, by granting six senators to the smaller states with a smaller population base, the bigger states would not be able to kick them around.

In 1996 there is talk about a constitutional change and statehood for the territory by the year 2001. I believe that is too far away and we could put programs in place before then. I am told that section 121 of the constitution will allow this parliament to give the Northern Territory statehood, provided we can reach an arrangement in Senate representation.

I believe that the territory should not start with fewer than six senators. Then a timetable—whether it be gauged on growth or population—could be put in place to allow the territory to reach its full maturity in representation. It is not a matter of if; it is now a matter of when. I certainly hope that the timetable is accelerated before the year 2001.

In terms of the legislative process in the Northern Territory, we are subject to the power of veto by the Commonwealth. We have been since 1974. I am happy to say that in the last 22 years not one piece of legislation passed by territorians has ever been rejected by the Commonwealth. In 1901 the states all had six senators. We were part of South Australia in 1901. In 1910 the South Australians could not handle the development of the north and they gave it back. The territory was formulated in 1911 and we have been under Commonwealth control since then. The Northern Territory, with one‐sixth of the Australian land mass, should be a state before the year 2001. I would be very proud if I could be the House of Representatives member who tabled the constitution for the Northern Territory.

Land rights, obviously, is a very important issue in the Northern Territory. My position will be to influence policy development and to have a legislative program in favour of economic and social development in the Northern Territory, remembering that 40 per cent of Australia's export income is generated north of the Tropic of Capricorn. I was very pleased to see that the Governor-General in his speech yesterday said that the Commonwealth government would make sure that our indigenous communities are part of that development.

Native title has not worked. Two years have passed and some $30 million has been spent and we are still unsure of where we are going. I acknowledge that during the election campaign the coalition foreshadowed that it was going to amend the Native Title Act. I am pleased to say that in the Governor-General's speech it has been foreshadowed that amendments are going to take place to native title. That is very important because there is a lot of confusion in the remote parts of the Northern Territory and in other parts of Australia. People are looking for a finalisation of this matter.

We have two land councils in the Northern Territory—the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. It divides the territory in half. I think it is wrong. It is now time to establish smaller land councils. Aboriginal communities want smaller land councils so they can determine their own future and wellbeing. A large land council in the Top End dictates what happens in half of the Northern Territory. I invite honourable members who have never been to the Northern Territory to come and see for themselves first-hand the implications of the very large areas we have. Aboriginals in some parts of the territory cannot talk about land in another part of the territory which is not part of them. Land, for Aboriginals, is their mother. If I live in one section of the Northern Territory and I am part of a land council I really should not be talking about other parts of that land as far as they are concerned. Smaller land councils will ensure far greater development in terms of land ownership.

I turn to Kakadu and Uluru. Obviously I am not going to have time to finish what I have set out to do today. I will probably use the grievance debate to pick up other points that I do not get through tonight. With Kakadu and Uluru we are talking about management of those two parks. We are not talking about ownership. The Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Service have good management models. I believe they have done an excellent job since 1978. Katherine, which is the major national park, is on Aboriginal land and the Katherine Gorge is managed by the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Service. Territorians do not understand why Canberra wants to run our parks. Can't we be trusted? We believe we can. We know that we must consult with traditional owners both at Kakadu and Uluru.

There are 4.7 million hectares of park in the Northern Territory and 2.1 million of those are just Uluru and Kakadu. There are 12 other parks in the remainder, which the Northern Territory government controls and runs very well through its parks and wildlife service. The maintenance of these large parks is an enormous problem. My advice is that Kakadu is deteriorating under federal supervision. Some waterways are becoming polluted with an introduced feral aquatic plant, salvina molesta. There is also mimosa pigra. A feral pig program also needs great attention.

The Northern Territory government has its own programs. Kakadu, with its area and waterways, and other waterways are controlled by the Northern Territory government. If they are working on these problems in our waterways and if at the same time that is not happening in Kakadu, then everybody is wasting their time. There needs to be a coordinated approach.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may remember a headline about my wanting to go out to the tollbooth with a sledgehammer. Symbolically speaking, that is what I wanted to do because tollbooths in the parks, as far as we are concerned, are not the way to go if we are going to encourage tourism. But let me talk about ANCA. In 1975 ANCA started in this country with a staff of six and a budget of just over $1 million. In 1996, expenditure on Kakadu and Uluru is some $8 million—just to run those two parks. The total budget for the territory, as I understand it, is about $23 million. The whole budget for ANCA in 1994-95 was $75 million, and plus the $11 million that it collects makes a total of $85 million. It now has some 460 officers, of whom 349 are full-time. In regard to the aid spent on those parks, the Northern Territory could do a far better job with its National Parks and Wildlife Service than ANCA.

Let us talk about uranium and get one thing straight. The uranium province was there before the park was established. We have not tried to establish a uranium mine in Kakadu. It was in the South Alligator Rivers Region and the park came afterwards. ERA has been there since 1974. Kakadu was not declared until 1979. The Jabiluka and Koongarra mines are still out of the park, but there seems to be some worry about them.

I am very happy that the coalition has said that it is going to abandon the uranium three‐mine policy. This will help the Northern Territory. We know that our Commonwealth brother, Canada, is able to mine uranium. It is able to take advantage of the market.

Let us look at the exports out of the Northern Territory. Some $1.46 billion worth of exports came out of the Northern Territory in 1994-95. One per cent of Australia's population, which is about 180,000 people, supplies the Australian community with two per cent of GDP. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, on being elected Deputy Speaker. I am quite sure that you will do a fantastic job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Namadgi, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech. I ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, on your election to this very high office. I look forward to having the opportunity of saying likewise to the Speaker and the Second Deputy Speaker. May I also say at this point how much I have enjoyed hearing the speeches from the other new members who have proceeded me—the members for Gilmore (Mrs Gash), Longman (Mr Brough), Macarthur (Mr Fahey), Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) and the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas). I now know how they felt when they stood.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with a great sense of privilege that I rise in this chamber today. It was one of my proudest moments when I was sworn in as the first member for Namadgi yesterday. It is not very often that a member has the opportunity to be an electorate's first representative and I am aware of the special responsibilities that come with that task.

Namadgi is the Aboriginal name for the mountains south‐west of Canberra. For those who are unfamiliar with the new electoral boundaries in the ACT, Namadgi consists of the whole of Tuggeranong, the south Woden suburbs of Chifley, Pearce, Torrens, Mawson, Isaacs and Farrer, as well as the remainder of the ACT to south and west of the Murrumbidgee River.

The Namadgi area has a very rich heritage. A rock shelter just north of the Namadgi National Park contains evidence that Aboriginal people were living in the region during the last ice age around 20,000 years ago. The first pastoralists settled in the valleys at the southern end of the Namadgi Park in the 1830s. They faced a struggle to establish themselves in a remote area subject to severe weather.

The area is now home to a population of nearly 90,000 people. Each one of these people has a stake in the future of their community and I see it as a fundamental part of my role as their federal member to represent the very diverse range of interests in the community and service the needs of my constituents. But to me that is not quite enough.

I believe it is important to have a vision in politics. It is not sufficient to say, as a politician, `I am here and I want to represent the community,' because by definition that is what we are elected and paid to do. It is our job. What must come with wanting to represent that community is a vision and a firm belief in how and why.

BREAK.PARA: I want to represent the community through the Australian Labor Party because I believe in the philosophy of the party—social justice, equality, human rights, compassion and assistance to those in need. This is the philosophy the party was founded on out of the trade union movement over 100 years ago. I believe in progress and change but for the good of the whole community. I believe in the rights of all individuals not just those who are rich and powerful or have the loudest voices. I am here because the ordinary people must have a voice in parliament. That is why I represent the community as a member of the ALP.

I see it as my major responsibility in this place to ensure quality representation for the people of the electorate of Namadgi. I can assure them of dedication and hard work on their behalf. I will be accessible and always ready and willing to hear their views and be their voice in this place.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave a commitment during the election campaign that he would govern for all Australians. I would like to ask the honourable member: what has happened to that promise? It certainly has yet to be demonstrated clearly in Namadgi. I have given an absolute commitment to represent all the residents of my electorate and I call on the Prime Minister to restate his commitment to govern for all of the Australian population.

I have a long association with the Namadgi area, both professionally and at a personal level.
