As a result, I have had the privilege in participating in the growth and development of one of the fastest growing urban areas in Australia. My electorate is like any other urban electorate in the country. It shares the same problems and its residents have the same aspirations for themselves and their families. I believe that the Namadgi electorate embodies the spirit of modern day Canberra. It was not so long ago that Canberra was limestone plains, but now in a relatively short time Canberra has developed into a modern and diverse community. The Namadgi area has likewise developed in this fashion. It is part of the whole, but a very distinct part.

I am very proud that my electorate encompasses the Namadgi National Park. Namadgi was proclaimed a national park in 1984. It covers 94,000 hectares or almost half of the Australian Capital Territory and is the most northerly alpine environment in Australia. Its tallest mountain, Bimberi Peak, is only 318 metres below Australia's highest, Mount Kosciusko. Given the proximity of our rapidly developing urban areas to the national park and the distinctive nature of the electorate, careful and balanced development must take place.

Not only do we have the highest proportion of young families of any electorate in Australia making their homes in Namadgi but also a rapidly increasing teenage population, along with a small but growing proportion of older citizens. The growth of the teenage population presents challenges for policy makers in the next few years. These kids have expectations that their city will be able to provide them with challenging and relevant employment in the future.

The Tuggeranong Town Centre is beginning to develop into a healthy work base for the electorate. Large public sector employers, such as the Department of Social Security and the Health Insurance Commission, have provided the centre with a much needed employment boost. As a direct result of this strong public sector growth, the electorate now has a variety of retail, commercial and community facilities that meet the demands of an ever‐growing population. However, with a target population still to reach of around 100,000, continued development is essential to ensure growth into the future.

Since the election the emphasis has turned from a probable increase of that employment base through the development of a Commonwealth department office complex in that town centre to a fight to maintain the Commonwealth work base we have. The electors of Namadgi expect no more or less than what the Canberra plan promised them years ago in its formulation—a full and viable employment base in their own local region.

In the ACT the strength and the viability of the private sector is more dependent on the public sector and government decisions than any other city in the nation. The growth of small and medium business in this town is reliant on certainty and stability in the public sector. With just under half the ACT's work force employed in the public sector, the current speculation surrounding that public sector is causing, quite justifiably, considerable concern among the residents of Canberra. Given this prevailing climate, it comes as no surprise that economic activity in the ACT is stalling and, in some areas, moving rapidly into reverse.

Throughout the recent federal election campaign the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) travelled the country championing the cause of small business and the need to raise the standards of honesty and accountability in government. What must the small business people of the ACT be thinking right now? Recent statements by the Canberra Business Council and the ACT Liberal government confirm the extreme concern of local business at the federal government's plans for the ACT. One only need acknowledge the full page advertisement in today's Canberra Times placed by the Canberra Business Council to understand that level of concern.

The speculation, the anxiety and the degree of uncertainty could be ended today by this government. Make no mistake, the coalition government's plans for this town and this community will create, I fear, an economic and social disaster. The coalition has shown a punitive, short‐sighted attitude towards the Public Service time and time again, as history is testimony to. Cast your mind back to the last time they were in government. The results of the Lynch razor gang sadly still hang strongly in our local memory.

During the election campaign, I gave numerous warnings that, once elected, a coalition government would cut much further than they were letting on. The electors of Namadgi believed me and they voted for me. I recall that my comments were treated with derision at the time and I was accused by many of scaremongering.

It amazes me that there is still a belief in the modern‐day coalition that genuine savings in government spending can be brought about through reducing Public Service numbers. It may be politically expedient to talk about cutting back government spending by reducing the number of public servants, but, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has pointed out on many occasions recently, the Public Service wages bill makes up only a very small component of total public sector outlay. So the scope for significant savings is minimal, but the impact of those savings is widespread. The government has offered no explanation of the link between public sector cutbacks and national prosperity. It seems to believe that one person's job loss is another person's tax cut.

Whilst I am not advocating protection of the Public Service for the sake of it, I strongly believe in the need to maintain a Public Service which is efficient, professional and driven by a high standard of service delivery. The Labor government undertook significant reform of the Public Service, increasing productivity and efficiency. The Service is to be congratulated for the way in which it adapted to meet the former government's reforms. In contrast, the coalition's approach appears to be driven by a narrow focus on that dollar bottom line. The result of this approach will be inefficiencies and a diminution of the previously very high standards. Morale in the service will be severely affected.

I have always believed that whenever there is a need to reduce job numbers it must be done with levels of service delivery as the paramount concern. The question I put to the new government is this: at what cost to the community are these public sector savings being made? That is the aspect of the equation that the government appears to ignore. There is no doubt that the cost will be increased workloads and excessive demands on individual public servants. But what of the reduction in the quality and type of community service, that is, the service to our community? Surely any responsible government would see the absolute arrogance of making substantial cuts to the Public Service without even publicly acknowledging their impact. Implementing destructive policy in complete isolation of the consequences typifies the sort of narrow vision that will guide this government through the course of its term.

This government must also publicly recognise that people will be directly affected by these cuts. When we speak of these effects, we are not referring to a list of undefinable values in the middle of an equation or a balance sheet. We are not simply talking about proposed targets for a departmental head to meet. We are talking about thousands of men and women throughout the country who will no longer have a job to go to because the government of the day believes that the only way to meet a budget target based on inexact forward estimates is to simply throw people out of work.

With all the attention on Canberra, people fail to realise the impact these cuts will have in regional Australia. Contrary to popular belief, the government of Australia is not all in Canberra. In fact, only about one in five Commonwealth employees is based in the ACT. Quite often, the Commonwealth public servants employed in regional areas help to form the backbone of their local community. They are the ones who actively participate in their local community—the school fetes and the sporting events. They spend their incomes in their local region. I wonder whether three of my colleagues on the other side—the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and the honourable member for Eden‐Monaro (Mr Nairn) are aware of the social and economic effects on their electorates if, for example, the local CES or DSS offices are closed.

It would be cynical to suggest that the government's silence on the ramifications of its approach to the Public Service indicates a lack of ideas on its part as to how to deal with the effects of such a decision. I take it as given that a responsible government would at least be prepared to deal with the consequences of its actions. I hope, for the sake of the people in my electorate and others who will suffer the inevitable effects, that my cynicism is unfounded.

With the federal government single‐mindedly concerned with returning the budget to the black, and the ACT Liberal government worried only about obtaining compensation to prop up its bottom line, who is going to be looking out for those really affected by the cutbacks—the families, the single parents, the pensioners, the students and those with a disability or a chronic illness? What happens when they start to fall through the cracks that will inevitably appear when the effects on service delivery occur?

In tough economic times there seems to be a propensity for the conservative side of politics to shamelessly perpetuate the myth that the Canberra community is somehow exempt from the pain felt in the rest of the country. Canberra is a city no different from any other in Australia. We are not spoilt, elitist or sterile. My electorate is the same as any other in the country. In fact, I invite all honourable members in this place to make the time to drive the 30 or 40 kilometres down to the southern urban areas of my electorate to get a true picture of my constituency.

Canberra is made up of ordinary Australians with expectations and needs that are found in all other communities in the country. We are concerned about our future and this nation's future. We are concerned about unemployment, the health and wellbeing of our families, the education of our children, the environment in which we live and the immense problems that can, and in fact do, face our youth.

As the national capital, there is no doubt that we enjoy the facilities that come with that role. However, Canberra is also a place where people live. I do not believe we should have to apologise for living here. We may have the facilities that a modern day city provides but we also have the same social problems—family separation, youth homelessness, unemployment, drug abuse and poverty.

Too often it is convenient for interstate politicians, and particularly the media, to score cheap political points by attacking Canberrans. I strongly object to any imputations that Canberrans, particularly those employed in the public sector, are living off the rest of the country. Those who simplistically attack the Public Service should remember that the Public Service provides services to the whole Australian community—valuable services such as social security, defence, veterans' affairs and so on. These are services that only the public sector can and should provide. In a time when the community feels increasingly cynical about the process of government, an adequately staffed professional public service forges an undeniable link between government and the community.

Of course, our local community is now wondering, given that the Prime Minister has decided to operate primarily from Sydney, whether the print newspaper headlines over the next few years may thunder `Sydney to cut pensions and benefits', `Sydney to shed 25,000 jobs' and so on. I suspect not.

A lot has been said recently about the limited number of female members of parliament. As I look around this chamber, I am particularly pleased to see that the number of women parliamentarians has increased from previous parliaments. However, both sides of politics need to be aware that more must be done. It is simply not good enough for one side or the other to grandstand about which has more women members. Until women have equal representation in this parliament as a matter of course, the problem is not resolved; the true meaning of full and proper representation of the community will not have been achieved.

In the ACT both the Labor and Liberal parties have a proud record of supporting women candidates. Among the ALP women are the former ACT senator Susan Ryan, who was the first female Labor cabinet minister; Ros Kelly, who also served as a cabinet minister; former ACT Chief Minister Rosemary Follett, who was the first female to head a government in Australia; and, more recently, our newly elected Senator Kate Lundy. The ACT Liberal Party has also actively promoted women candidates, the most notable of these being Senator Margaret Reid and ACT Chief Minister Kate Carnell.
During my term as a member of the ACT Legislative Assembly between 1992 and 1995, I was proud to be a member of a Labor government that in fact had equal numbers of males and females in its caucus.

In finishing, I would like to thank all the residents of the electorate of Namadgi for giving me this unique opportunity. I must also thank particularly the people of Tuggeranong Valley for their support. It was my professional and social involvement in Tuggeranong over many years that prompted me to seek elected office. I would like to thank all members and supporters of the Australian Labor Party, but in particular the members of the Lanyon, Tuggeranong and South Woden sub‐branches, for all their tireless work and dedication which made my election possible. Unfortunately, there are too many to name individually. However, I pay special tribute to my campaign director and friend, Mr John Hargreaves; my friend and former employer, Mr Terry Connolly; and of course my family. As we all know, it is primarily that level of support that gets us here.

I am looking forward to working with all of my colleagues in this federal parliament to ensure that Canberra continues to progress for the good of all Canberrans and, through that, for all Australians. Thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Dawson, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mrs DE‐ANNE KELLY

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I congratulate you on your election as Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives. I would also like to congratulate the Liberal and National parties on their victory—winning government. I wish Mr Howard and Mr Fischer, our Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, well.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I address you today with humility, aware that a great responsibility rests on my shoulders. The mighty seat of Dawson, a rural and regional seat in North Queensland, the largest sugar seat in Australia, has chosen only its fourth member since the seat was proclaimed in 1949. The electorate chose the best man for the job, only this time the best man happened to be a woman.

The Queensland National Party and the people of Dawson have also made political history, for it is my honour to be the first National Party woman to ever sit in the House of Representatives. It was a considerable leap of faith for the Queensland National Party and the people of Dawson to choose a woman to defend their industries and the people in North Queensland.

I would like to tell you a little about Dawson. It stretches from Alligator Creek, south of Townsville, down the Queensland coast to Clairview. It takes in the mining towns of Collinsville and Glenden. The principal centre is Mackay, followed by Ayr, Home Hill, Bowen, Proserpine, Sarina and the glorious Whitsundays. Dawson pays its way. With only 0.7 per cent of Australia's population, it has four per cent of Australia's exports. A Dawson person is six times more effective in producing exports for this great country than is the average Australian. Dawson is the sweetest seat in Australia. Half of all Australia's sugar is grown in my seat and 80 per cent of that is exported.

Any Treasurer who is feeling a little glum and a bit worried about the balance of trade will be heartened greatly by a visit to the mighty seat of Dawson because out of our ports of Dalrymple Bay and Hay Point, the coal‐handling facilities in Mackay, every year flows $2.4 billion worth of coal—3.4 per cent of the exports of our great Commonwealth. Dawson is the engine room of exports—sugar, beef, coal, horticulture and tourism—despite all the difficulties, such as droughts, lack of infrastructure and dependence on fluctuating commodity prices, that beset those who live in regional and rural areas.

I would like to pause for a moment and tell you some of the difficulties that face the industries in Dawson. Our beef industry has now seen a dramatic fall in prices of 20 per cent. Soon that will be 30 per cent. I am also concerned about access for tourists to the mighty Whitsundays. If you have not had a holiday in North Queensland, do yourself a favour and come to the Whitsundays. It is absolutely magnificent there. But we have a difficulty because we do not have access to the tourist areas in Dawson. That is something that I have pledged to rectify while I am the federal member.

Water storage has been a considerable difficulty. Under the last 13 years of government we have seen very few major water storages go into what is a very dry part of Australia. The sugar industry is suffering paralysis by analysis. It has been examined by technocrats, bureaucrats and everybody else so many times that it is experiencing a period of paralysis. I hope that the technocrats, both federal and state, leave my mighty sugar industry alone so it can get on with doing what it does well—being one of the major exporters of sugar to the world.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have a gift for you today: North Queensland, 100 per cent Australian coffee, grown in Bowen. I understand from the people who have tasted this coffee that it is some of the finest coffee in Australia. I would like to present this to you later and I hope that you will enjoy it as a small memento of Dawson.

Moving on to more serious matters, those of us who represent rural and regional areas are very few in number. It behoves us, therefore, when we are weak in number to be fierce in debate. I trust the House will understand the fierceness of our debate.

A seat is not just about economic factors and exports; it is the heart and soul of the people there. Dawson is very proud to have the largest percentage of Australian South Sea Islanders in any seat in Australia. These are the descendants of the Kanakas, the indentured labourers—some say slaves—who were brought out last century from the islands of the South Pacific to work in the sugar plantations. They are a tremendous people, very Christian in their faith and with strong family groups. They are very eager to take part, on their merits, in all the opportunities that our country offers.

We have many people of different heritage, notably Italian and Maltese. Many of those people arrived in this country with just a suitcase. They now have flourishing sugarcane properties which they built up by cutting cane by hand—up to about 10 tonnes a day. Believe me, that is harder work than any of us will ever do. They have given us a great cultural heritage in Dawson. We have the Australian‐South Sea Islander Cultural Hut, the Maltese festival—the only one in Australia—and the Tre Venizi in Burdekin, to name a few.

BREAK.PARA: I would now like to pay tribute to my predecessor, Mr Ray Braithwaite. Ray was the member for Dawson for 20 years. No matter where you travel around Dawson, you hear the same thing: Ray is honest, he works hard and he has great integrity. He made what I think is the greatest sacrifice any federal member can make for constituents: he gave up his personal ambitions for his electorate. In 1992 when Ray was the shadow minister for aged care, the coalition had a policy of reducing the sugar tariff to negligible levels by the year 2000. Ray resigned his shadow ministry for his electorate and set a standard of representation that I and many others can aspire to. Ray Braithwaite championed the cause of the Australian South Sea Islanders and worked for fairness for subcontractors. He was truly a great representative of the people of Dawson.

I would now like to thank those who worked long and hard in my campaign. The wonderful Queensland National Party people organised meetings, rallies and fund‐raisers right across Dawson. Although I cannot name them all, there are some special people whom I would like to mention: Mr Ken Crooke, our state director; Sir Albert Abbott, whose faith in me never wavered; Mrs Eileen Deicke, a good friend and supporter; Jack Long; and Jim Wort.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you could never do this job without the support of your family, and I am blessed to have a wonderful husband who has supported me through this campaign. I also have a dear little son, who is eight years old, called Ian. Whenever I became rather disheartened about the campaign and my opponents, he would say to me, `Don't worry, Mummy. They are in a rowboat and you're in a speedboat.' Fortunately, that turned out to be true.

I am very glad that my mother is here today and sad that my father could not be—except I hope in spirit. It is to my father, the late Ian Park, that I owe my character and convictions. I grew up on a cattle property. Dad believed that girls could do anything, and we sure did. We mustered, I built fences and we cut calves. It was a terrific childhood.

During the beef crash of the 1970s, when cattlemen shot their cattle because they were not worth the freight to the meatworks, my father along with many others founded the Cattlemen's Union. In real terms the cattle industry is in the same situation now as it was in the 1970s. The difficulties are as profound. My father said that primary producers, by and large, could struggle through the bad seasons and the bad commodity prices, but the biggest threat they faced was political in terms of poor policy and political interference. I think that is as true now as it was then. My father taught me about true representation, that if you represent somebody you can never back down from pushing their concerns.

I would now like to mention somebody who has been a great inspiration to me: Lady Bjelke-Petersen, Florence, who was a senator for Queensland in parliament until recently and is of course the wife of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. Florence taught me some valuable lessons. She said that complex political problems could be looked at by simply asking: are they the right thing or are they the wrong thing? She also said that it is most important to keep faith with those who keep faith with you.

I would now like to speak about my political philosophy. I was very pleased to hear the Governor-General mention in his address yesterday the national interest. In recent times there has been a lot of talk of the public interest. I think that is a rather poor term to use. The national interest is what we should be concerning ourselves with, because the nation is not just a public, which is those who are living now. A nation is those who have defended and worked for our great country. It is those who are yet unborn. A nation is a contract between past, present and future Australians.

I would now like to mention a little about my view of how you do not build a nation and then what I believe does need to be done. You cannot build a nation by dividing its people with special privileges. You cannot build a nation by pitting the weak against the strong. Competition is sometimes exploitation. You cannot pit the metropolitan city against the regional centre or the country town. You

cannot pit the chain store against the corner store. You cannot pit the international commodity traders against the small family farmer. You cannot build a nation by substituting the disorderly love and discipline of family life for the cold, structured care of the state. You cannot build a nation by substituting kindness and respect for life with the sterile computer‐generated use‐by date for human life.

Consider the railway worker who stopped me in a country pub—not that I spend all my time in country pubs, I might add—the other week. He is raising seven sons on a railway worker's income. He is going to turn them into fine young Australian men. But he wants an incentive, a reward, for doing the right thing. I am very pleased to see that the new coalition government is going to give incentives for all Australians doing the right thing. You cannot build a nation by snaring men's enterprise and endeavour in a web of bureaucracy and dependency.

But what of the future? I would like to think that in 100 years time—that sounds like a very long time away but we will have great‐great‐grandchildren then and they will look back and either honour us or decry us for the decisions that we make now—we would still have a sovereign nation, with one people, one flag, our constitution and our democratically elected government. I would like to think that we still had a nation where people had a spiritual faith, a belief, in something outside themselves, where children were nurtured in a loving home with a mother and father. I would like to think we still had a community of small towns and regional centres—not a vast megopolis stretching from Melbourne up to Brisbane, what I call `Mel/Syd/Bane', and that we still needed the community of small regional centres, because those are the reservoirs of all the values we hold dear and are distinctly Australian: decency, fellowship, good humour.

I do not want to see an Australia then that is made up of multinational companies. I would like to think it would still be possible for Australians to have a go, to have a small business or a family farm. I do not want to see future Australians inheriting our financial debts. I would like to think that the children of the future in our great nation had only their own financial debt to bear—not a generational debt bequeathed by us. I would still like to see a nation that was clean and disease free. I would like to see all Australians—Aboriginals, my Australian South Sea Islander people, Torres Strait Islanders and others—sharing on their merits in the opportunities that our great country offers.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in closing I would like to share with you the creed of the Queensland Country Women's Association, one of the largest women's organisations in this country: I would be true for there are those who trust me; I would be pure for there are those who care; I would be strong for there is much to suffer; I would be brave for there is much to dare; I would be friend to all, the foe, the friendless; I would be giving and forget the gift; I would be humble for I know my weakness; I would look up and laugh and love and lift. That is not a bad description of the qualities and the task that lie before a federal member. God bless all my people in Dawson. I pray to be worthy of the great task they have set before me. Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Order! Before I call the honourable member for Barton, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I congratulate you on your election to the honour of the office you hold and in particular as a representative of the Australian Labor Party in this House. I know that you will discharge your office with impartiality and authority as required. I also congratulate those new members who have spoken before me today, particularly the honourable member for Dawson (Mrs De-Anne Kelly) and the honourable member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis), who both gave particularly interesting and thoughtful speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment on my background and involvement in my electorate of Barton. It is not widely known that in 1958, upon the vacation of the seat of Barton by the late Dr Evatt, who was moved into a safer seat, my father contested preselection against the late Len Reynolds.

I was born in 1958, and so was one of Len Reynolds's sons. In recent years Len's son and I have had the opportunity to discuss our heritage. We both speculated as to whether our creations had any connection with that preselection contest in terms of evening up the public relations aspect. Fortunately I can say that we both concluded neither of our parents would have been influenced in any way by those political events when planning our creation. But my involvement in the political processes of Barton goes back quite some way.

As it turned out my father narrowly lost preselection to Len Reynolds, but he went on to become Len's campaign director. They became great mates and supporters of one another in their respective political careers. That is a feature of the Labor Party which I have learnt to respect—the contest is on but, after the contest, we work together for the cause.

I am aware of the contribution that the late Dr Evatt made to this parliament and his contribution as a great jurist and member of the High Court. Barton is of course named after Sir Edmund Barton, our first Prime Minister, who was a High Court judge. It was Sir Edmund Barton who led the delegation to London on the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Bill, which became our constitution.

It is of particular significance to me that Dr Evatt held the seat. I commenced my legal career some 16 years ago working as an associate to his nephew, the Hon. Phillip Evatt DSC, a judge of the Federal Court of Australia.

Moving on to my immediate predecessor and friend, Gary Punch, I do not think it would be said that Gary, at this stage, is a great jurist, but he will have the opportunity to finish off his law degree now that he is retired from this House. In that respect, with Gary's determination we do not know what may come.

BREAK.PARA: It is in that context of the legal background, of the naming of the seat of Barton and of those who have held it that I focus in this maiden speech.

On 2 March 1996 a new government was elected. We are particularly lucky in this country that the transition of government occurs so easily, with the minimum of disruption and fuss. It occurs because of people's respect, prizing and cherishing of our democratic principles. Regrettably that is still not a common event when you look at the totality of the globe.

There can be no question that the Liberal-National coalition has a mandate to form government in this 38th Parliament, but I will focus on just what is a political mandate. Our democracy would not be valued if it were not based upon fundamental principles of freedom and the rule of law. It is important to remember that democracy has, however, its own capacity for tyranny. The existence of democracy does not indicate liberty among citizens. It is unfortunately the case that some of the most menacing encroachments upon liberty invoke the democratic principle and assert the right to majority rule. In short, our system of government is not based upon the mere exertion of constitutional power obtained from the electorate but adherence to our prized and cherished safeguards against the abuses of arbitrary government action.

One learns very quickly when one enters political life that it is necessary to function in a context of great complexity. There are many people who are distrustful of government. Others are divided into groups who are proponents of their particular philosophies or their particular interests. Many indeed will promote their own self‐interests above the national good. But one way or another they all exert pressure on each and every one of us in this House. It is in that context that any government has to make its decisions.
My belief is that a government which governs simply in the interests of one section of our society is not a democratic government in the sense that we have come to understand that term.

The question is: how does a government discharge what is an unquestioned mandate but, at the same time, balance policies that will beneficially affect some sectors of society and detrimentally affect other sectors of society?

The answer is by acknowledging, respecting and adhering to fundamental liberties and the rule of law which we have inherited. Specifically, in words more eloquent than mine, the late Justice Lionel Murphy said:

Our constitution is affected by the operation of silent constitutional principles which are not mentioned in the constitution . . . they include the principles of responsible government and the separation of the judicial from other powers . . . they include many of the great principles of human rights stated in the English constitutional instruments (the Magna Carta, the Declaration of Rights and the Bill of Rights of 1688) such as those which require observance of due process and disfavour cruel and unusual punishment. They are part of our constitutional heritage (as they are part of the North American heritage) derived from the same English sources . . . these principles emerge from the struggles for freedom against arbitrary government.
His Honour concluded:
Those principles of justice are so rooted in the traditions and conscience of our people as to be ranked as fundamental.

We have literally inherited that concept of the rule of law—or, as the Americans speak of, due process of the law—from generation to generation. In the famous introductory words of the Magna Carta we were given `for ourselves and our heirs forever' the pledges and liberties written in that charter. In chapter 39 of the Magna Carta is found the famous phrase `by the law of land'. Chapter 39 states:

No free man shall be taken, or imprisoned, or disseised, or outlawed, or exiled, or in any way destroyed; nor shall we go upon him, nor set upon him, but by the lawful judgment of his peers or by the law of the land.

That chapter has been repeatedly referred to throughout the ages as being the foundation of what we describe as the rule of law. It is a principle which countless thousands of young men and women have literally died for. Those principles are based on a fundamental rule that no government, nor individual, should act against another to their detriment without giving them the right to be heard in their own defence or interest.

My comments are intended not to be mere platitudes, but to be of very real significance and relevance to government today. The electors of Barton, for instance, have been affected by two significant government actions in the two months that it has been in office. The first is the re-opening of the east‐west runway at Kingsford Smith airport on 20 March 1996. That decision was made after the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) granted an exemption from the need for an environmental impact statement, which was otherwise required under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Those administrative procedures involved in the EIS process would have facilitated constituents with the opportunity of presenting argument as to the detriment they are suffering, and will continue to suffer, from the re-opening of the runway, and measures which should have been taken by the government before any such action was taken. That action was taken under the arrogant boast of democratic mandate.

It appears that, within 24 hours of receiving a request for the exemption, the Minister for the Environment granted such exemption despite a paragraph in the administrative procedures made under the act which states:

The minister shall, in determining whether to exempt a Commonwealth action . . . have regard to the general principle that it is desirable in the national interest that the requirements of those procedures should, as far as reasonably possible, apply to all Commonwealth actions.

We have heard a lot said today about the control of this parliament on executive action. This was an act of executive action which was taken within 24 hours of consideration. It was taken to put planes over the homes of the people of Barton; to literally intrude on their private property—because the concept of property goes from the ground upwards—without giving them the right to be heard, again under the catchcry of `mandate'.

A further significant issue which has affected my electorate of Barton is a decision of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation to transport spent nuclear fuel rods through the electorate without any specific notice to electors, without identification of the route and without giving residents an opportunity to have an input in the proposed method of transport, again through proper EIS procedures. We are not talking about trifles or triviality. We are talking about the transport, in some cases metres from doorways where there were sleeping children, of radioactive waste with undisputed carcinogenic properties.

At the end of the day there may not have been any other means of transporting that waste, or any question as to whether it should have been transported, but the residents of Barton, whose streets were used to transport the substance, had a right to be heard as to how they would be affected by the risks and what steps could have been taken to minimise the risks.

There are very worrying signs in the executive actions, or the actions of instrumentalities, that have occurred in the first two months of this government which give great concern for the right of people to be heard in their own interests—specifically the electors of Barton who have been affected.

On the reverse side of the coin, the concept of the rule of law necessarily means having an agency to identify and enforce that interest. The essentiality of the ability to protect and enforce one's interest was commented upon in the 17th century by Sir Edward Coke, who said that every citizen `has a right for injury done to him by any other subject to take his remedy by the course of the law and have justice and right done to him'.

In that context it is extremely difficult to comprehend how the government could contemplate removing from the capacity of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission the ability for the commission to resolve a wide variety of subject matter which form, and will inevitably continue to form, the subject of industrial disputes.

We are not talking about political principles of union against employer, we are talking about the right of ordinary workers to obtain redress before an unbiased and impartial umpire in respect of such fundamental matters as, for instance, fair promotional opportunities; fair and safe manning levels; unjustified or unfair victimisation by supervisors; the adequacy of rest breaks; the adequacy of breaks between shifts; superannuation; and, of course, job security.

They are matters which affect not only the immediate worker but the worker's family. To say that you are no longer able to seek redress for any impingement on those rights or any threat to change those rights which have been established is to compel both employers and workers to the law of the jungle and, quite literally, anarchy.

While ministers in this House may be in a cloistered environment and their staffers are in a cloistered environment, receiving advice from departmental officers in a cloistered environment, if you talk to any businessmen, to people in the real world, they will say the reason their business has been slow since the election is because of the fear of the outbreak of anarchy. It defies logic as to why any government would even risk such a situation. That risk, which will continue for a long time because of the procedures in bringing this legislation into the House, is highly detrimental to our economy.

In conclusion, I am very much aware that I am here as a result of the dedication and efforts of a great many people. The efforts of Labor Party branch members in my campaign were second to none. The assistance of my family, who are represented here by my mother, my father and my wife, was very significant indeed. I mention also a member of my staff, Nick Melas, who was of great assistance to me in the campaign. It is an honour to have my father here tonight. He is missing out on a meeting of the board of the St. George Leagues Club to attend.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ultimate sacrifice.

—I think that is right. I am very proud to be the third generation of my family to represent the Australian Labor Party in a parliament of this country. My grandfather served in state parliament between 1920 and 1932.

BREAK.PARA: On 22 August 1962 in his maiden speech in the Senate my father said, in respect of his father, Alfred McClelland:

My father had the honour of representing the labour movement for some years in the New South Wales Legislative Assembly. I am told by his colleagues of the time that he was regarded as a fine Labour man. If at the end of my political career I can claim successfully to have emulated my father's high standard of public conduct, I will have performed my task well.

In honour of those two men and their dedication as part of the labour movement to advance society and to strive for the achievement of economic and social justice for all Australians, may I say: if at the end of my political career it is said of me that I was a fine Labor man and if it is said of me that I emulated my father's high standard of public conduct, then I, too, will have performed my task well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Herbert, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and congratulations to you on your appointment. I appreciate the chance to make this speech at the first opportunity. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be hard pressed, as most members here would be, to name the most widely known Aboriginal name in politics. Although for some time many could not pronounce the word, it became a household talking point earlier this year. The word you are all thinking about is also the name of a suburb of Australia's largest tropical city, Townsville. It is the name of a Queensland state electorate. The word, of course, is now part of my state's history—Mundingburra. Mundingburra and its new state member, Frank Tanti, will be remembered for a very long time.

SPEECH.PARA: Mundingburra, too, is very special to me. As a Townsville city councillor, I have represented that suburb for the past 11 years and I now represent Mundingburra at the federal level. As you all know, Mundingburra recently changed the government of Queensland. It focused the national spotlight on the capital city of northern Australia. Today, I again direct the national spotlight to Townsville.

PARA.BREAK: As the light of this national forum reflects on this glass icon, I ask honourable members to reflect on its significance. This is the 1996 award given to Australia's community of the year. This award proudly belongs to Towns ville. This year, Townsville is the brightest star in Australia. From what I am about to outline to you, you will conclude that the city has begun a period of major growth and economic development.

SPEECH.PARA: In the life of this parliament, Townsville will be the fastest growing regional centre in the country. It is very likely we will see a population growth of more than 10 per cent within three years. This is a commercial, Mr Deputy Speaker, with substance. Ministers and members alike need to know and understand that Townsville will be Australia's brightest star for some years to come. Its future is supported by mineral deposits of world significance, by marine science, earth science and tropical medicine research of world significance, and by a government infrastructure such as Australia's largest defence base.

Confidence is on the rise in Townsville and North Queensland. Australia as a whole stands to benefit enormously from the massive injection of capital into the economy of North Queensland that is expected in the near term. The President of the Townsville Chamber of Commerce, Mal Missingham, has provided me with a list of 12 projects committed for completion over the next three years. Together, these 12 projects represent nearly $1 billion worth of investment flowing right now in the Townsville pipeline.

The more business leaders I talk to and the more meetings I attend with the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Regional Development, Townsville Enterprise and the Townsville Chamber of Commerce, the more certain I am that Townsville is at a major development crossroad. Townsville is a city on the move.

Townsville already has a nickel refinery and a copper refinery. A start on a major zinc refinery is only a matter of months away. When completed, the Korea Zinc project will be a $1 billion development in our city—probably the largest single Korean investment outside of Korea. There is a clear message here for both the government and the people of Townsville. In a sense, Korea Zinc is an acid test for North Queensland. The success of this major development will, in effect, be a signal to other companies wanting to invest in North Queensland. A number of major Korean companies are closely watching how Townsville smoothly handles the building of this refinery. Townsville is in the box seat to attract much more substantial Korean development.

However, Townsville and North Queensland need the joint cooperation of the local, state and federal governments to capitalise on the abundance of industry, business, economic and tourist projects that have already been or could be initiated in the region.Locally, the Townsville and Thuringowa city councils have the prime responsibility to immediately address the issues of availability of suitably zoned land, the timely provision of water and waste water services and the giving of attention to waste disposal issues. In particular, water and land issues need immediate attention. In addition, I have asked both local authorities to consider establishing a sister city link with Korea. I have advised the mayors that federal funds are available to assist with this. It is an inexpensive `must do' project.

The state government, for its part, must urgently approve the construction of a base load power station for the city, and it must also ensure that rail and port infrastructure will meet the needs of the coming development. The federal government can contribute through customs and immigration policies that reduce red tape and through contributions to national infrastructure to serve the region. This government can also take the lead in organising local high‐level trade missions to Korea. I have already spoken to Australia's ambassador in Korea in this regard. There is, for example, also the potential to export cattle feed from the Burdekin to Korea.

The new projects I speak of will provide thousands of jobs—thousands of jobs—new road and rail access to the Townsville port, many new secondary industries and value added production generating many more export dollars for our country. But Korea Zinc is not the be-all and end-all for Townsville, nor can we afford to rely on it to be so. We need to look at the spin-off opportunities from downstream mineral processing.

BREAK.PARA: For example, sulfuric acid is one of the major by‐products of zinc processing; it is also one of the primary elements in the production of chemical fertilisers. The development of a chemical fertiliser plant will open up a potential export market worth millions of dollars on a yearly basis. With copper and nickel refineries already established in the region, the capability is there, with the inclusion of a zinc refinery, to expand into the production of alloys and other strategic metals.

As well, Townsville is on the doorstep of the Bowen Basin gas deposits and the Pentland coal reserves. Development of these resources would result in a petrochemical industry being established. However, research funds are needed to ensure the efficient extraction of gas from the coal reserves. James Cook University in Townsville is ideally placed to undertake this research.

I now turn to the need to improve port access. It is clear that a new road-rail access servicing the industrial developments south-east of the city must be provided. The current favoured proposal is to build a new dual link, crossing Ross River near its mouth and extending south-east out of Townsville. This $75 million project provides direct access to the port with minimal impact on existing residential development.

However, there are several matters our community needs to think about. For example, if the fishing fleet were relocated lower down the river, the need to provide an opening rail and road bridge would be eliminated thereby reducing the costs and river traffic delays. Secondly, a strong case could be made to return all port authority land—except for a dedicated road-rail corridor—on the southern bank of the river to an environmental park. Thirdly, I believe that the existing port access for Queensland Nickel and the northern beaches needs to be preserved.

Townsville is also looming as a centre for major advancement in airfreight operations, particularly of perishable goods. The Burdekin and Bowen areas of north-east Queensland produce one-fifth of the state's fruit and vegetables; the vast majority is earmarked for domestic markets. Presently, the exported produce from the region is predominantly handled by southern ports in Brisbane and Sydney, despite the proximity of Townsville's all-weather airport.

There is a business opportunity for the establishment of cold storage export facilities at Townsville airport. For this to be realised, facilities at Townsville airport would have to be upgraded. An export coordination centre, runway improvements and the airport's handling facilities need to be addressed. Of course, all this takes money, but the benefits extend well beyond airfreight.

The RAAF would benefit from these improvements as they would enable the base to comfortably accommodate heavy military transport aircraft, particularly those arriving from the United States. This is a commonsense approach, as RAAF Townsville will have the task of supporting the army's third brigade and the nation's operational Defence Force situated in Townsville.

Improvements would also be a perfect stepping stone to better international airport facilities at Townsville airport. The major jump-off points for international airlines have always been Brisbane and, in recent years, Cairns. The standard of air service, however, between Cairns and Townsville and between Brisbane and Townsville should be seriously re‐evaluated and money invested in feasibility studies for these necessary upgrades for Townsville airport. In this respect, the tourism industry in the Townsville region would also benefit enormously.

Moving on to live exports of another kind, Townsville stands to benefit from the great progress made in recent years in the area of live cattle exports. Live cattle exports are the only shining light in an Australian beef industry that continues to suffer from drought and low prices. This growth has been directly linked to growth in the demand for beef in South‐East Asia—specifically, Indonesia and the Philippines. As Asia's taste for beef grows—and it has been growing rapidly—the demand for packaged, processed and frozen beef will also increase. In areas of Australia where live cattle exports are made from, this has also resulted in growth in frozen and packaged beef exports. Townsville can help fill that demand.

With the new port access in place Townsville residents should have no fear about issues of amenity. Cattle can be railed directly from the Charters Towers district to the port without having to be held in the city. A North Queensland live cattle export enhancement program, initiated by the North Queensland Beef Research Council, is nearing completion. NQBRC have been working closely with the North Queensland Economic Development Board, the Queensland Department of Primary Industries and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation on that project, the aim of which is to improve grazier and buyer live cattle market education and initiate direct trade delegations to South‐East Asia. The program will help pave the way for further growth in North Queensland for live cattle exports, and Townsville is perfectly situated to capitalise on this growth.

As I mentioned at the beginning of my address, Townsville is Australia's brightest star. But it is not just because of the big picture and the grand development element. Queenslanders are parochial at the best of times, but the citizens of Townsville and the twin city of Thuringowa take the cake and I am honoured to be able to represent them. Being parochial and proud of who we are and where we come from is central to our identity.

Footy fans in this House will know that the North Queensland Cowboys joined the Australian Rugby League last year. Now, the Cowboys did not have the best of years by any stretch of the imagination; perhaps they were playing the wrong code. But that did not stop the fans from turning out in droves week after week to see their team in action—win, lose, or draw. In their first year in the league they averaged the third highest home ground attendance figure in the 20‐team competition—a great effort!

The Townsville Suns were the 1993 National Basketball League wooden‐spooners, but that did not stop the supporters from coming in game after game to pack the home court stadium to the rafters. The Townsville Suns are approaching their 42nd sold‐out home game in a row. This is an NBL record. Thankfully, this season is looking much brighter for the Suns. I wish both the Suns and the Cowboys all the very best.

We take great pride in our achievements and this is by no means restricted to the sporting arena. We are always there for one another as a community. There is no better example of this than the VP50 festival, the major reason why Townsville was named Australia's community of the year this year. Townsville's celebration attracted thousands of veterans, visitors, official guests and media from around the world, and was recognised as the centrepiece of the nationwide Australia Remembers campaign. Indeed, it proved to be the genesis of the campaign. Back then, as a member of the Townsville City Council, it was with enormous pride that I watched as the community—old and young—worked hand in hand with business and government and rallied together to make VP50 the enormous success it was.

Now, we must once again rally to bring Townsville and North Queensland through to the next century. We must rally the support and cooperation of the community—of small business, big business and industry, and the local, state and federal governments—to realise the tremendous economic and investment opportunities that are within our reach.

In preparing for my address today I went back through the first speeches of my predecessors who have represented Herbert. One constant theme clearly stood out in those speeches and that was that it was high time that Townsville, Herbert and North Queensland received the recognition and due attention from the federal government that they deserved. In March 1962 the member for Herbert, Ernie Harding, found it necessary—and I quote from his first speech—`to ask for a fair deal for Queensland generally and for North Queensland in particular'.

Since my election as the new member for Herbert I am pleased to be able to say that perhaps I do not have to repeat many of the pleas of my predecessors. Townsville is already receiving close federal attention, and I thank the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) and Senator Grant Tambling for visiting Townsville and delivering on this government's commitment to greater community consultation.

Drawing on a theme from Duke Bonnett, the member for Herbert from 1966 to 1977, visits such as these show the people of northern Queensland that the government recognises our handsome contribution to the progress of this country. It is good to see, too, that the Queensland state government is also taking steps in this direction. Queensland Premier, Rob Borbidge recently opened a North Queensland office of the Premier in Townsville.

But I have also found out that a member's job does not just stop at the big picture scheme of things. Individuals still have concerns and problems which need to be addressed. To conclude, I would like to relay to the House a brief story.

It was a Friday morning and the phone rang—as phones tend to in members' offices—and it was an elderly lady in quite a deal of distress. Her sister—a lady in her late eighties—had fallen ill at home while caring for her bedridden spouse. The couple were fiercely independent people and did not want to be a burden on anyone, so they failed to tell anyone of their situation.

It was a week before the sister became aware that they should have help. She tried all the usual agencies but received the stock answer, `If they don't agree to receive help, then there is nothing we can do.' In desperation, the sister finally rang my office. Lyn Richardson took the call and immediately understood that direct action was needed. She got straight on the phone, dialled up the Blue Nurses and said with all the authority in the world, `This is Lyn from the federal member's office. I have two people who are desperately ill and we need to get them into hospital today.'

The arrangements with the families and the agency were made. A couple of hours later the couple were in hospital under care. The medical staff who attended them said that had they stayed at home unattended over the weekend they would have probably died.

A federal member's office can open a lot of doors and cut through a lot of red tape. In this situation I am convinced it saved two lives. As much as the federal member's job is to represent the community and to serve the nation as a whole, we simply cannot afford to forget the individuals. None of us can be in our electorate offices all the time, but that does not mean that we still cannot offer that individual service.

Two people are still alive today who might otherwise not have been and, indeed, it is a joy and a wonderful thing to help others. However, one victory is not enough. Many other battles remain to be fought and the potential rewards for Herbert, North Queensland and Australia are enormous. My message today is: come to Townsville to invest and come to stay, to live and to work. Come and be part of Australia's Community of the Year.

Before concluding, may I recognise the love I have for my family: my wife, Margaret; my son, Mark; and my daughter, Kylie. Margaret and I are tremendously proud of our family. Mark looks set to become Australia's best young field geologist and Kylie wants to be the first female Prime Minister of this country. I thank my family for their advice and support. Together we work hard for our community and I am pleased and proud that my mum and dad are with us today. Mr Deputy Speaker and members, thank you for your courtesy in listening to my speech. I look forward to working with you all in the life of the current parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, on this occasion I would like to place on the record my congratulations to the Speaker on his election to his high office, and also to you for continuing in the capacity which you have previously served this parliament as Deputy Speaker and, in this case, as Second Deputy Speaker. I am sure you will again bring distinguished service to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Two years ago when I stood in this place to make what was then my first speech to the parliament, I raised the topic of science and technological development. It is very appropriate that that should have been my first speech in this place because I now stand to give my first speech in this parliament as shadow minister for science and information technology. It is a theme which I want to continue in my first speech today to the current parliament.

Science has always been critical to the development of Australia. I think anyone who understands the nature of the Australian continent—we have a very large resource base and a large land mass but a relatively small population by world standards—will understand the importance of science to this country. Science has always underpinned our place in the world. A very creative and innovative approach to basic science has always underpinned the mining activities in this country as well as agriculture, manufacturing and environmental management. Science is one of our greatest national assets. It helps us to exploit the many other natural assets which this country has and, in doing so, it uses one of our other great natural assets: the people of this country and their skills.

How are we going to continue to maintain this very innovative and creative approach which Australians have always brought to science and to the management of it in their country? We have always had a very strong commitment from the public sector. Our public sector science has always been very strong and it has specialised in basic and strategic research which, over the period of the Labor government, increased by some 60 per cent in real terms over that last decade. The CSIRO enjoyed an increase of some 23 per cent in that same period in real terms, and university research has increased by some 164 per cent since 1983. Those are the statistics. They underpin the very strong commitment of the Labor government to science in this country in its various guises and, in particular—as my remarks later will highlight—the importance of basic university research and the funding which has been provided to that in recent years.

PARA.BREAK: Australia, as I am sure honourable members will appreciate, has shown a greater commitment to university research than even the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, Germany or France. As a percentage of GDP, our expenditure on university research ex ceeds all of those countries with whom we would normally be pleased to compare ourselves. All up, government expenditure on research, development and innovation is some $3.6 billion a year. I think it is very important to include innovation with research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: Innovation is a much misunderstood topic in this country and it is one which we have failed to exploit in the past. In the last few years, though, science in this country has also been combined with technological innovation in a way which we have not seen before, but in a way which is vital to the future long-term development of this country. If we are to continue to exploit the advantages which we have—those eminent natural resources on which this country has grown for the last century or more—then we will need to combine more innovation in our research and development, in our civilian science and in the way in which business applies those techniques to manufacturing, agriculture, mining and all of the other assets that this country has. We will also need to ensure that that massive expenditure of over $3 billion a year is able to reward Australians who are contributing through their tax dollars to that very investment.

Honourable members who served with me in the last parliament on the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology of this House—I hope to see it re-established in this parliament because I think it performed a very valuable service in the last and previous parliaments—will be aware of the value of innovation to this country. Innovation has always been a very important part of our psyche and development, but we have failed in the past to adequately target and identify ways in which government and the private sector can contribute to innovation in this country.

What else has government done in recent years? The cooperative research centres would have to be one of the highlights of the Labor Party's contribution to science in this country over the last decade. They represent a massive commitment by government in a whole variety of scientific and very practical endeavours to ensure that the quality of life in this country is enhanced. Recently, I had the opportunity to attend the launch of the Cooperative Research Centre for Water Quality in Adelaide—a very significant development in a state which is often quoted as being one of the driest states in the driest continent in the world.

South Australia has a lot to gain from investment and research on water quality, as Australia generally does, and I know that the CRC which we recently opened in South Australia will return that investment by the public and private sectors many times over. I was certainly struck at the launch of that CRC by the significant number of private sector companies which were prepared to invest their own dollars in that research effort. I am sure that it will certainly repay them, as it will the people of Australia. But how did that process become established? How was that kicked off? Obviously by the very significant leadership and financial commitment of the government sector. Without that investment by the public sector, those private companies would not have had the opportunity to be part of a very exciting research centre.
Debate interrupted.
