SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, can I first place on record my congratulations to you, sir, on your appointment to your high office. Tonight I would like particularly to place on record in this parliament the achievements of some very special individuals in my community and to inform the House of the important recognition they have recently received.

SPEECH.PARA: In May of 1988, 12 Sydney businessmen of Italian origin formed the Italian Affair Committee for the purpose of assisting the Spastic Centre of New South Wales in providing services for babies, children and adults with physical disabilities throughout our state. What began as a very successful exercise in raising donations for the centre's work in general had by 1993 developed into a joint project with the Spastic Centre aimed at establishing a new branch of the organisation in south‐western Sydney.

Known as the `growthpoint project', the Italian Affair Committee became responsible not only for organising the construction of a new centre for disabled people in the greater western Sydney suburbs but also for its financing. Without knowing it, the committee had embarked on bringing the largest community project ever undertaken in Australia to fruition. Of course, time has shown that they not only did so but did it with style.

Firstly, they managed to elicit the donation of a parcel of land from Fairfield City Council for the building of the centre. Next, they coordinated hundreds of local businesses and tradespeople to give their time, expertise and materials for free in the construction of the building. Finally, the committee approached local clubs, businesses and community groups to donate money to assist in the financing of the project.

By October last year when the then Prime Minister, the Hon. Paul Keating, officially opened the building, the Italian Affair Committee had not only been successful in getting the centre up and running for the hundreds of disabled people and their families who live in western Sydney but had also managed to raise approximately $3.5 million for the construction of the new regional centre in the process—this from a total of some $6 million raised by the committee for the New South Wales Spastic Centre over the last seven years.

The centre has some 67 rooms specially built and designed to cater for young people with cerebral palsy. The building of the centre became one of the defining moments of my community. Ordinary Australians gave their time and effort to get the new regional centre off the ground. The Italian Affair Committee inspired people not only to give their physical support to the project but also to dig deep into their pockets in order to turn a dream into a reality.

I would now like to record in Hansard the names of the 12 members of the Italian Affair Committee in order for the House and the rest of Australia to recognise their contribution. The Italian Affair Committee are: convenor, Roy Mittiga, whose son Joey provided the inspiration; chairman, Pat Sergi; vice‐chairman, Tony Labbozzetta, and Roy Spagnolo, Charlie Monti, Tony Brescia, Sam Barone, Frank Carioti, Pat Costa, Ferdie Dominelli, Roland Melosi and Nat Romeo.

As someone very closely involved with the committee, I was determined to see that these individuals received some sort of recognition for their selfless and inspiring acts. I subsequently nominated the group for an Advance Australia Foundation award and am now extremely pleased to report that in February this year it was announced that the nomination had been successful and that the Italian Affair Committee would receive a foundation award for community service.

That, unfortunately, is where my story begins to turn sour. The Advance Australia Foundation awards were introduced in 1980 to recognise publicly individuals and groups in the community for their outstanding contributions to Australia's people and its way of life. When the committee and I were informed of the honour to be bestowed upon them we were delighted. The award had been offered to these 12 men as a group and so we expected, once the arrangements for the awards ceremony had been made, to receive invitations for all of them. What a shock to find that only one member of the 12 and I received an invitation. I thought that there had to be a mistake.

My office contacted the Advance Australia Foundation immediately and alerted them to the error. Only it was not an error. The foundation had deliberately decided to recognise the achievements of all 12 men by asking only one to the ceremony. Was it because there was no room at Government House? No. Government House informed my office that they were happy to have all 12 and their spouses attend. Did it have something to do with the New South Wales Premier and his recent changes to the role of Government House? No. The Premier's Department had no problem with the 12 attending.

BREAK.PARA: The finger ultimately came to point at the Advance Australia Foundation itself. It was the foundation that would not extend the hand of friendship to all of the 12 and to their wives to share tea and biscuits with the Governor of New South Wales. I even offered to pay for the tea and biscuits. And the reason? According to a letter I received from James Malone, chief executive of the foundation, the decision was taken to `keep the numbers attending the ceremonies to within a manageable limit'.

The Italian Affair Committee is unique. It organises and works collectively—not as one chief and his 11 little indians. Decisions and responsibilities are equally shared and so it is entirely appropriate that any recognition of its work should be attended by the entire committee and not just a single officer. The foundation, with its head in the sand, still cannot see this and so I, and I hope the committee, will no longer be attending the ceremony.

It was a shame that this chapter had to be written. But now, thank goodness, the chapter can finally be closed. The Italian Affair Committee will continue with its fundraising efforts while its legacy, the Spastic Centre at Prairiewood, will continue to thrive. It is the foundation's loss that these wonderful men and their wives will not be at the ceremony. It is a stain on the foundation's name that after giving the award to recognise the actions of 12 men it cannot stand the price of a few extra cups of tea and another packet of biscuits to honour them in the correct fashion.

Despite the bad taste that has been left in all of our mouths by this episode, I am still very glad that I nominated the Italian Affair Committee for its award and I am very pleased to know that it won. I am sure that members of this House would support me in congratulating the Italian Affair Committee on its fine work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, before beginning my contribution to the adjournment debate this evening may I take the opportunity to congratulate you, sir, on your elevation to the office of Speaker. I know that you will be fair, you will be firm and you will be impartial. My very best wishes to you.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise tonight the question of homeless youth, an issue which I have raised in this parliament before some years ago and an issue which I brought before the Keating government on many occasions. I received very little satisfaction from the Keating government.

I attended a meeting convened by a Bendigo family who invited a number of other parents from surrounding districts. They brought it to my attention that a number of young people were being encouraged to leave home. The distress that it caused to their families was immense and tragic. I raised this issue with the Keating government at the time and got very little response. That is why today's announcement by the new Prime Minister, the Hon. John Howard, that he would set up a prime ministerial youth homeless task force brought great appreciation from me. I am sure it will be appreciated by the parents who convened that meeting some years ago.

It creates great trauma when young people leave home and cut themselves off from their families and family life. What better way to start off this prime ministerial task force than to appoint Captain David Eldridge from the Salvation Army as chairman of the committee?

I have a very close involvement with the Salvation Army. On Friday in Bendigo I will be launching the Salvation Army's Red Shield Appeal. I know of the very fine work they do—as is done by many other community welfare organisations such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence, St Vincent de Paul, St Luke's Family Care in Bendigo and a whole range of community welfare organisations—in catering and helping to service people who have some disability, who are in discomfort or who are simply having a very tough time.

The Salvation Army is doing a magnificent job in the Bendigo area. I look forward to the work of Captain David Eldridge on the youth homeless task force. I know that the parents of the young people in Bendigo who came to see me and convened that meeting will be appreciative of the efforts of the Prime Minister in convening this task force.

Some of the support services already offered by the Salvation Army in Bendigo include: emergency services; alcohol and drug rehabilitation; emergency housing; family support; material aid provision; employment, training and placement programs; counselling; court work; and aid through their thrift industries. An education program to teach people how to reduce their weekly food bill by shopping cheaply and nutritionally continues to play an important role in the Bendigo community and surrounding areas.

I am sure that the Salvation Army and all of the welfare agencies involved in the task force, which will be overseen by the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), will do an excellent job. It is a very important task that they have been asked to undertake by the Prime Minister. I feel sure that we will come up with some answers. One of the issues that they will need to address is young people being encouraged by some organisations to leave home. They will look at all those departments that have been encouraging young people to leave their homes and the protectiveness of their families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Through representations to me today from the Corio electorate and from press reports, it has been brought to my attention that on Monday at a Christies auction a culturally priceless work of Australian art went under the hammer to a foreign buyer for $1.9 million. That piece of art was Eugene Von Guerard's work View of Geelong , which was painted in 1856. The painting is one of the artist's earliest works and is very significant to Geelong's history. It depicts the area five years after the discovery of gold in Victoria. At that time Geelong was experiencing a surge in its economy, stimulated by the influx of people heading to Ballarat in search of gold and also by the export of wool from its productive western district hinterland through the port of Geelong.

PARA.BREAK: Von Guerard is well known for his panoramic scenes and the fine detail of his paint ings. View of Geelong is no exception. The painting depicts the development of Geelong looking down from Ceres and is in microscopic detail. He has depicted the beginnings of the Geelong West township, sailing and steam ships moored at Point Henry, Yarra Street and the Botanical Gardens.

SPEECH.PARA: The Geelong art gallery in its centenary year worked hard with the assistance of the Visard Foundation and the Victorian state government to put together over $1 million to mount a substantial bid for the painting. On the basis of previous art sales for similar works, it would have been more than enough to win the bid. Alas, that was not so.

There are several issues raised by the sale of this work to foreign buyers. Significant and important movable cultural heritage pieces such as this are protected under the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986. The National Cultural Heritage Committee assesses applications to export such pieces. In this case it has granted an export licence and I and others would like to know why.

The committee recently successfully recommended the retention in Australia of the painting View of the town of Sydney on the basis that it was associated with a significant place or person in Australia. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal upheld the export ban on the basis that the loss of this painting would significantly diminish the cultural heritage of Australia.

I appeal on the floor of this House to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) to directly intervene in this matter, overturn the decision and refuse the export permit. I read with interest that Dr Joseph Brown, an original member of that committee, has expressed a similar view. He has described the sale of this particular piece of work to foreign buyers as treasonable.

The painting is not only of importance to Australia's cultural heritage, it is very important to the people of Geelong. Our regional art gallery is one of the finest in Australia. This painting would be a significant addition to the gallery's collection and would provide an enormous boost to cultural tourism in the city. My appeal goes to the minister to directly intervene. This is a priceless art piece. It is of most significance to the people of Geelong and, indeed, the people of Australia and it must be retained in the city.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on your appointment. It is always a pleasure to come into this chamber as part of a strong, vital and youthful government and, as part of such, I will enjoy addressing you for the next three years. As my fellow members are quite aware, my electorate spans Perth's northern suburbs and is home to more than 100,000 people, all very dedicated to their local member. Although I do not presume to be in the same league as my electorate's namesake, Mrs Edith Dircksey Cowan, I do share many of her philosophies and her personal sense of motivation. Ms Edith Cowan is possibly best known to each of you, indeed to most Australians, as the face on the new $50 note, one of which I have just borrowed from my colleague.

SPEECH.PARA: The new $50 note shows an open, honest and sensitive face accompanied by some smaller illustrations. However, this recognition is really only the postscript to a most remarkable story—a story which commenced on 2 August 1861 in Geraldton, Western Australia, with the birth of baby Edith; an event which was to have a profound effect on the shaping of thought, policy and legislation in Western Australia, if not Australia.

In 1897, nearly 100 years ago, Edith married James Cowan, the brother of one of her early teachers. It was during her husband James's appointment as police magistrate that Mrs Cowan became interested in social questions, the franchise for women, day nurseries and the boarding‐out system.

In 1915, she was appointed as member of the bench of the newly appointed Children's Court—on which she was to sit for a further 18 years. In 1920, she became a justice of the peace and subsequently was given an OBE. By 12 March 1921, following the Western Australian state election, she had the honour of becoming the first woman member of any parliament in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Considered a forceful speaker, Mrs Cowan was responsible for, and succeeded in, amending the Administration Act so that mothers were placed on equal footing with fathers when their children died intestate, and introducing the Women's Legal Status Act which aimed at abolishing the restrictions of entry of women to civil office, occupation and to practise law.

After leaving parliament, Mrs Cowan channelled a great deal of her energies into the National Council of Women, became a freemason, had delegate status to the Sixth International Conference of Women in Washington, and was the first woman appointed to the Provincial Synod of Western Australia. Mrs Cowan was also a member of the Perth Hospital Board, and one of the founders of the Western Australian Historical Society.

Undeniably, Mrs Cowan was an amazing Australian, an amazing woman and an amazing humanitarian. I very much admire her dogged and spirited approach to the real issues, and I respect and support her overriding commitment to eliminating injustice in our community. It is somewhat ironic that these underlying values—in all her work—were established not in the materialistic 1980s, or even in the preceding few decades before this, but in the early 1920s!

Mr Speaker, I bring this to your attention not as a history lesson for my fellow members but to alert you first and foremost to the considerable efforts and talent of Australia's first woman parliamentarians and also to alert you to the fact that this year marks 75 years since Mrs Cowan was first elected to parliament. This is a benchmark of considerable significance and one which should be noted by this House on behalf of all Australians.

Further, I believe that Mrs Cowan could rightly be considered as a catalyst to the reform process which today affords this House and state parliaments of Australia. Mrs Cowan recognised the fact that gender should not be a prerequisite for assuming ability, potential or wealth. This effort and thought has been translated into real terms in that today we have 46 women, in all, represented in this parliament. Simply put, this represents 20.5 per cent of this parliament. This figure, although less than I would personally prefer, recognises the fact that these women have entered parliament not through some arbitrary figure, fact or formula, but through hard work, solid personal performance, a commitment to excellence and a strong skill base.

This year we celebrate the largest contingency of women parliamentarians ever to enter any Australian parliament. This year we celebrate 75 years of women's participation in public office. This year we celebrate the 75th anniversary of Edith Cowan being the first woman to enter parliament in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in some of the comments made by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) about the tremendous work of the Salvation Army because, as he quite correctly remarked, very shortly there will be the Red Shield appeal which is their major annual fundraising exercise. As the City Chairman for Wanneroo, closely involved with the Red Shield appeal in my region, I take a great deal of pleasure in acknowledging some of the key people in the Wanneroo City appeal team. Of course, I look forward to a successful outcome in my second term as the City Chairman for Wanneroo.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I acknowledge Captain Neil Venables from the Heathridge Citadel of the Salvation Army. Neil and his family are tremendous community people. The Heathridge Citadel serves a very large area that has a large number of families in which there are, in some instances, financial hardships and social problems. They do an extraordinarily good job of making sure that they play their part in assisting to alleviate the sorts of common social problems that go hand in hand with these types of things.

I might add that during the last financial year they suffered some quite significant problems in their government funding. That is something that occurred as a result of the fudging of the unemployment figures, because the funding was based on the unemployment for the region. Of course, as the previous government tried to conceal the unemployed through various schemes, then they in fact artificially lowered the threshold for the Salvation Army's funding. That meant in Heathridge they had a shortfall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Which is a shame, as the member for Fairfax quite correctly points out. I would also point out that Lieutenant Paul Hately is at the Merriwa Citadel in Merriwa looking after the needs of a very fast growing community. My electorate is one of the fastest growing regions in the country, and in Merriwa, Clarkson and Butler, the brand new suburb developments in my electorate extraordinarily large numbers of new families with children, many of whom are in lower income brackets, are coming into the electorate, coming into these areas needing that sort of help.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to thank, if I may, Bob Hales, who is a soldier with the Salvation Army and who helps me out on a voluntary basis in my office but who is also very heavily involved with the appeal. I also acknowledge the Mayor of the City of Wanneroo, Councillor Arnold Dammers, who has also taken on a key role in helping out with our fundraising activities for 1996 in the Red Shield appeal.

Secondly, Mr Speaker, I would like to support the comments made earlier today by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in relation to gun control. As somebody said in the last few days, one can make knee‐jerk reactions. But as a former policeman in Western Australia, someone who had a job in the supervision and regulation of firearms licensing and the like, I am conscious of the fact that although in Western Australia we had a very tight and quite strict firearms licence regime, we found it very difficult from time to time when we came across people who had come from other states—in particular, Queensland, where it appears that firearms are much easier to obtain.

I give the example of when I was a uniformed constable at Subiaco. A young fellow of about 22 or 23 arrived in the station. He was doing the right thing, he was being a good citizen. He had actually driven across from Queensland in his ute with a semi‐automatic firearm hanging up in the back of the ute all the way from wherever he had come from in Queensland. He brought the gun in to get it licensed. Of course, we immediately seized it and pointed out to him that, in fact, he had committed an offence ever since he had arrived in Western Australia. Obviously having done the right thing and brought the firearm in, we were conscious that he had done his citizenship bit or duty to try to get himself licensed in Western Australia.

In this particular case, when we asked him why he wanted to have this firearm in the future, he said he was travelling in Western Australia and he needed it just in case he got into trouble. We were not quite sure exactly what sort of trouble he was likely to get into. But, quite clearly, as the Prime Minister has indicated, with a council of police ministers coming up shortly there is a need for not only uniform national gun laws but also a national register of firearms—that is quite clearly now a very important element—and a comprehensive ban on semi‐automatic firearms.

I cannot, for the life of me, see any reason for anyone in Australia, other than a member of the armed services or the police or someone in some other emergency capacity, to own and possess a semi‐automatic firearm. It is, quite clearly, time for all semi‐automatic firearms to be banned and probably time for an amnesty to allow those people who still have them to hand them in without fear of being prosecuted.

I conclude by saying that I subscribe to the bipartisan views of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. Quite clearly, the national government now has a fundamental role in ensuring there are uniform national firearm laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you must allow me to congratulate you on gaining this high office. I wish you well in your deliberations. On occasions you will feel as though you are walking through a minefield but I am quite sure that you, with all your service experience, will handle the job well.

SPEECH.PARA: In the address‐in‐reply debate, one of the most important segments of my speech was to be economic factors; but, unfortunately, I did not get to it. When we think about the economic sectors of the Northern Territory we have to think about the mining sector, the tourism sector, Asian trade, the gas pipeline, defence, primary industry and the horticulture industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about motherhood?

—And motherhood, yes. We will get to statehood at some other stage. The important thing is that the Northern Territory cannot be quarantined from the Commonwealth cuts that are likely to happen. It would be unrealistic to think that we could be. I believe, in light of the deficit which the coalition has inherited from the previous government, we have to be very cautious in terms of what the expectations will be for the Northern Territory. I remind honourable members of the arguments for the Northern Territory to be considered for special funding needs, especially in areas of health, education, housing and roads in smaller remote communities. Land rights and native title have an impact on development, as does the duplication of services by the Commonwealth in the provision of state‐like functions.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic factors cover many sectors—uranium, gold, bauxite, manganese, copper, natural gas, zinc, Timor Gap oil and other products, which represented $1.49 billion worth of exports from the Northern Territory in 1994‐95. With tourism, in the early 1970s our figures were 50,000 tourists a year. In 1994‐95 over one million tourists visited the Northern Territory. Present investment in tourism ventures and infrastructure is over $200 million and the estimate of revenue from tourism in the Northern Territory is $645 million for 1994‐95.

The territory has been at the forefront in developing trade links with Asia over many years. If you draw a radius of 3,000 kilometres north from the city of Darwin you pick up a population base of about 300 million. Come south for 3,000 kilometres and the best you can pick up is a population base of 18 million. Four years ago Asian trade was worth $28 million a year to the Northern Territory; in 1994‐95 it was some $123 million.

Concerning primary industry and live cattle exports, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), in his maiden speech, spoke about the live exports that were evolving from the Townsville region. When the Northern Territory started its live cattle export program some 10 years ago, southern producers thought that they were not on the right boat, but in 1996 we can assume that about 300,000 head of cattle will be exported through the port of Darwin and the indications for 1996‐97 are that, hopefully, as many as half a million head of cattle could be exported through the Darwin port.

Horticulture and aquaculture industries are expanding all the time. I understand that in the pearling industry, which is one of the major fishing industries that we have, exports are totalling in excess of $100 million a year. Defence spending was about $54 million per annum in the territory last year. Obviously, defence has become a very important part of the economic factors in the Northern Territory and all indications are that the coalition is going to maintain the current defence infrastructure and spending in its budget. As I said earlier in the address‐in‐reply debate, one per cent of the population of Australia produces exports to two per cent of the GDP.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very limited time available, all that I now seek to do is to speak on behalf of my colleagues the member for Namadgi, Annette Ellis, and the member for Fraser, John Langmore, about a very special Australian, Netta Burns OAM, who died yesterday and who had perhaps the most extraordinary history in the Labor Party and the Labor movement of anybody of our current generation.

SPEECH.PARA: I had known her for about 10 years when we were jointly celebrating the 1983 victory of the Labor Party and I asked her when she had started working for the Labor Party, expecting her to say, `In 1972.' She said, `Well, the first Prime Minister I worked for was Clement Attlee.' She worked for the British Labour Party during the period of Attlee's leadership and continued to be a great servant of the Labor Party and the Labor movement until this year when she died.

I will have another opportunity publicly to speak of her contribution in many other forums of public life—of her profound knowledge of issues of social security and her commitment to many worthwhile causes. But, time having virtually run out in this adjournment debate, what I want to do today on behalf of my two colleagues and, I think, every member of the Australian Labor Party is to note our profound regret at the passing of this great Australian and to express to her children—Jonathan, Michael, Timothy, Sarah and Rupert, some of whom I am privileged to call my very close personal friends—our great sympathy in their loss. I look forward to the opportunity on another occasion to speak at greater length about this outstanding Australian who made a great contribution to the Labor Party and to Australia and whom all her friends will miss dearly.
